If you've been asked to write one before, you know this is the case. And if this is your first attempt, you probably have a lot of questions. \n<a href=\"https://coschedule.com/blog/content-writing-tips/\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener noreferrer\">Well-written</a> and \n<a href=\"https://coschedule.com/blog/how-research-driven-content-marketing-generates-demand-with-michele-linn-from-mantis-research-amp-095/\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener noreferrer\">research-backed</a> white papers can be powerful tools for earning trust with readers and building brand authority. However, marketers often churn them out with an assembly-line mentality, resulting in uninspired content that under-delivers. Fortunately, you're about to learn how to approach your project the right way, in order to get the best results. In this post, you'll learn: \n<ul> \n <li><strong>What separates top-quality white papers from run-of-the-mill pretenders?</strong></li> \n <li><strong>How to start researching and outlining this type of long-form content.</strong></li> \n <li><strong>The best way to write yours using an included template.</strong></li> \n</ul> Plus, much more. By the time you're done reading, you'll be ready to get started with confidence with advice based 100% on real-world experience. \n<div class=\"link-callout\"> \n <a name=\"toc\"></a>\n <strong>Table of Contents</strong> \n <ul> \n  <li><a href=\"https://coschedule.com/blog/?p=59497#template\">White Paper Template</a></li> \n  <li><a href=\"https://coschedule.com/blog/?p=59497#definition\">What Are White Papers?</a></li> \n  <li><a href=\"https://coschedule.com/blog/?p=59497#examples\">10 Examples of Quality White Papers</a></li> \n  <li><a href=\"https://coschedule.com/blog/?p=59497#process\">White Paper Ideation</a></li> \n  <li><a href=\"https://coschedule.com/blog/?p=59497#outline\">Write Your Outline</a></li> \n  <li><a href=\"https://coschedule.com/blog/?p=59497#research\">Do Your Research</a></li> \n  <li><a href=\"https://coschedule.com/blog/?p=59497#format\">Now, You're Ready to Write</a></li> \n  <li><a href=\"https://coschedule.com/blog/?p=59497#edit\">Edit. Edit. Edit.</a></li> \n  <li><a href=\"https://coschedule.com/blog/?p=59497#how-to\">How to Format Your White Paper</a></li> \n  <li><a href=\"https://coschedule.com/blog/?p=59497#design\">Handing Off for Design</a></li> \n  <li><a href=\"https://coschedule.com/blog/?p=59497#promotion\">Promoting Your White Paper</a></li> \n  <li><a href=\"https://coschedule.com/blog/?p=59497#repurpose\">What’s Next: Repurposing Your White Paper Content</a></li> \n </ul> \n</div> [Tweet \"How to Write White Papers People Actually Want to Read (Template) via @CoSchedule\"] \n<a name=\"template\"></a> \n<h2>Download: White Paper Template</h2> In this post, we'll dig into the nuts and bolts of writing effective white papers. But first, be sure to grab your free white paper template (Word format). Then, use it to put all the advice in this post into practice. [Cookie \"Get Your White Paper Template! || https://coschedule.com/blog/wp-content/uploads/Blog-Ben-WhitePaper-mockup.png || Download Now || https://coschedule.com/blog/wp-content/uploads/White-Paper-Template-1.docx.zip\"] \n<div class=\"link-callout\">\n <a href=\"https://coschedule.com/blog/?p=59497#top\">Back to the Top</a>\n</div> \n<a name=\"definition\"></a> \n<h2>What Are White Papers, Exactly?</h2> A white paper is a document that argues a specific position or solves a problem for its audience. While they originated as official government documents, companies, brands, and nonprofits of all types use them to establish topical authority. According to \n<a href=\"https://owl.purdue.edu/owl/subject_specific_writing/professional_technical_writing/white_papers/index.html\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener noreferrer\">Purdue Owl</a>: \n<blockquote>\n Typically, the purpose of a white paper is to advocate that a certain position is the best way to go or that a certain solution is best for a particular problem. When it is used for commercial purposes, it could influence the decision-making processes of current and prospective customers.\n</blockquote> \n<img class=\"alignnone wp-image-85365 size-full\" src=\"https://media.coschedule.com/uploads/2020/08/white-paper-definition.png\" alt=\"The definition of a white paper.\" width=\"1361\" height=\"581\" /> \n<h3>Determine if a White Paper is Really the Best Content Format</h3> Before you get too far along, you might decide a different format would work better to reach your audience and achieve your goals. Follow this graphic to help decide if writing a white paper is the best approach: \n<img class=\"aligncenter wp-image-85416 size-full\" src=\"https://media.coschedule.com/uploads/2020/08/white-paper-vs-ebook-vs-case-study.png\" alt=\"Decide whether to choose white papers, case studies, or an ebook.\" width=\"1361\" height=\"591\" /> \n<div class=\"link-callout\">\n <a href=\"https://coschedule.com/blog/?p=59497#top\">Back to the Top</a>\n</div> \n<a name=\"examples\"></a> \n<h2>10 Examples of Actual White Papers You Can Follow for Inspiration</h2> What does a white paper usually look like? They're generally formatted as PDFs and look somewhat similar to an ebook or typical research report. Here's an example: \n<img class=\"drop-shadow wp-image-74842 size-full\" src=\"https://media.coschedule.com/uploads/white-paper-example-linkedin-1.png\" alt=\"Example of a white paper from LinkedIn\" width=\"1360\" height=\"825\" /> Here are links to more examples: \n<div class=\"link-callout\"> \n <ul> \n  <li><u><a href=\"https://www.firstperson.is/whitepaper\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener noreferrer\">Unify Business Messaging (First Person)</a></u></li> \n  <li><span style=\"text-decoration: underline;\"><a href=\"https://business.linkedin.com/marketing-solutions/marketing-strategy?u=0\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener noreferrer\">LinkedIn Marketing Resources (a library of white papers)</a></span></li> \n  <li><a href=\"https://www.voxmedia.com/2020/2/26/21155010/its-not-who-you-are-but-what-you-are-consuming\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener noreferrer\"><u>It's Not Who You Are, But What You Are Consuming (Vox Media)</u></a></li> \n  <li><a href=\"https://www.ibmbigdatahub.com/sites/default/files/whitepapers_reports_file/the-path-to-data-veracity-hybrid-cloud-white-paper-72016072usen.pdf\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener noreferrer\">The Path to Data Veracity (IBM</a>)</li> \n  <li><a href=\"https://cloud.google.com/security/overview/whitepaper\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener noreferrer\">Google Security White Paper (Google)</a></li> \n  <li><a href=\"https://www.experian.com/assets/simmons-research/white-papers/demographic-and-preferences-of-coffee-drinkers-in-america.pdf\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener noreferrer\">Coffee in America (Experian)</a></li> \n  <li><a href=\"https://www.apple.com/final-cut-pro/docs/Apple_ProRes_White_Paper.pdf\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener noreferrer\">Apple ProRes (Apple)</a></li> \n  <li><a href=\"https://www.ironcladbrandstrategy.com/white-papers\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener noreferrer\">Ironclad Brand Strategy White Papers (Ironclad)</a></li> \n  <li><a href=\"https://1prismgroup.com/white-paper-brand-dna/\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener noreferrer\">White Paper: Brand DNA (Prism Group)</a></li> \n  <li><a href=\"https://azure.microsoft.com/en-us/resources/azure-stack-hci-overview-white-paper/\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener noreferrer\">Microsoft Azure Stack HCI (Microsoft)</a></li> \n </ul> &nbsp; \n</div> \n<div class=\"link-callout\">\n <a href=\"https://coschedule.com/blog/?p=59497#top\">Back to the Top</a>\n</div> \n<a name=\"process\"></a> \n<h2>First Things First: Understanding What You're Writing About</h2> Let’s figure out what you’re going to write about. This involves several steps. \n<ul> \n <li><strong>Figure out who you're writing for</strong>. Who’s going to read your white paper? Ideally, your organization or agency should have an idea who your target audiences and customers are. If not, we’ve put together a <span style=\"text-decoration: underline;\"><a href=\"https://coschedule.com/blog/how-to-find-your-target-audience/\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener noreferrer\">comprehensive guide that might help</a></span><span style=\"font-family: -apple-system, BlinkMacSystemFont, 'Segoe UI', Roboto, Oxygen-Sans, Ubuntu, Cantarell, 'Helvetica Neue', sans-serif;\">.</span></li> \n <li><strong>Identify problems you can solve for them</strong>. Once you’ve identified your audience, think about what kinds of information they need from you. Secondarily, you might also tie that back into your own products or services. That sets you up at the solution to that problem.</li> \n <li><strong>Align those problems with your product</strong>. When you know what problems to solve, you’ve got a purpose for your white paper. The next challenge, then, is to decide which ones to write about, and from which angle. A simple brainstorming session can help with this.</li> \n</ul> [Tweet \"Before you start writing, you need to understand what you'll be writing about.\"] \n<h3>Some Questions to Get Started</h3> Start by asking a few questions: \n<ul> \n <li><span style=\"font-weight: bold;\">Which problems are top priority?</span>&nbsp;Consider starting with ones that are most pressing or timely.</li> \n <li><span style=\"font-weight: bold;\">Which problems can I tie back into my business?</span> Say your organization wants to be known as an authority on an area you’re new to, or maybe you have a new product or service offering coming out, and want to position yourself as the best option. Find ideas that <a href=\"https://coschedule.com/marketing-strategy/marketing-goals/\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener noreferrer\">align your goals</a> with your audience’s.</li> \n <li><span style=\"font-weight: bold;\">What are we experts on? </span>If you have deep knowledge or expertise on an area you’re known for, a white paper can help reinforce that perception.</li> \n</ul> \n<div class=\"link-callout\">\n <strong>Recommended Reading:</strong> \n <a href=\"https://coschedule.com/blog/content-marketing-brainstorming-process/\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener noreferrer\">The Best 30-Minute Content Marketing Brainstorming Process</a>\n</div> \n<div class=\"link-callout\">\n <strong><a href=\"https://coschedule.com/blog/?p=59497#toc\">Back to the Top</a></strong>\n</div> \n<a name=\"outline\"></a> \n<h2>Next, Write Your Outline</h2> White papers are usually fairly long. The same outlining process you’d use for a shorter piece, like a blog post, will work here. You might need to make it a bit longer or more detailed, though, to avoid getting lost in your thoughts partway through. An effective white paper outline should include: \n<ul> \n <li><span style=\"font-weight: bold;\">Headline: </span>Start with a working version that describes your topic. CoSchedule's&nbsp;<span style=\"text-decoration: underline;\"><a href=\"https://coschedule.com/headline-analyzer\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener noreferrer\">Headline Analyzer</a></span>&nbsp;can help.</li> \n <li><span style=\"font-weight: bold;\">An executive summary</span>: This is essentially a brief (200 words or so) description of what your white paper will be about. Think of it like a short pitch for why someone should write what you’re about to write.</li> \n <li><span style=\"font-weight: bold;\">Your introduction</span>: Which points will you touch on in your intro? These are what you’ll expand on in the body of your white paper.</li> \n <li><span style=\"font-weight: bold;\">Section sub-headings</span>: Like your headline, these don’t need to be final yet, but you should have a clear idea of what you’ll discuss in each section. If your headline is the core problem you’ll solve, consider each sub-heading a sub-point or step toward resolving it.</li> \n</ul> Beneath each sub-heading, include further bullet points clarifying \n<span style=\"font-weight: bold;\">exactly what you’ll write about</span>. Know what you want to say before you try to say it. Consider the following elements: \n<ul> \n <li><span style=\"font-weight: bold;\">Sidebars</span>: White papers often include sidebars or breakout boxes with additional information or data tables, like what you’d find in a magazine. In each section, list any possible sidebar ideas you might have. This could include any research or data you’ll need to find (more on this in a bit).</li> \n <li><strong>Images:</strong> Will you have data or ideas that would be best presented visually?</li> \n <li><span style=\"font-weight: bold;\">Conclusion</span>: Summarize your key takeaways. If it’s appropriate, you might consider adding a call-to-action here, too.</li> \n</ul> Here’s what a hypothetical outline might look like. \n<div class=\"link-callout\">\n <strong><a href=\"https://coschedule.com/blog/?p=59497#toc\">Back to the Top</a></strong>\n</div> \n<a name=\"research\"></a> \n<h2>Do Your Research</h2> Good white papers are fact-based and research-driven. You’re not here to throw your opinions out to the world without data to back them up. Depending on what you’re covering, you might get by with nothing more than Google and your company’s own insights. If you want to take things to the next level, though, you’ll need to do deeper research. [Tweet \"If you want to take things to the next level, you'll need to do your research.\"] \n<h3>Do Your Own Original Research</h3> This is the most difficult option, but it can provide the most valuable results. If you have access to publically-available information, so does your competition. Original research you produced yourself, however, is uniquely powerful. Here are just a few benefits to original research: \n<ul> \n <li><span style=\"font-weight: bold;\">It establishes you and your organization as an authoritative source</span>. Wouldn’t it be awesome if your white paper became a highly-linked source of information for others?</li> \n <li><span style=\"font-weight: bold;\">It gives you something no one else has</span>. And that would make your white paper much more valuable than something anyone could have slapped together spending an afternoon with Google.</li> \n <li><span style=\"font-weight: bold;\">You’ll learn more about your audience and industry</span>. Last year, we did a survey of our blog audience. We were then able to turn our findings into a 5,000+ word blog post. That’s long enough that it could have been a white paper, had we decided to publish it as one. It taught us a lot about our audience, too, including things we wouldn’t have learned otherwise.</li> \n</ul> If you have the time and resources to do your own research study, Andy Crestodina of Orbit Media Studios has a \n<a href=\"https://www.orbitmedia.com/blog/research-best-form-of-content/\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener noreferrer\">f<span style=\"text-decoration: underline;\">antastic guide to get you started</span></a>. \n<h3>Dig Into Research Reports</h3> Industry research reports can provide an excellent data-backed foundation for your content. Here are some potential sources to consider: \n<ul> \n <li><a href=\"https://go.forrester.com/\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener noreferrer\">Forrester</a></li> \n <li><a href=\"https://www.gartner.com/en\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener noreferrer\">Gartner</a></li> \n <li>Do a quick Google search for [YOUR INDUSTRY] + [research firm].</li> \n</ul> This can yield information and insight that will help you effectively build your case. \n<h3>Check Out Wolfram Alpha</h3> \n<span style=\"text-decoration: underline;\"><a href=\"https://www.wolframalpha.com/\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener noreferrer\">Wolfram Alpha</a></span>&nbsp;calls itself a “computational knowledge engine.” What does that mean? It’s a search engine for facts and data with calculation functionality built in. It’s an extremely robust and powerful tool for research. They have plenty of \n<span style=\"text-decoration: underline;\"><a href=\"https://www.wolframalpha.com/resources/\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener noreferrer\">help guides and resources</a></span>&nbsp;to get you on your way. While this video is a bit old, it provides a high-level overview of what you can do with the tool: https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=rRGNS6z5bLY \n<h3>Make Use of Government Websites</h3> Depending on your industry, there are several government websites that might be helpful. Here’s a handful to consider: \n<ul> \n <li><span style=\"text-decoration: underline;\"><a href=\"https://www.sba.gov/offices/headquarters/oee/resources/2836\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener noreferrer\">U.S. Small Business Administration</a></span></li> \n <li><span style=\"text-decoration: underline;\"><a href=\"https://factfinder.census.gov/faces/nav/jsf/pages/index.xhtml\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener noreferrer\">American Fact Finder</a></span></li> \n <li><span style=\"text-decoration: underline;\"><a href=\"https://www.bls.gov/bls/demographics.htm\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener noreferrer\">Bureau of Labor Statistics</a></span></li> \n</ul> \n<div class=\"link-callout\">\n <strong><a href=\"https://coschedule.com/blog/?p=59497#toc\">Back to the Top</a></strong>\n</div> \n<a name=\"format\"></a> \n<h2>Now, You're Ready to Format and Write This White Paper</h2> We’ve done a lot of things so far. Some of it even involved a little bit of writing. Mostly, though, we’ve spent our time getting ready to write. Writing a white paper isn’t easy. You’re now staring down an intense and involved project. If you’re writing in an industry where you’re not a subject matter expert, then your preparation (outlining, researching, and working with internal or client SMEs) is going to be even more important. You’ve got this, though. Flex those fingers, tap into your inner Hemingway, and let’s knock this thing out. \n<div class=\"link-callout\">\n <strong>Recommended Reading:</strong> \n <a href=\"https://coschedule.com/blog/marketing-skills/\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener noreferrer\">The 50 Most Essential Marketing Skills You Need to Be Successful in 2020</a>\n</div> \n<h3>How Do White Papers Differ From Writing Other Types of Content?</h3> We’ve touched on this a little earlier, but it’s worth repeating here. While there are some similarities, writing a white paper isn’t quite like writing a blog post, case study, research report, grocery list… you get the point. It’s decidedly its own animal and should be treated as such. White papers should be: \n<ul> \n <li><span style=\"font-weight: bold;\">Professional in tone: </span>This is formal, almost academic-style writing.</li> \n <li><span style=\"font-weight: bold;\">Narrowly-focused: </span>Pick one topic and explore it thoroughly.</li> \n <li><span style=\"font-weight: bold;\">Fact-based:</span>&nbsp;Unverified claims don’t belong here.</li> \n <li><span style=\"font-weight: bold;\">Data-backed: </span>You don’t have to like math, but you have to love what numbers can do to make your writing stronger.</li> \n</ul> \n<img class=\"alignnone wp-image-85366 size-full\" src=\"https://media.coschedule.com/uploads/2020/08/white-paper-purpose.png\" alt=\"The different qualities of a white paper.\" width=\"1361\" height=\"661\" /> [Tweet \"White papers should be professional in tone, narrowly-focused, fact-based, and data-backed.\"] \n<h3>Writing Your Title Or Headline</h3> \n<a href=\"https://coschedule.com/blog/how-to-write-the-best-headlines-that-will-increase-traffic/\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener noreferrer\">Your headline</a> is the first thing that will sell your white paper to your audience. You want to write something that conveys clear value up front and gets them to click. However, you also want to avoid anything that could be perceived as click bait, or overly casual. Your headline should hit each of the following checkboxes: \n<ul> \n <li><span style=\"font-weight: bold;\">Establish a clear benefit to your reader</span>: Why should they care? What’s in it for them to read past your title page? Including interesting stats or a strong action verb can help.</li> \n <li><span style=\"font-weight: bold;\">Sound professional</span>: Even if your blog or social media content is fun and light-hearted, a white paper should strike a professional tone. It doesn’t need to be sterile and lifeless, per se, but use your best judgment here.</li> \n <li><span style=\"font-weight: bold;\">Set realistic expectations for your reader</span>: If your headline reads, “Ten Ways Shipping Companies Can Deliver Faster Shipments,” you better go into detail on all ten tactics. You’d be surprised how many “white papers” throw a paragraph of text surrounded by images onto a page and call it good.</li> \n</ul> Let’s take a look at five hypothetical headline examples you can follow: \n<ol> \n <li><span style=\"font-style: italic;\">How SaaS Companies Can Onboard 53% More Customers In 2017</span></li> \n <li><span style=\"font-style: italic;\">Why Are Content Calendars Important For Marketing Teams</span></li> \n <li><span style=\"font-style: italic;\">7 Ways Small Businesses Can Compete With Enterprise Corporations</span></li> \n <li><span style=\"font-style: italic;\">Why Companies Should Use Agile Project Management</span></li> \n <li><span style=\"font-style: italic;\">How Nonprofits Can Do Better Fundraising</span></li> \n</ol> These examples aren’t wildly creative, but they all include at least one of the following: \n<ul> \n <li>A clear benefit</li> \n <li>A stat or action verb</li> \n <li>A professional tone</li> \n</ul> \n<img class=\"alignnone wp-image-85367 size-full\" src=\"https://media.coschedule.com/uploads/2020/08/headline-contents.png\" alt=\"What a headline should include.\" width=\"1361\" height=\"624\" /> \n<h3>Writing Your Introduction</h3> \n<a href=\"https://coschedule.com/blog/blog-post-introductions/\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener noreferrer\">Your intro should quickly hook your audience</a> while covering the main points the rest of your document will cover. Here’s everything it should cover: \n<ul> \n <li><span style=\"font-weight: bold;\">State the problem your white paper intends to solve</span>. To create added urgency, it should also touch on the consequences for not taking action.</li> \n <li>&nbsp;<span style=\"font-weight: bold;\">Summarize the key areas your white paper will cover</span>. Give a high-level overview of what readers can expect from start to finish.</li> \n <li>&nbsp;<span style=\"font-weight: bold;\">Explain the benefits of reading your white paper</span>. What will your reader be equipped to do after reading what you have to say?</li> \n</ul> \n<h3>Writing Each Subsection</h3> Once you’ve hooked a reader’s attention with your intro, you’ll want to keep it. Make sure each section delivers on the promises you made in your introduction. When you’re writing an extremely long-form piece, it can be easy to get lost. That’s why sticking to an outline is so important, and we do hope you spent some time putting one together. With thorough research and a strong outline in hand, you can make the actual writing exponentially easier. Let’s look at a hypothetical outline: \n<span style=\"font-style: italic;\">How to Select a Veterinarian </span> \n<ul> \n <li><span style=\"font-style: italic;\">Find options in your area.</span></li> \n <li><span style=\"font-style: italic;\">Research each one.</span></li> \n <li><span style=\"font-style: italic;\">Make a call.</span></li> \n</ul> \n<div class=\"link-callout\">\n <strong>Recommended Reading:</strong> \n <a href=\"https://coschedule.com/blog/content-marketing-editorial-calendar-template/\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener noreferrer\">The Best Way to Get Organized With a Content Marketing Editorial Calendar (Template)</a>\n</div> If we were to write this section, we’d start with a paragraph about the importance of selecting a good veterinarian. We’d then dedicate a paragraph or two (or more) to each sub-point. Following this order will ensure your writing flows well from one point to the next in a logical order. When writing each section, consider using bulleted lists to make text easy to skim. For example: \n<ul> \n <li>This is an insightful point about your topic.</li> \n <li>Here’s another interesting piece of data.</li> \n <li>Finally, here is a third important takeaway.</li> \n</ul> Continue until you’ve worked through each portion of your outline. \n<div class=\"link-callout\">\n <strong><a href=\"https://coschedule.com/blog/?p=59497#toc\">Back to the Top</a></strong>\n</div> \n<a name=\"edit\"></a> \n<h2>Edit. Edit. Edit.</h2> Your first draft of a large document like this won’t be perfect, so it’s important to have a \n<a href=\"https://coschedule.com/blog/content-editing/\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener noreferrer\">sound editing process</a> in place. If your organization has another writer or editor on staff, then work together to polish your draft. \n<h3>Establish a Set Editing Process</h3> Know who your editor will be ahead of time and develop a set process. In our experience, it’s easiest to use tracked changes in Microsoft Word or Google Docs. \n<img class=\"alignnone wp-image-85368 size-full\" src=\"https://media.coschedule.com/uploads/2020/08/establish-your-process.png\" alt=\"Establish your editing process.\" width=\"1361\" height=\"485\" /> If you don’t have access to an editor, and even if you do, tools like \n<span style=\"text-decoration: underline;\"><a href=\"http://grammarly.com\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener noreferrer\">Grammarly</a></span>&nbsp;and \n<span style=\"text-decoration: underline;\"><a href=\"http://www.hemingwayapp.com/\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener noreferrer\">Hemingway</a></span>&nbsp;can also be life-savers. https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=JJ9_6ipZ6ws \n<h3>Edit for Content, Not Just Grammar</h3> While editing a white paper (or anything), it’s important to edit for content, and not just spelling and grammar. This entails asking the following questions: \n<ul> \n <li><span style=\"font-weight: bold;\">Does this content answer all the questions a reader might have?</span>&nbsp;If something important is missing, note it for the writer.</li> \n <li><span style=\"font-weight: bold;\">Is everything factually accurate?</span>&nbsp;Double-check facts, statistics, and sources.</li> \n <li><span style=\"font-weight: bold;\">How easy is your writing to understand?</span>&nbsp;If there is language or jargon your audience may not understand, note it and consider alternatives. This can be corrected with a simple search on <span style=\"text-decoration: underline;\"><a href=\"http://www.thesaurus.com/\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener noreferrer\">Thesaurus.com</a></span>.</li> \n</ul> This isn’t to say \n<a href=\"https://coschedule.com/blog/process-social-media-following-celeste-mora-grammarly-amp-025/\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener noreferrer\">correcting grammatical and spelling errors</a> isn’t important. Far from it. However, it’s just as important (if not more so) to ensure the quality of your information is up to par as well. \n<div class=\"link-callout\">\n <strong><a href=\"https://coschedule.com/blog/?p=59497#toc\">Back to the Top</a></strong>\n</div> \n<a name=\"how-to\"></a> \n<h2>How to Format Your White Paper</h2> If you’re fortunate enough to have a designer on your team, they’ll likely handle design and formatting for you. However, if you’re on your own, don’t worry! That’s why we included a free white paper template in this post. Here’s how to edit it and make it work for you. Start by filling in your title page; it looks like this: \n<img class=\"drop-shadow aligncenter wp-image-74751 size-full\" src=\"https://media.coschedule.com/uploads/white-paper-template-header.png\" alt=\"Title page for white paper template\" width=\"1360\" height=\"343\" /> &nbsp; Simple enough. Next, follow the instructions included in the template to fill in each content section: \n<img class=\"drop-shadow aligncenter wp-image-74752 size-full\" src=\"https://media.coschedule.com/uploads/white-paper-template-introduction.png\" alt=\"Introduction section of white paper template\" width=\"1360\" height=\"713\" /> &nbsp; Now, you might want to adjust the appearance of your fonts and headers. This is easy to do with Microsoft Word. All you have to do is edit your styles. Find the styles pane and right-click what you’d like to change. Let’s start with \n<strong>Normal</strong>: \n<img class=\"drop-shadow alignnone wp-image-74787 size-full\" src=\"https://media.coschedule.com/uploads/Blog-Ben-WhitePaper_Update-14.png\" alt=\"Formatting your headers on Microsoft Word.\" width=\"1541\" height=\"176\" /> Next, click \n<strong>Modify</strong>: \n<img class=\"drop-shadow aligncenter wp-image-74754 size-full\" src=\"https://media.coschedule.com/uploads/update-match-style.png\" alt=\"Where to find Update to Match Style\" width=\"1360\" height=\"333\" /> Now, you can change your \n<strong>standard paragraph text</strong>: \n<img class=\"drop-shadow aligncenter wp-image-74755 size-full\" src=\"https://media.coschedule.com/uploads/modify-style.png\" alt=\"Modify Style\" width=\"1360\" height=\"1294\" /> &nbsp; If you’d like to change your Heading 1, 2, and 3 styles, follow the same process. \n<div class=\"link-callout\">\n <strong><a href=\"https://coschedule.com/blog/?p=59497#toc\">Back to the Top</a></strong>\n</div> \n<a name=\"design\"></a> \n<h2>Handing Off for Design</h2> Unless you happen to be a skilled designer, it will be best to have a designer \n<a href=\"https://coschedule.com/blog/how-to-design-blog-graphics-with-free-tools/\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener noreferrer\">create graphics</a> for your white paper. Your designer is likely going to need some direction from you, though, so your work isn’t done yet. [Tweet \"Your designer is likely going to need some direction from you.\"] \n<h3>How to Provide Designers With Image&nbsp;Direction</h3> While writing, think about what kinds of images you’d like. Make notes in your doc that include the following information: \n<ul> \n <li><span style=\"font-style: italic;\">GRAPHIC HEADLINE</span>: [<span style=\"font-style: italic;\">Include a brief header or title for your graphic</span>]</li> \n <li><span style=\"font-style: italic;\">GRAPHIC COPY</span>: [<span style=\"font-style: italic;\">Include descriptive copy</span>]</li> \n <li><span style=\"font-style: italic;\">GRAPHIC DATA</span>: [<span style=\"font-style: italic;\">Include statistics, numbers, percentages, metrics, and so forth</span>]</li> \n <li><span style=\"font-style: italic;\">GRAPHIC NOTES</span>: [<span style=\"font-style: italic;\">Include other thoughts or image direction for your designer</span>]</li> \n</ul> That should be enough to give your designer an idea of what to create. \n<div class=\"link-callout\">\n <strong>Recommended Reading:</strong> \n <a href=\"https://coschedule.com/blog/how-to-work-with-designers/\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener noreferrer\">How to Work With Designers With Authentic Advice From CoSchedule's Designer</a>\n</div> \n<h3>One-Column Vs. Two-Column Layout (Or Something More Creative)</h3> If your white paper is lengthy, you might want to consider a two-column layout. That’s because they’re easier to read and skim, thanks to shorter line length. If your designer is good, you can get creative with how a multi-column layout might look. Check out \n<span style=\"text-decoration: underline;\"><a href=\"https://business.linkedin.com/marketing-solutions/cx/17/02/the-sophisticated-marketers-guide-to-linkedin\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener noreferrer\">this example from LinkedIn</a></span>&nbsp;(\n<span style=\"font-style: italic;\">email signup required</span>): \n<img class=\"drop-shadow aligncenter wp-image-74849 size-full\" src=\"https://media.coschedule.com/uploads/creative-column-layout.png\" alt=\"Example of a creative white paper layout\" width=\"1360\" height=\"832\" /> &nbsp; If you’re working on your own, your template can easily be converted into a two-column layout. Highlight your text, find the Layout tab, and select either one or two columns: \n<img class=\"drop-shadow aligncenter wp-image-74757 size-full\" src=\"https://media.coschedule.com/uploads/change-columns.png\" alt=\"Changing columns in Word\" width=\"1360\" height=\"614\" /> \n<div class=\"link-callout\">\n <strong><a href=\"https://coschedule.com/blog/?p=59497#toc\">Back to the Top</a></strong>\n</div> \n<a name=\"promotion\"></a> \n<h2>Promoting Your White Paper</h2> You’ve put a ton of work into your white paper. Now, how do you get people to actually read it? The answer is with a comprehensive promotion plan. \n<h3>Decide Where to Host Your White Paper</h3> The first thing you’ll need to decide is where your white paper is going to live. Do you host it on your website? Your blog? A landing page? There are pros and cons to each. Let’s cover each one: \n<ul> \n <li><span style=\"font-weight: bold;\">Landing Pages</span>: <a href=\"https://coschedule.com/blog/how-to-write-landing-pages/\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener noreferrer\">Landing pages</a> are perfect for hosting your white paper on an attractively-designed page that’s optimized to convert. You can easily build landing pages with tools like <a href=\"https://unbounce.com/\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener noreferrer\">Unbounce</a>, <a href=\"https://www.leadpages.net/\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener noreferrer\">Lead Pages</a>, or <a href=\"https://instapage.com/\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener noreferrer\">Instapage</a>.</li> \n <li><span style=\"font-weight: bold;\">Blog Posts</span>: This is a quick and simple option. <a href=\"https://coschedule.com/blog/blog-writing-process/\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener noreferrer\">Blog posts</a> also give you room to provide context for your white paper. Plus, being on your blog’s home page can also give it more visibility.</li> \n <li><span style=\"font-weight: bold;\">Website Pages</span>: Resource libraries are a strong spot to put white papers. Consider creating something similar to <a href=\"https://mailchimp.com/resources/\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener noreferrer\">MailChimp’s resource library</a>:</li> \n</ul> \n<img class=\"aligncenter wp-image-59699 size-full\" src=\"https://coschedule.com/blog/wp-content/uploads/blog_white-papers-09.png\" alt=\"MailChimp resource page.\" width=\"770\" height=\"425\" /> It might be possible to combine approaches, too. For example, you could create a landing page for your white paper, link to it in a blog post, and then include the actual document in your resource library. That’s maximizing the exposure for your hard work. \n<div class=\"link-callout\"> \n <strong>Recommended Reading:&nbsp;</strong>\n <a href=\"https://coschedule.com/blog/best-times-to-post-on-social-media/\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener noreferrer\">What 23 Studies Say About the Best Times to Post on Social Media</a> \n</div> \n<h3>Use Your Email List</h3> If your email list is comprised primarily of professionals interested in the kind of research in your white paper, then send it to them. Keep these thoughts in mind: \n<ul> \n <li><span style=\"font-weight: bold;\">Stick to a professional tone</span>. You want to sound authoritative.</li> \n <li><span style=\"font-weight: bold;\">Focus on the value for your email recipien</span>t. Everything you write should be keeping this in mind.</li> \n <li><span style=\"font-weight: bold;\">Include a link at the bottom of your other emails</span>. If you send email newsletters, consider adding a section for your white paper there, too.</li> \n</ul> \n<div class=\"link-callout\">\n <strong>Recommended Reading:</strong> \n <a href=\"https://coschedule.com/blog/how-to-build-an-email-list/\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener noreferrer\">21+ Ways to Build an Email List That Will Skyrocket By 140% In 1 Year</a>\n</div> \n<div class=\"link-callout\">\n <strong><a href=\"https://coschedule.com/blog/?p=59497#toc\">Back to the Top</a></strong>\n</div> \n<a name=\"repurpose\"></a> \n<h2>What’s Next: Repurposing Your White Paper Content</h2> Quality white papers take a lot of work to produce, so make the most of it by repurposing its contents elsewhere. Here are a few ways to do this. \n<h3>Spin Your Sub-Sections Into Blog Posts</h3> You can likely write an entire blog post based on each section of your white paper. This gives you the opportunity to drill deeper into each specific point. Plus, if you link back to your white paper in each post, you can direct more attention toward it. Follow this process to help turn one small point into a much deeper and valuable blog post: \n<ol> \n <li><span style=\"font-weight: bold;\">Take a section of your white paper you think you could have expanded upon further</span>.</li> \n <li><span style=\"font-weight: bold;\">Start writing hypothetical headlines that could work for a blog post</span>.</li> \n <li><span style=\"font-weight: bold;\">Then, start building an outline</span>. Which points or information weren’t you able to include in your white paper? Go back to your research and dig deep to add more detail.</li> \n <li><span style=\"font-weight: bold;\">Write your next blog post.</span></li> \n</ol> Do this for each piece of your white paper, and you’ll quickly have multiple pieces of content promoting your white paper. That’ll help you get the most mileage possible for your efforts. \n<h3>Leverage Your Research Elsewhere</h3> You probably dug up tons of interesting stats and pieces of information while doing your research. Use that information in other content you write. For example, you could easily: \n<ul> \n <li><span style=\"font-weight: bold;\">Create new social media content sharing intriguing stats from your research.</span></li> \n <li><span style=\"font-weight: bold;\">Include research findings in other reports or blog posts (with or without referencing your white paper, as appropriate)</span>.</li> \n <li><span style=\"font-weight: bold;\">Pitch a speaking engagement based on your findings. </span>Dig up something your audience would be interested in? Do you belong to any professional groups or do any public speaking? Consider using part of your research as a topic for a speaking engagement or conference session.</li> \n</ul> \n<div class=\"link-callout\">\n <strong><a href=\"https://coschedule.com/blog/?p=59497#toc\">Back to the Top</a></strong>\n</div> \n<a name=\"conclusion\"></a> \n<h2>Ready. Set. Write.</h2> We’ve now guided you through all the steps to writing an effective white paper. With the information in this post, plus the included template, you should have everything you need to do the job right. Let’s recap quick: \n<ul> \n <li><span style=\"font-weight: bold;\">We discussed what a good white paper should (and shouldn’t) be</span>. Offer your readers unique, valuable, and well-researched insights on one specific topic. Don’t slap together thin content, make it look nice, gate it behind an opt-in form, and then call it day.</li> \n <li><span style=\"font-weight: bold;\">We walked through a complete writing process to produce the final document</span>. From ideation all the way through design, every step of the process has been covered.</li> \n <li><span style=\"font-weight: bold;\">We touched on what comes next once your white paper is published</span>. Seriously, if you’re going to set aside the time to write a white paper (which could take days or weeks to produce), then get the most return on it you possibly can. Spin that sucker into as many content assets as you can think of.</li> \n</ul> \n<em>This post was originally written on May 18, 2017. It was updated and republished on August 12, 2020.</em>\n<p>The post <a rel=\"nofollow\" href=\"https://coschedule.com/blog/how-to-write-white-papers-templates-examples/\">How to Write White Papers People Actually Want to Read (Template)</a> appeared first on <a rel=\"nofollow\" href=\"https://coschedule.com\">CoSchedule Blog</a>.</p>","descriptionType":"html","publishedDate":"Wed, 12 Aug 2020 ttps://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx21/cdn100@2020_2/2020/08/24/21-56-39-231_7a4cb98db3ae32d3.webp","https://media.coschedule.com/uploads/creative-column-layout.png":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx4/cdn24@2020_5/2020/08/24/21-56-40-180_d5c9a2c6193c3188.webp","https://media.coschedule.com/uploads/change-columns.png":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx21/cdn40@2020_1/2020/08/24/21-56-33-729_ce4737ff0bc87118.webp","https://coschedule.com/blog/wp-content/uploads/blog_white-papers-09.png":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx6/cdn75@2020_4/2020/08/24/21-56-38-085_411a570deb181d7f.webp"},"publishedOrCreatedDate":1598306169443},{"createdTime":"2020-08-25 05:56:09","updatedTime":"2020-08-25 05:56:09","title":"Marketing Operations: The Start to Finish Guide for Busy Managers","link":"https://coschedule.com/?p=77388","description":"<img class=\"alignnone wp-image-84271 size-full\" src=\"https://media.coschedule.com/uploads/2020/07/marketing-operations-header.gif\" alt=\"Marketing operations guide for busy marketers header\" width=\"1360\" height=\"580\" /> You’re managing a team of marketers. Each has a different job, a different set of tools, and a different way of working. How can you manage those and make sure they’re spending their time effectively \n<span style=\"font-style: italic;\">without</span>&nbsp;getting on their bad side? You don’t want to be a micro-manager, after all. Luckily, there are a set of processes that you’ll need to make sure your team is spending time on \n<span style=\"text-decoration: underline;\"><a href=\"https://coschedule.com/marketing-strategy/marketing-tactics/\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener noreferrer\">high-growth activities</a></span>. It starts with a solid marketing operations team. \n<h2>Download Your Marketing Operations Templates</h2> Putting this advice into practice will take some tools. Get started with some downloadable options in this kit: \n<ul> \n <li><strong>Performance Review Question Template:</strong> Identify bottlenecks in marketing workflows by helping team members identify performance problems.</li> \n <li><strong>Performance Management Checklist:</strong>&nbsp;Never miss another important step when it comes to maximizing your team's potential.</li> \n <li><strong>Marketing Project Checklist Template:</strong> Build consistent processes and workflows for every marketing project.</li> \n <li><strong>Marketing Project Management Plan Template:</strong> Plan and organize a consistent approach to managing projects.</li> \n <li><strong>Marketing Project Management Calendar Template:&nbsp;</strong>Visualize deadlines and organize projects in one place — with full visibility for your entire team.</li> \n</ul> [Tweet \"Marketing operations: the start to finish guide for busy marketers.\"] [Cookie \"Get Your Marketing Operations Templates || https://media.coschedule.com/uploads/2020/07/Blog_Marketing-Operations_outlines-07-2.png || Download Now || https://media.coschedule.com/uploads/Marketing_Operations_Templates.zip\"] \n<div class=\"link-callout\"> \n <a name=\"toc\"></a>\n <strong>Table of Contents</strong> \n <ul> \n  <li><a href=\"https://coschedule.com/?p=77388#definition\">What is Marketing Operations?</a></li> \n  <li><a href=\"https://coschedule.com/?p=77388#manager\">What Does a Marketing Operations Manager Do?</a></li> \n  <li><a href=\"https://coschedule.com/?p=77388#important\">Why is Marketing Operations Important?</a></li> \n  <li><a href=\"https://coschedule.com/?p=77388#five\">5 Marketing Operations Processes You Need</a></li> \n  <li><a href=\"https://coschedule.com/?p=77388#implement\">How to Implement a Marketing Operations Process</a></li> \n  <li><a href=\"https://coschedule.com/?p=77388#processes\">Operationalizing Your Marketing Processes</a></li> \n  <li><a href=\"https://coschedule.com/?p=77388#agile\">Consider Implementing an Agile Approach</a></li> \n  <li><a href=\"https://coschedule.com/?p=77388#conclusion\">Ready to Get Started?</a></li> \n </ul> \n</div> \n<a name=\"definition\"></a> \n<h2>What is Marketing Operations?</h2> Wondering exactly what “marketing operations” means? This term describes how a marketing team runs. Also known as “MO,” it’s broken up into three main roles: \n<ol> \n <li>Data</li> \n <li>Technology</li> \n <li>People</li> \n</ol> Marketing operations is the piece of the puzzle that defines how a marketing team runs behind the scenes. It makes sure campaigns run smoothly, team members are happy, and more importantly —\n<span style=\"text-decoration: underline;\">&nbsp;<a href=\"https://coschedule.com/marketing-strategy/marketing-goals/\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener noreferrer\">meet their goals</a></span>. \n<img class=\"alignnone wp-image-84272 size-full\" src=\"https://media.coschedule.com/uploads/2020/07/marketing-operations.png\" alt=\"Definition of marketing operations\" width=\"1360\" height=\"1190\" /> \n<div class=\"link-callout\">\n <strong><a href=\"https://coschedule.com/?p=77388#toc\">Back to the Top</a></strong>\n</div> \n<a name=\"manager\"></a> \n<h2>What Does a Marketing Operations Manager Do?</h2> Ready for some obvious news? The person handling this part of a marketing strategy is called a marketing operations manager. This person handles the HR of their team, \n<span style=\"text-decoration: underline;\"><a href=\"https://coschedule.com/marketing-strategy/\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener noreferrer\">marketing strategy</a></span>, and toolstack. It’s their job to make sure they’ve got a strong team who is equipped with the best technology and training to create ground-breaking marketing campaigns. \n<div class=\"link-callout\">\n <strong>Recommended Reading:</strong> \n <a href=\"https://coschedule.com/blog/agile-marketing-training-resources/\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener noreferrer\">16 Awesome Agile Marketing Resources to Train Your Busy Team</a>\n</div> A marketing operation manager’s main goal is to optimize the entire marketing process — from budgeting for each campaign and managing assets, to optimizing ROI and sending MQLs to sales. Lower-level marketing staff will report to them. They typically report to a CMO or CEO on behalf of the entire marketing department. This video, from \n<a href=\"https://www.informatica.com/\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener noreferrer\">Informatica</a>, does an excellent job breaking down what their work entails. https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=azYKE6gX5yo \n<div class=\"link-callout\">\n <strong><a href=\"https://coschedule.com/?p=77388#toc\">Back to the Top</a></strong>\n</div> \n<a name=\"important\"></a> \n<h2>Why is Marketing Operations Important?</h2> Now we’re clear on what marketing operations actually is, so let’s move on to the juicy part: why it’s important. We’ve already mentioned that a marketing operations manager wants to improve the output of their marketing team. That’s why one of their main priorities is to work on boosting staff productivity. [Tweet \"A main priority for a marketing operations manager is to boost staff productivity.\"] In practice, this could be a social media marketer complaining that they spend too much time doing a low-output task. That time-consuming task might be pulling their focus away from something more important or of higher value, which impacts how much work they get done. In turn, the marketing operations manager would look for tools to do it for them. Before you brush this off as a niche example, remember that modern technology could automate \n<span style=\"text-decoration: underline;\"><a href=\"https://www.mckinsey.com/business-functions/mckinsey-digital/our-insights/four-fundamentals-of-workplace-automation\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener noreferrer\">45% of the activities</a></span> people are paid to perform. There’s always a task you can cut; it’s a marketing operations manager’s job to spot it. \n<img class=\"alignnone wp-image-84273 size-full\" src=\"https://media.coschedule.com/uploads/2020/07/dopson-quote.png\" alt=\"Quote from Elise Dopson about managers cutting tasks.\" width=\"1360\" height=\"580\" /> Marketing operations also keeps a marketing team on track to meet their goals. Let’s say that your monthly report shows you’re behind on your KPIs, and you aren’t predicted to meet your forecast of 500,000 website visitors by the end of Q1. Your marketing operations manager spots this, and plans a way to fix it — maybe with new assets, extra promotion of existing content, or budget for advertising. Either way, the problem is solved before it starts stunting growth even further. \n<img class=\"alignnone wp-image-84274 size-full\" src=\"https://media.coschedule.com/uploads/2020/07/mo-process.png\" alt=\"The process behind how marketing operations functions.\" width=\"1360\" height=\"4386\" /> \n<div class=\"link-callout\">\n <strong><a href=\"https://coschedule.com/?p=77388#toc\">Back to the Top</a></strong>\n</div> \n<a name=\"five\"></a> \n<h2>5 Marketing Operations Processes You Need</h2> Now you know that marketing operations is a key part of any marketing department, you might be questioning which processes your manager will handle. Here are five processes you need to create from the get-go: \n<h3>1. Budget Management</h3> Did you know that the average company spends \n<span style=\"text-decoration: underline;\"><a href=\"https://vtldesign.com/digital-marketing/content-marketing-strategy/percent-of-revenue-spent-on-marketing-sales/#:~:targetText=The%20average%20percentage%20of%20total,The%20least%20successful%20spend%2014%25.\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener noreferrer\">26% of their annual revenue</a></span>&nbsp;on marketing? Sure, your marketing operations manager will need a process to define how much of your revenue will be assigned to marketing efforts. They’ll also need to break down how that budget is proportioned to various channels or departments, such as: \n<ul> \n <li>Email marketing</li> \n <li>Social advertising</li> \n <li>Content creation</li> \n</ul> This process varies dramatically from company to company. You might decide to \n<span style=\"text-decoration: underline;\"><a href=\"https://blog.hubspot.com/marketing/how-to-manage-marketing-budget-free-budget-templates\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener noreferrer\">split your budget</a></span> proportionally based on how important each channel is for your business, or you might be planning an advertising campaign that needs more budget at specific times of the year. Your marketing operations manager needs a plan of action of \n<span style=\"text-decoration: underline;\"><a href=\"https://coschedule.com/marketing-strategy/marketing-budget/\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener noreferrer\">how to set those budgets</a></span> — and, more importantly, make sure you’re not overspending. \n<h3>2. Lead Management</h3> Marketing teams shouldn’t work in silos. It’s your marketing operation manager’s job to make sure that the leads you’re driving from marketing are converting into sales-qualified leads. It’s harder than you might think; just \n<span style=\"text-decoration: underline;\"><a href=\"https://www.geckoboard.com/learn/kpi-examples/sales-kpis/mql-to-sql-conversion-rate/#:~:targetText=Implisit%20analyzed%20the%20pipelines%20of,source%20of%20the%20lead%20was.\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener noreferrer\">13% of MQLs</a></span> convert to SQLs. \n<img class=\"alignnone wp-image-84275 size-full\" src=\"https://media.coschedule.com/uploads/2020/07/mql-sql.png\" alt=\"13% of MQLs convert to SQLs.\" width=\"1360\" height=\"580\" /> Failing to convert your marketing leads could lead to your department wasting their time and budget. You’re attracting people who won’t buy — making your entire strategy pointless. However, a \n<span style=\"text-decoration: underline;\"><a href=\"https://coschedule.com/blog/lead-generation-process/\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener noreferrer\">lead management process</a></span>&nbsp;constantly evaluates this conversion rate. It also allows marketing teams to collaborate with sales to identify your top customers, so you can rejig your strategy to attract them. That’ll work wonders on your marketing ROI. \n<h3>3. Reporting and Analytics</h3> Reporting has gained a reputation for being boring, but while your creative team might not want to digest data, you won’t know whether your strategy is working without them. A marketing operations manager needs a process for creating these reports, which includes: \n<ul> \n <li>Who creates the reports?</li> \n <li>How often?</li> \n <li>What should they report on?</li> \n <li>Who needs to read them?</li> \n <li>How are they made?</li> \n</ul> The good news? This process doesn’t have to be complex. Simply write up the answers to those points in a shared document and explain it to your team. Tell them to follow that process when they create a new marketing report. \n<h3>4. Asset management</h3> Every marketing team has assets. This usually includes content (i.e. blog posts, videos, and podcasts). [Tweet \"Every marketing team has assets. This usually includes content (i.e. blog posts, videos, and podcasts).\"] A marketing operations manager needs to control everything related to these assets, including their: \n<ul> \n <li><span style=\"text-decoration: underline;\"><a href=\"https://coschedule.com/blog/content-creation-process/\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener noreferrer\">Creation</a></span></li> \n <li>Licensing</li> \n <li>Usage</li> \n</ul> Without a process for this, your assets will be all over the place. It might lead to serious problems, like using a non-licensed image, then getting into trouble because you’ve used it without permission. That can be avoided with a marketing operations process that makes sure images are licensed before they’re passed onto marketing teams. Bonus: CoSchedule's&nbsp;\n<span style=\"text-decoration: underline;\"><a href=\"https://coschedule.com/asset-organizer\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener noreferrer\">Asset Organizer</a></span> is the ideal tool for this. You can store all of your assets in one place and organize them by usage — like conference slides, social media images, or business cards. \n<h3>5. Data Management</h3> It’s no secret that we have more data than ever before; 90% of the world’s data was created within \n<span style=\"text-decoration: underline;\"><a href=\"https://www.mediapost.com/publications/article/291358/90-of-todays-data-created-in-two-years.html\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener noreferrer\">two years</a></span>. With so much data available, it can quickly become overwhelming. Every dashboard has a set of metrics, and each new tool introduces you to a bunch of new metrics. That’s why your marketing operations team needs a process that defines: \n<ul> \n <li>How you’ll collect data.</li> \n <li>What you’ll collect.</li> \n <li>How you’ll use it.</li> \n</ul> A marketing operations team also needs to include how they’ll clean data — especially when cleaning up old, outdated, or inaccurate data can help you generate up to \n<span style=\"text-decoration: underline;\"><a href=\"https://www.slideshare.net/RingLead/the-cost-of-bad-and-clean-data\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener noreferrer\">70% more revenue</a></span>. Remember, if you’re collecting your customer's data, you’ll need to tell them all of the above, too — usually through a disclaimer or privacy policy. Work with your \n<span style=\"text-decoration: underline;\"><a href=\"https://digitalguardian.com/blog/what-data-protection-officer-dpo-learn-about-new-role-required-gdpr-compliance\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener noreferrer\">Data Protection Officer</a></span> on this. \n<div class=\"link-callout\">\n <strong>Recommended Reading:</strong> \n <a href=\"https://coschedule.com/blog/marketing-request-forms-template/\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener noreferrer\">Marketing Request Forms: How to Create One Your Team Will Actually Use</a>\n</div> \n<div class=\"link-callout\">\n <strong><a href=\"https://coschedule.com/?p=77388#toc\">Back to the Top</a></strong>\n</div> \n<a name=\"implement\"></a> \n<h2>How to Implement a Marketing Operations Process</h2> Creating a marketing operations process sounds easier than it looks. You’ll need to think about how your team are involved, the frequency of each process, and the tools you’ll need to make them happen. \n<div class=\"link-callout\">\n <strong>Recommended Reading:</strong>\n <a href=\"https://coschedule.com/blog/marketing-operations-strategy/\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener noreferrer\"> The Best Marketing Operations Strategy to Help Overloaded Marketing Managers</a>\n</div> The best news? There is a simple process you can use to get started. \n<h3>1. Use a Team Management Dashboard</h3> Earlier, we discussed how a marketing operations manager will define tasks for their team. You don’t have to remember who is responsible for each, individual part of the process you’re creating, though. A team management dashboard allows your entire department to see who is responsible for what and check that tasks in the workflow are being completed. Let’s put that into practice using the asset management process. The following team members have different responsibilities: \n<ol> \n <li>Ellie takes photographs.</li> \n <li>Lucy will get them copyrighted.</li> \n <li>Matt will plan to use them in <span style=\"text-decoration: underline;\"><a href=\"https://coschedule.com/blog/social-media-content/\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener noreferrer\">social media content</a></span>.</li> \n <li>Jason will proof and publish them.</li> \n</ol> To find your team management dashboard inside CoSchedule, click the \n<strong>Team</strong> option from your dropdown menu. You’ll see a complete view of the jobs your team are working on each day, along with how many \"Unscheduled,\" \"Past Due,\" and \"Completed\" tasks are on their schedule. \n<img class=\"drop-shadow aligncenter\" src=\"https://media.coschedule.com/uploads/e7f467be-e7c6-4488-9781-5c0605e4d469_Screen20Shot202018-11-2320at202.14.4220PM.png\" alt=\"team management dashboard\" width=\"1098\" height=\"658\" /> A team management dashboard stops things from getting missed throughout the process. Each team member also knows what they need to do and when — helping with accountability. \n<h3>2. Create Templates For Each Task</h3> Think of how long you spend creating the same tasks. It’s a tedious job, right? Remember, a marketing operations manager needs to find smart ways to cut time and improve productivity — not just for their staff, but themselves, too! [Tweet \"A marketing operations manager needs to find smart ways to cut time and improve productivity — not just for their staff, but themselves, too!\"] You can do that by creating templates for each task in your process. If you’re using CoSchedule, create a new project to use as your template. Add the tasks that need to be completed to tick-off that entire project, and click \n<strong>Assign</strong> to give a team member control over that task. \n<img class=\"drop-shadow aligncenter\" src=\"https://media.coschedule.com/uploads/37b35054-879c-4d97-b25e-ad30a55d6922_Screenshot202020-01-1920at2014.53.09.png\" alt=\"assign tasks in coschedule\" width=\"1600\" height=\"624\" /> Simply duplicate this project when it’s time to run through the process again. Your entire department can see who is responsible for each step, and you’ll get a notification when each task is completed — which stops important things from getting missed. \n<div class=\"link-callout\">\n <strong>Recommended Reading:</strong> \n <a href=\"https://coschedule.com/blog/marketing-tasks-checklist-template/\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener noreferrer\">The Best Way to Plan and Organize Marketing Tasks With Checklists</a>\n</div> \n<h3>3. Monitor Team Performance Reports</h3> We’ve already mentioned that a marketing operations manager's goal is to improve efficiency in their team. It’s their job to make sure they spend time on high-growth tasks and maximize your overall marketing ROI. How can you know whether or not you’re doing that? The simple answer: \n<span style=\"text-decoration: underline;\"><a href=\"https://coschedule.com/blog/team-performance-reports-demo/\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener noreferrer\">Performance reports</a>,</span>&nbsp;which break down your team’s activities. They’ll show you answers to questions such as: \n<ul> \n <li>Are they meeting deadlines?</li> \n <li>How much time are they spending on each task?</li> \n <li>Is there a tool you can use to cut time/improve performance?</li> \n</ul> Find the answers for your team by heading to your CoSchedule dashboard and clicking \n<strong>Analytics</strong>. From there, select the \n<strong>Team Performance</strong> report option: \n<img class=\"drop-shadow aligncenter\" src=\"https://media.coschedule.com/uploads/29d95a08-3830-4965-933f-1f06c79bc898_pasted20image200.png\" alt=\"coschedule's team performance report\" width=\"1082\" height=\"821\" /> There are a bunch of interesting metrics in here, such as your average task completion rate, the percentage of tasks completed on time, and the number of tasks overdue. Scroll a little further, and you’ll see the same metrics broken down by marketing team member. \n<img class=\"drop-shadow aligncenter\" src=\"https://media.coschedule.com/uploads/811d8b2f-f379-446d-b28a-7f67cb526046_Screenshot202020-01-2220at2014.24.24.png\" alt=\"coschedule's team member performance report\" width=\"1600\" height=\"982\" /> Using the performance dashboard, you see that your social media team are spending three hours each week copying and pasting evergreen content that’s performed in the past. As a result, those tasks are often completed past their original due date. Instead of allowing them to waste time doing this task manually, why not use CoSchedule to \n<span style=\"text-decoration: underline;\"><a href=\"https://coschedule.com/blog/social-media-automation/\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener noreferrer\">automate their social posting</a></span>? The ReQueue feature allows you to share old content with one click — no faffing around or digging through your feed to find content to repost. That could give them an extra two hours every week to use elsewhere. \n<h3>4. Choose Tools That Integrate Well Together</h3> You don’t need to search for tools that wipe out complete tasks that your team does. Some tasks, like private messages with potential leads, need a human touch. That’s not to say you can’t use technology to cut down the time they spend writing them or do a better job at it. Take email subscriptions, for example. We all want more high-quality leads on our list, right? People who fit that bill might be those already engaging with your SMS marketing campaigns. Send a message asking whether they’d like to sign-up to your list, using an automation to get them added. There’s no waiting for your customer, nor extra admin work for your team. They’re on your email list within a matter of seconds. If you’re using CoSchedule to manage your marketing strategy, you have access to hundreds of similar automations for each channel, including: \n<ul> \n <li>WordPress</li> \n <li>Social media</li> \n <li>Email service providers (e.g. MailChimp, Constant Contact, Active Campaign, and Campaign Monitor)</li> \n</ul> [Tweet \"If you’re using CoSchedule to manage your marketing strategy, you have access to hundreds of similar automations for each channel.\"] Some \n<span style=\"text-decoration: underline;\"><a href=\"https://www.emailmonday.com/marketing-automation-statistics-overview/\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener noreferrer\">63% of marketers</a></span> say they saw the benefits of using marketing automation within the first six months. It’s one of the easiest ways for a marketing operations manager to start maximizing their team’s time and focus on high-growth marketing tactics. \n<img class=\"alignnone wp-image-84277 size-full\" src=\"https://media.coschedule.com/uploads/2020/07/marketing-automation.png\" alt=\"63% of marketers seeing the benefits of marketing operations.\" width=\"1360\" height=\"580\" /> \n<div class=\"link-callout\">\n <strong><a href=\"https://coschedule.com/?p=77388#toc\">Back to the Top</a></strong>\n</div> \n<a name=\"processes\"></a> \n<h2>Operationalizing Your Marketing Processes</h2> Efficient and effective processes are one of the key components of marketing operations. A successful marketing team doesn’t just set it and forget it, they are constantly improving and tailoring best practices. \n<div class=\"link-callout\">\n <strong>Recommended Reading:</strong>\n <a href=\"https://coschedule.com/blog/marketing-project-management-skills/\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener noreferrer\"> 8 Marketing Project Management Skills You Need to Lead a Successful Team</a>\n</div> Start by planning and documenting your workflows. Documenting your workflows means that everyone knows the correct order of operations, when tasks are due, and where their contributions fit into the project’s timeline. They are essential for completing work on time, every time. A documented workflow also means that you can spend more time doing meaningful work and less time following-up with every person at every stage of a marketing project. Here’s how to do it: \n<ul> \n <li><strong>Step 1:</strong>&nbsp;Determine each team member’s role for each type of project you execute regularly.</li> \n <li><strong>Step 2:</strong>&nbsp;Map out each task that needs to be completed.</li> \n <li><strong>Step 3:</strong>&nbsp;Next, assign the task and determine the length of time needed to complete each task.</li> \n <li><strong>Step 4:</strong> Work back from there to determine the necessary project length and attach task due dates for each step in the workflow.</li> \n</ul> For example, here’s what this might look like for a webinar: \n<ul> \n <li><strong>Generate ideas:</strong> Strategist – due 30 days before launch</li> \n <li><strong>Recruit guest:</strong> Strategist – Due 25 days before launch</li> \n <li><strong>Create talking points:</strong> Strategist – Due 18 days before launch</li> \n <li><strong>Design slide deck:</strong> Designer – Due 17 days before launch</li> \n <li><strong>Include in drip campaign:</strong> Marketing Automation – Due 14 days before launch</li> \n <li><strong>Approve slide deck:</strong> Strategist – Due 12 days before launch</li> \n <li><strong>Schedule social promotion:</strong> Writer/Social Strategist – 10 days before launch</li> \n <li><strong>Test run-through:</strong> Guest and Host – 1 day before launch</li> \n</ul> Let’s illustrate how this can be done with CoSchedule. In the top right-hand corner of your project, click the task template icon. Then, create a new task template. Name your workflow and add each task associated with the project. Next, you can add a due date for each task and assign it to the relevant team member. Now, your webinar workflow is documented and ready to be attached to every webinar project from here on out. \n<div class=\"link-callout\">\n <strong><a href=\"https://coschedule.com/?p=77388#toc\">Back to the Top</a></strong>\n</div> \n<a name=\"agile\"></a> \n<h2>Consider Implementing an Agile Approach</h2> Agile refers to a flexible marketing approach in which teams identify high-value projects, break those project down into smaller deliverables, measure their impact, and then iterate on the results to incrementally improve. \n<a href=\"https://coschedule.com/agile-marketing-guide/\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener noreferrer\">Agile Marketing</a> provides marketing teams a set process for running most marketing campaigns. Here is a very high-level explanation of how to get started applying this methodology with your team: \n<h3>Step 1: Define the Project</h3> Before you get started, make sure that the project is a good fit for an Agile approach. Agile is best fit for big projects that can easily be divided up into smaller pieces. Think website redesigns and large marketing campaigns. \n<h3>Step 2: Sprint Planning Meeting</h3> Next, schedule the sprint planning meeting. Everyone who will be working on the project will attend this meeting. Discuss each task and deliverable for the project. \n<h3>Step 3: Task Breakdown</h3> Each task within the project needs to be broken down. This should be fairly granular. For example, writing, proofing, and approving the blog post could be separate tasks. At this time, the head of the project (most likely the marketing manager) will ask info regarding how much time each task will take to accomplish. These tasks could be visualized using a Kanban board. \n<img class=\"alignnone wp-image-84278 size-full\" src=\"https://media.coschedule.com/uploads/2020/07/kanban-board-example-1.png\" alt=\"Visual representation of what the Kanban board looks like.\" width=\"1361\" height=\"777\" /> \n<h3>Step 4: Daily Scrums</h3> Once you have all your tasks planned, teams start working on their tasks. To keep track of your project, you will begin having daily check-in meetings. These are extremely short and should only take 5-10 minutes. \n<img class=\"alignnone wp-image-84279\" src=\"https://media.coschedule.com/uploads/2020/07/daily-standup.png\" alt=\"Definition of daily standups.\" width=\"1360\" height=\"1395\" /> Each team member will answer three questions: \n<ul> \n <li>What did you do yesterday?</li> \n <li>What will you do today?</li> \n <li>Any roadblocks?</li> \n</ul> \n<div class=\"link-callout\">\n <strong><a href=\"https://coschedule.com/?p=77388#toc\">Back to the Top</a></strong>\n</div> \n<a name=\"conclusion\"></a> \n<h2>Ready to Get Started?</h2> Marketing operations is a key part of any company. Without it, you’ll spend time on the wrong things — focusing on low-growth activities that waste everyone’s time. The simplest way to get started is to list the processes your team follows. Then, create a marketing operations process for each task using the guide above. You’ll soon start to see how much work you get done when one-off tasks and confusion are gone! \n<div class=\"link-callout\">\n <strong>Recommended Reading:</strong> \n <a href=\"https://coschedule.com/blog/marketing-request-forms-template/\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener noreferrer\">Marketing Request Forms: How to Create One Your Team Will Actually Use</a>\n</div> \n<em>This post was originally published on Feb. 19, 2020. It was updated and republished on July 9, 2020. Leah Dekrey contributed writing to this post.</em>\n<p>The post <a rel=\"nofollow\" href=\"https://coschedule.com/blog/marketing-operations/\">Marketing Operations: The Start to Finish Guide for Busy Managers</a> appeared first on <a rel=\"nofollow\" href=\"https://coschedule.com\">CoSchedule Blog</a>.</p>","descriptionType":"html","publishedDate":"Thu, 09 Jul 2020 13:40:51
