Disjointed marketing content and constantly jumping from screen to screen is the worst. With Email Marketing from CoSchedule, all your email campaigns live on your single marketing calendar&nbsp;— giving you ultimate visibility into your marketing strategy and individual initiatives.</li> \n</ul> \n<a href=\"https://coschedule.com/signup\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener noreferrer\">Start your free trial now</a>. \n<h2>Create Your Own Email Marketing Strategy in 11 Steps</h2> Creating an email marketing strategy doesn’t have to be complicated. The following eleven steps will help you plan your work and work your plan in no time. \n<div class=\"link-callout\"> \n <a name=\"toc\"></a>\n <strong>Table of Contents:</strong> \n <ol> \n  <li><a href=\"https://coschedule.com/blog/?p=54247#tools\">Choose Your Email Marketing Tools</a></li> \n  <li><a href=\"https://coschedule.com/blog/?p=54247#audience\">Identify Your Target Audience</a></li> \n  <li><a href=\"https://coschedule.com/blog/?p=54247#tactics\">Choose List-Building Tactics</a></li> \n  <li><a href=\"https://coschedule.com/blog/?p=54247#segments\">Create Your Email List Segments</a></li> \n  <li><a href=\"https://coschedule.com/blog/?p=54247#schedule\">Create Email Sending Schedule</a></li> \n  <li><a href=\"https://coschedule.com/blog/?p=54247#goals\">Define Your Email Marketing Goals</a></li> \n  <li><a href=\"https://coschedule.com/blog/?p=54247#types\">Decide Which Types of Emails to Send</a></li> \n  <li><a href=\"https://coschedule.com/blog/?p=54247#format\">Formatting Your Email Content</a></li> \n  <li><a href=\"https://coschedule.com/blog/?p=54247#optimize\">How To Optimize Your Emails</a></li> \n  <li><a href=\"https://coschedule.com/blog/?p=54247#tests\">What A/B Tests Will You Run</a></li> \n  <li><a href=\"https://coschedule.com/blog/?p=54247#reporting\">Reporting</a></li> \n </ol> \n</div> \n<a name=\"tools\"></a> \n<h2>Step One: Choose Your Tools</h2> Finding the right tools is the first step in your strategy. A lot of these platforms are super powerful and can help you organize and send your emails at the drop of a hat. \n<h3>Email Marketing Tools</h3> Some common email marketing tools that you might consider using are: \n<ul> \n <li><span style=\"text-decoration: underline; font-weight: bold;\"><a href=\"https://mailchimp.com/\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener noreferrer\">MailChimp</a></span></li> \n <li><strong><a href=\"https://www.campaignmonitor.com/\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener noreferrer\">Campaign Monitor</a></strong></li> \n <li><strong><a href=\"https://www.constantcontact.com/index.jsp\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener noreferrer\">Constant Contact</a></strong></li> \n <li><strong><a href=\"https://www.activecampaign.com/\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener noreferrer\">ActiveCampaign</a></strong></li> \n</ul> This is a short list in a sea of other email tools you could use. Find the tool that fits your team based on what you want to accomplish with your email marketing. \n<div class=\"link-callout\">\n <strong>Recommended Reading: </strong>\n <a href=\"https://coschedule.com/blog/free-email-marketing-software-tools/\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener noreferrer\">The Best Free Email Marketing Software Tools You Should Use</a>\n</div> \n<h3>Marketing Automation Tools</h3> You might not want to stop at a simple email marketing tool. You may also consider adding a marketing automation tool to your list. Marketing automation makes it easy for you to follow up with customers and send subscribers the right email at the right time based on how they are interacting with your website. Some email marketing platforms have basic marketing automation features built-in&nbsp;— like the option to send birthday email messages automatically. It's worth taking some time to figure out the depths of marketing automation you need and your bandwidth for maintaining automation initiatives. These activities can take a big chunk of time to manage. Potential automation tools to add to your list are: \n<ul> \n <li><span style=\"text-decoration: underline; font-weight: bold;\"><a href=\"https://autopilothq.com/?gclid=EAIaIQobChMIiKT6-8H32QIV17bACh0sIgx-EAAYASAAEgJwNPD_BwE\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener noreferrer\">Autopilot:</a></span>&nbsp;Autopilot makes it easy to plan journeys and triggers that send your subscribers emails based on how they interact with your website.</li> \n <li><span style=\"text-decoration: underline; font-weight: bold;\"><a href=\"https://www.adroll.com/\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener noreferrer\">Userfox:</a></span>&nbsp;Userfox is a small, email-focused automation tool that sends emails to subscribers based on events that you put into the system. Userfox was bought by the Adroll Group in 2014.</li> \n <li><span style=\"text-decoration: underline; font-weight: bold;\"><a href=\"https://www.hubspot.com/\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener noreferrer\">HubSpot:</a></span>&nbsp;Hubspot doesn’t have as much email automation functionality as the other two on this list, but it is suited for companies who want to control multiple aspects from one tool.</li> \n <li><strong><a href=\"http://www.marketo.com\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener noreferrer\">Marketo:</a></strong>&nbsp;A powerful marketing automation tool that is most suitable for enterprise-level marketers.</li> \n <li><strong><a href=\"https://www.pardot.com\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener noreferrer\">Pardot</a></strong>: A full solution that helps marketers create meaningful connections, generate more pipeline, and empower sales to close more deals. This marketing automation option fits well if you use Salesforce as your CRM.</li> \n</ul> Once you have your tools, add them to the first slide in your email marketing strategy template: \n<img class=\"drop-shadow alignnone wp-image-83739 size-full\" src=\"https://media.coschedule.com/uploads/2020/06/tool-selection-1.png\" alt=\"Tool selection slide from template\" width=\"1361\" height=\"769\" /> \n<div class=\"link-callout\"> \n <strong>Action Items:</strong> \n <ol> \n  <li>Research email marketing tools.</li> \n  <li>Compare which ones will work best for your marketing team.</li> \n  <li>Add them to your strategy template.</li> \n </ol> \n</div> \n<a href=\"https://coschedule.com/blog/?p=54247#toc\">Back to the Top</a> \n<a name=\"audience\"></a> \n<h2>Step Two: Identify Your Target Audience</h2> Once you have your tools selected, you to need to focus on building your email subscriber list. The first step to build your email list is to identify your target audience. \n<span style=\"text-decoration: underline;\"><a href=\"https://coschedule.com/marketing-strategy/marketing-persona\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener noreferrer\">As a refresher</a></span>:&nbsp;\n<span style=\"font-family: -apple-system, BlinkMacSystemFont, 'Segoe UI', Roboto, Oxygen-Sans, Ubuntu, Cantarell, 'Helvetica Neue', sans-serif;\">Your target audience is the ideal customer you want to attract to your product or service through your marketing efforts.</span> How can you find your target audience? \n<strong>Recommended Reading:</strong> \n<a href=\"https://coschedule.com/marketing-strategy/marketing-persona\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener noreferrer\">How To Find Your Target Audience With A Marketing Persona</a> First, answer the following questions: \n<ul> \n <li>Who are our current best customers?</li> \n <li>What qualities do they have in common?</li> \n <li>What problem are they experiencing that has our customers search for a solution, like our product or service?</li> \n <li>Why did they purchase our product or service?</li> \n <li>What did we provide for our customers that our competition didn’t?</li> \n</ul> [Tweet \"Is your email marketing strategy focused on your target audience?\"] Using those answers, format your target audience statement with the following template: \n<blockquote>\n {Insert your company} creates content to attract {insert target audience} so they can {insert desired outcome} better.\n</blockquote> Record your target audience demographics and statement in your template. \n<img class=\"drop-shadow alignnone wp-image-83756 size-full\" src=\"https://media.coschedule.com/uploads/2020/06/target-demographic-1.png\" alt=\"What is our target demographic?\" width=\"1361\" height=\"768\" /> \n<a href=\"https://coschedule.com/blog/?p=54247#toc\">Back to the Top</a> \n<a name=\"tactics\"></a> \n<h2>Step Three: Create Tactics to Get Your Audience to Opt Into Your Email List</h2> Now that you know who your target audience is, you can begin to brainstorm tactics that will attract them and convince them to sign up and join your email list. Here are just a few ideas to get you started. \n<h3>Give Them Something Valuable in Return</h3> One of the most common ways to get your audience to join your email subscriber list is to gate content upgrades behind an opt-in form. What is valuable to your customers? A downloadable template or ebook that shows them how to solve a problem or answer a question they might be having. If you gate something that doesn’t provide value, you might end up losing that subscriber. \n<img class=\"aligncenter wp-image-55239 size-full\" src=\"https://coschedule.com/blog/wp-content/uploads/opt-in-form-example.png\" alt=\"Example of an opt-in form.\" width=\"770\" height=\"642\" /> \n<h3>Go For the Direct Ask</h3> Another way to gain subscribers is to go for the direct ask. Explain to them why they should opt into your email list and entice them with personalized information, like this pop-up from \n<span style=\"text-decoration: underline;\"><a href=\"https://www.fargo3dprinting.com/\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener noreferrer\">Fargo 3D Printing</a></span>. Gathering information like this will also help you segment your list. \n<img class=\"aligncenter wp-image-55240 \" src=\"https://coschedule.com/blog/wp-content/uploads/example-opt-in-form-2.png\" alt=\"Second example of an opt-in form\" width=\"518\" height=\"579\" /> Here's another pop-up example from \n<a href=\"https://www.nanit.com/products/nanit-plus?gclid=EAIaIQobChMI-eLUmuvl6QIVEPDACh1LVg1GEAAYASAAEgL_6PD_BwE\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener noreferrer\">Nanit</a>, encouraging visitors to sign up for their newsletter. The company asks for the ages of the visitor's children, which would indicate the company does some segmenting based on developmental stages of the child's age. \n<img class=\"drop-shadow aligncenter wp-image-70161\" src=\"https://media.coschedule.com/uploads/Screenshot-2019-05-20-15.06.44.png\" alt=\"Email subscription prompt form nanit\" width=\"534\" height=\"307\" /> \n<h3>Use the Header and Footer of Your Website</h3> Another place you can put an email opt-in button is on your website’s header and footer. \n<strong>Recommended Reading:&nbsp;</strong>\n<a href=\"https://coschedule.com/blog/inbound-marketing-strategy-process-templates/\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener noreferrer\">Conquer Your Inbound Marketing Strategy with this Process (+ 4 Templates)</a> Why not meet your audience halfway and make it easy to remind them that they can get more information about your products by joining your email list? Take a look at \n<span style=\"text-decoration: underline;\"><a href=\"https://www.ulta.com/\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener noreferrer\">this example from Ulta</a></span>: \n<img class=\"aligncenter wp-image-55241 size-full\" src=\"https://coschedule.com/blog/wp-content/uploads/ulta-opt-in-form-example.png\" alt=\"Opt in form example from Ulta\" width=\"770\" height=\"466\" /> &nbsp; Here's another example from \n<a href=\"https://michaelhyatt.com/\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener noreferrer\">Michael Hyatt</a>: \n<img class=\"drop-shadow aligncenter wp-image-67434 size-full\" src=\"https://media.coschedule.com/uploads/Screenshot-2019-02-11-14.21.58.png\" alt=\"Website homepage from michaelhyatt.com\" width=\"645\" height=\"343\" /> &nbsp; And another from \n<a href=\"https://us.boohoo.com/\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener noreferrer\">British Clothing Company, Boohoo</a>: \n<img class=\"drop-shadow aligncenter wp-image-67711 size-full\" src=\"https://media.coschedule.com/uploads/Screenshot-2019-02-25-14.20.20.png\" alt=\"Opt-in from boohoo.com for email subscription\" width=\"777\" height=\"524\" /> \n<a href=\"https://coschedule.com/blog/?p=54247#toc\">Back to the Top</a> \n<a name=\"segmets\"></a> \n<h2>How to Segment Your Email List</h2> We mentioned earlier in this section that you can segment your email list. What does that mean and how can that help you? Here's a quick email segmentation definition: \n<blockquote>\n The process of grouping like individuals on an email list based on their behavior or characteristics to send specifically targeted emails that address that particular group of users' needs or problems.\n</blockquote> You can just blast out your emails to everyone on your list and hope that it resonates with someone and convince them to convert. However, today we can use data and information to go further and serve content to the right people, at the right time, to help guide them through your marketing funnel. In fact, segmenting your list can have a positive effect on your email list. \n<span style=\"text-decoration: underline;\"><a href=\"https://mailchimp.com/resources/research/effects-of-list-segmentation-on-email-marketing-stats/\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener noreferrer\">MailChimp conducted an internal study</a></span>&nbsp;and found that segmented campaigns had: \n<ul> \n <li>14.31% higher open rates</li> \n <li>100.95% more clicks</li> \n <li>9.37% lower unsubscribe rates than their non-segmented campaigns</li> \n</ul> \n<span style=\"text-decoration: underline;\"><a href=\"https://zapier.com/learn/email-marketing/email-list-segmentation-guide/\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener noreferrer\">You can segment your list</a></span>&nbsp;based on a variety of things, including: \n<ul> \n <li>Company size</li> \n <li>Location</li> \n <li>Activity on your website</li> \n <li>How long they’ve been on your email list</li> \n</ul> In order to accurately segment your list, you need to gather this data about your customers when they first sign up. Add options for subscribers to choose from before they complete their signup. List potential ways your team will try and grow your email list in your template and email list segments. \n<img class=\"drop-shadow alignnone wp-image-83741 size-full\" src=\"https://media.coschedule.com/uploads/2020/06/email-list-segments-1.png\" alt=\"Email list segments table\" width=\"1361\" height=\"768\" /> \n<div class=\"link-callout\"> \n <strong>Action Items:</strong> \n <ol> \n  <li>Brainstorm email list growth strategies.</li> \n  <li>Record strategies in your template.</li> \n  <li>Update strategies every three months — based on what’s working well and what isn’t.</li> \n  <li>List out what criteria you will use to segment your list.</li> \n </ol> \n</div> \n<h2>Step Four: Choose the Types of Emails to Send</h2> There are many different types of emails you can send to your list. You can choose one, or change it up, based on the various segments you have in your list. Here are three different types of emails to get started with. \n<h3>Newsletters</h3> Newsletters are a popular email format. They come to your subscriber’s inbox at the same time at recurring intervals. They allow you to show them a variety of content and information your subscribers might have missed if they haven’t visited your website lately. \n<span style=\"text-decoration: underline;\"><a href=\"https://blog.hubspot.com/marketing/guide-creating-email-newsletters-ht\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener noreferrer\">According to Hubspot,</a></span>&nbsp;successful email newsletters contain 90% educational content and 10% product or promotional content. The same post from Hubspot says newsletters should contain a single theme or idea. That way you can prevent yourself from randomly throwing content into your newsletter just to get it out there. You might even send out different newsletters on different topics based on who you’re sending each newsletter to on your list. What does an excellent newsletter look like? Take this example from \n<a href=\"https://www.theskimm.com/?utm_source=google&amp;utm_medium=paidmedia&amp;utm_campaign=DS_SEM_ADW_SNT_BRAND_Core_Exact&amp;gclid=EAIaIQobChMI-dnL-eTl6QIVAb7ACh2CPQz0EAAYASAAEgJxVPD_BwE\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener noreferrer\">The Skimm</a>: \n<img class=\"aligncenter wp-image-55243 size-full\" src=\"https://media.coschedule.com/uploads/email-newsletter-example.png\" alt=\"Example of an email newsletter from the Skimm\" width=\"770\" height=\"1696\" /> \n<span style=\"text-decoration: underline;\"><a href=\"https://blog.hubspot.com/marketing/email-newsletter-examples-list\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener noreferrer\">Photo from Hubspot</a></span> \n<span style=\"text-decoration: underline;\"><a href=\"https://www.theskimm.com/\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener noreferrer\">The Skimm newsletter</a></span>&nbsp;is specific in the fact that it rounds up the latest news from the day before and quickly summarizes it for readers. It provides the benefit of not having to read long news stories and allows subscribers to quickly catch up on the news from the day before. [Tweet \"Round up your most recent content into an informative email newsletter.\"] Here's another awesome newsletter round-up from \n<a href=\"https://www.spotify.com/us/\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener noreferrer\">Spotify</a>: \n<img class=\"drop-shadow alignnone wp-image-83560 size-full\" src=\"https://media.coschedule.com/uploads/2020/06/Spotify-min_2019.png\" alt=\"\" width=\"600\" height=\"2681\" /> &nbsp; \n<a href=\"https://www.airbnb.com/\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener noreferrer\">Airbnb</a> also has a great newsletter that mixes both content and promotional elements. \n<img class=\"drop-shadow aligncenter wp-image-67438 size-full\" src=\"https://media.coschedule.com/uploads/airbnb.png\" alt=\"Another email newsletter from airbnb\" width=\"508\" height=\"961\" /> \n<h3>Automated Drip Emails</h3> Automated drip campaigns are emails that are sent to users based on their interactions with your website, or content that is sent on a schedule, to help move customers down your marketing funnel. Once your subscriber takes action, emails are slowly dripped into their email inbox to help convince them to convert. These emails change based on the action that your list members take. For example, say you had a subscriber who clicked on your product page, added things to their cart, but didn’t make a purchase. The automated emails could be sent to your subscriber that gently remind them to head back to their cart or learn more about their products. Take a look at this example from \n<span style=\"text-decoration: underline;\"><a href=\"https://www.doggyloot.com/\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener noreferrer\">DoggyLoot</a></span>:\n<a href=\"https://www.shopify.com/blog/12522201-13-amazing-abandoned-cart-emails-and-what-you-can-learn-from-them\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener noreferrer\"><img class=\"aligncenter wp-image-55244 size-full\" src=\"https://media.coschedule.com/uploads/doggy-loot-email.png\" alt=\"Email from Doggy Loot for promotions and shopping cart reminders\" width=\"770\" height=\"959\" /></a> This is a great example because of the sense of urgency the copy creates. If your customer doesn’t buy these items now, they might miss out on them altogether. \n<a href=\"https://www.asos.com/us/\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener noreferrer\">Asos</a> uses a similar tactic — encouraging people not to forget about the items in their abandoned cart. \n<img class=\"drop-shadow aligncenter wp-image-67439 size-full\" src=\"https://media.coschedule.com/uploads/asos-abandoned-cart-email.png\" alt=\"Email from asos about items left in your cart\" width=\"619\" height=\"928\" /> This video shows how to create a drip campaign in \n<a href=\"https://youtu.be/gHUoUnmUqlg\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener noreferrer\">MailChimp</a>. \n<h3>Seasonal and Promotional Emails</h3> We all know the holiday emails that end up in our inboxes each year. They contain all those great deals, so you can get your shopping done and out of the way. Seasonal and promotional emails are timed emails that help entice your readers to purchase from your website. Here’s a typical example of a holiday promotional email: &nbsp; &nbsp; \n<a href=\"https://blogs.constantcontact.com/holiday-email-examples/\"><img class=\"wp-image-55245 size-full aligncenter\" src=\"https://coschedule.com/blog/wp-content/uploads/seasonal-email-example.png\" alt=\"Example of a seasonal email\" width=\"770\" height=\"1122\" /></a> Each email may vary and contain different, timely information that you want to get to your audience. Here's another promo email example from \n<a href=\"https://www.westelm.com/?Kenshoo=_k_EAIaIQobChMIiI243-nl6QIVhobACh241g9bEAAYASAAEgK-aPD_BwE_k_&amp;cm_ven=BrandSearch&amp;cm_cat=Google&amp;cm_pla=Brand_Search_Exact&amp;cm_ite=west%20elm&amp;gclid=EAIaIQobChMIiI243-nl6QIVhobACh241g9bEAAYASAAEgK-aPD_BwE\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener noreferrer\">West Elm</a>. \n<img class=\"drop-shadow aligncenter wp-image-67440 size-full\" src=\"https://media.coschedule.com/uploads/Screenshot-2019-02-11-14.52.35.png\" alt=\"Promotion from west elm about markdowns for the next few hours\" width=\"615\" height=\"818\" /> Here's another promo email example from \n<a href=\"https://ngmdomsubs.nationalgeographic.com/pubs/NG/NGM/ngm_direct_COM_232353.jsp?cds_page_id=232353&amp;cds_mag_code=NGM&amp;id=1591193622798&amp;lsid=31550912356045256&amp;vid=2&amp;gclsrc=aw.ds&amp;cds_response_key=I0BSR1MA0&amp;gclid=EAIaIQobChMIvZfMkerl6QIV0MDACh3BZwiiEAAYASAAEgLIcPD_BwE&amp;cmpid=org%3Dngp%3A%3Amc%3Dcpc%3A%3Asrc%3Dgoogle%3A%3Acmp%3Dbrand-us-google-national-geographic-keyword-only-exact%3A%3Aadd%3Dnational-geographic&amp;ds_rl=1265457\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener noreferrer\">National Geographic</a> that helps promote its Black Friday Sale. \n<img class=\"drop-shadow aligncenter wp-image-70171 size-full\" src=\"https://media.coschedule.com/uploads/Screenshot-2019-05-21-14.47.02.png\" alt=\"Black Friday promotion from National Geographic website for saving 70%\" width=\"390\" height=\"572\" /> In the strategy template, choose which types of emails you want to send to your email list and record it in your template. \n<img class=\"drop-shadow alignnone wp-image-83742 size-full\" src=\"https://media.coschedule.com/uploads/2020/06/email-content-type-1.png\" alt=\"Screenshot of the slide for email content type\" width=\"1361\" height=\"761\" /> \n<div class=\"link-callout\">\n <strong>Action Item:&nbsp;</strong>Decide which types of emails you want to send to your list. These could be broken down by your email list segments.\n</div> \n<a href=\"https://coschedule.com/blog/?p=54247#toc\">Back to the Top</a> \n<a name=\"schedule\"></a> \n<h2>Step Five: Determine How Often to Send Your Emails</h2> You've sent some emails and your subscriber list is growing, but your audience gets a lot of emails over the course of one day. How can you ensure that your emails are being seen? Well, sending them during the most strategic days and times can help. \n<span style=\"text-decoration: underline;\"><a href=\"https://coschedule.com/blog/best-time-to-send-email/\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener noreferrer\">According to ten different studies</a>,</span>&nbsp;the best times to send emails are: \n<img class=\"alignnone wp-image-83743 size-full\" src=\"https://media.coschedule.com/uploads/2020/06/email-time.png\" alt=\"The best time to send an email\" width=\"1361\" height=\"1182\" /> Your best times will vary a bit depending on your subscribers, so experiment to see what times your audience is the most engaged. You can’t just send your email at the best time; you also need to send it on the best day. \n<span style=\"text-decoration: underline;\"><a href=\"https://coschedule.com/blog/best-time-to-send-email/\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener noreferrer\">According to those same ten studies</a></span> the best days to send emails are: \n<img class=\"alignnone wp-image-83744 size-full\" src=\"https://media.coschedule.com/uploads/2020/06/email-day.png\" alt=\"The best day to send an email\" width=\"1361\" height=\"1182\" /> Does this mean that these are the best days for your list? Not necessarily. Each audience is unique and may require a little testing to find your best day to send email. To find your best times and days to send an email, try testing the following times: \n<img class=\"alignnone wp-image-83745 size-full\" src=\"https://media.coschedule.com/uploads/2020/06/test-email.png\" alt=\"Test your emails to find the best time for you\" width=\"1360\" height=\"868\" /> Remember, these are suggested times. Use the analytics in your email marketing platform to fine-tune&nbsp;your send times and understand what works best for your audience. Then record those winning times in your template. \n<img class=\"drop-shadow alignnone wp-image-83746 size-full\" src=\"https://media.coschedule.com/uploads/2020/06/sending-schedule.png\" alt=\"Email sending schedule slide\" width=\"1361\" height=\"779\" /> \n<div class=\"link-callout\"> \n <strong>Action Items:</strong> \n <ol> \n  <li>Experiment with the time you send your emails.</li> \n  <li>Track open rates, unsubscribes, click-throughs, and more for each email sent. This helps you understand how testing different things influences results over time.</li> \n  <li>From that data, determine when your audience is the most receptive to your emails and use those times as your best time to send an email.</li> \n </ol> \n</div> \n<a href=\"https://coschedule.com/blog/?p=54247#toc\">Back to the Top</a> \n<a name=\"goals\"></a> \n<h2>Step Six: Set Goals For Your Emails</h2> The next thing you need to do is set goals for your email marketing. Goal-setting is critical for your email marketing program because it gives each email you send a specific purpose. You need to know where you're heading before you can strategize a route to get there. Setting strategic goals helps you show your boss and other stakeholders in your organization that your email marketing strategy is having the right effect on your bottom line. How do you create a solid email marketing goal? By ensuring they’re S.M.A.R.T.: \n<img class=\"alignnone wp-image-83747 size-full\" src=\"https://media.coschedule.com/uploads/2020/06/smart-goals.png\" alt=\"What are SMART goals?\" width=\"1361\" height=\"542\" /> Each goal you create should be measurable, so you have a way to track your results, and specific to your campaign. Make sure that they're ambitious, but not so high they’re impossible to reach. Every goal should be relevant to the campaign in which it has been created. In other words, you don’t necessarily want to track the number of purchases an email drove if it isn’t directly selling something. For example, a promo email's goal could be total sales attributed to said email, while a simple newsletter could be CTR on an article included. Plus, each goal needs to be time-bound — meaning you should meet your goal within a set time limit. What kind of goals can you set for your email marketing program? \n<ul> \n <li><span style=\"font-weight: bold;\">Increasing click-through rates:</span> Click-through rates mean that your audience has read your email, and they have followed through to click the link to your website, which could increase your conversions.</li> \n <li><span style=\"font-weight: bold;\">Increasing your ROI:</span>&nbsp;<a href=\"https://www.campaignmonitor.com/blog/email-marketing/2016/01/70-email-marketing-stats-you-need-to-know/\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener noreferrer\"><span style=\"text-decoration: underline;\">For every dollar you spend</span></a> on email marketing, you see an average $44 return. You could set goals to help increase your average ROI.</li> \n <li><span style=\"font-weight: bold;\">Increasing your open rates:&nbsp;</span>An unopened email is about as effective as an unsent one. Trying to increase your open rates is a solid goal to set for your email marketing strategy.</li> \n <li><span style=\"font-weight: bold;\">Increasing the number of subscribers:&nbsp;</span>The more people you can reach with your emails, the better. Set a series of goals that help increase your total subscribers.</li> \n</ul> \n<div class=\"link-callout\">\n <strong>Recommended Reading:&nbsp;</strong>\n <a href=\"https://coschedule.com/marketing-strategy/marketing-goals\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener noreferrer\">How To Set SMART Marketing Goals</a>\n</div> Use the following template to create each one of your goals: \n<blockquote>\n By {insert day, month, year}, the {insert your organization’s name} marketing team will reach {insert number} {insert metric} every {insert time frame}.\n</blockquote> Enter those goals into your template: \n<img class=\"drop-shadow alignnone wp-image-83748 size-full\" src=\"https://media.coschedule.com/uploads/2020/06/annual-goals.png\" alt=\"Annual email marketing goals\" width=\"1361\" height=\"772\" /> \n<div class=\"link-callout\"> \n <strong>Action Items:</strong> \n <ol> \n  <li>For each campaign, set a series of S.M.A.R.T. goals that will help prove the success or failure of your campaign.</li> \n  <li>Track each goal and record results in your template.</li> \n  <li>Report back to your boss on progress.</li> \n </ol> \n</div> \n<a href=\"https://coschedule.com/blog/?p=54247#toc\">Back to the Top</a> \n<a name=\"format\"></a> \n<h2>Step Seven: Determine How You’re Going to Craft Your Content</h2> You have your email types selected, your goals are complete, and now you need to write email copy that encourages your reader to take action. The following categories will help ensure that your copywriters create content that makes your next email stand out. \n<h3>What Writing Style Does Your Team Use</h3> Emails can be written in all sorts of formats and styles. Depending on what type of email you’re creating, you could have larger blocks of text, or a list of links email readers can click on. Take CoSchedule, for example. We approach our email copy by writing single-sentence paragraphs: \n<img class=\"aligncenter wp-image-54584 size-full\" src=\"https://media.coschedule.com/uploads/SS-01-3.png\" alt=\"Example of how CoSchedule formats blog posts to be easily readable\" width=\"770\" height=\"737\" /> This format makes skimming plain-text email easy. \n<h3>Optimizing For Mobile Readers</h3> Another essential part of crafting your email content is to make sure that it is optimized for viewing across multiple devices. The fact is, \n<span style=\"text-decoration: underline;\"><a href=\"https://www.mediapost.com/publications/article/304735/majority-of-emails-read-on-mobile-devices.html\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener noreferrer\">55% of emails are read</a></span>&nbsp;on mobile devices, which means your copy should transfer easily. \n<span style=\"text-decoration: underline;\"><a href=\"https://www.copyblogger.com/mobile-friendly-emails/\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener noreferrer\">According to CopyBlogger</a></span>, there are ten ways you can ensure that your emails are mobile friendly. \n<ol> \n <li>Create short subject lines</li> \n <li>Use a single column template</li> \n <li>Keep your email under 600px wide</li> \n <li>Use a large font size — between 13 to 14 pixels is recommended</li> \n <li>Display small images</li> \n <li>Provide a distinct call to action</li> \n <li>Don’t make your CTA an image. If you do use an image, add ALT text that tells a person what the image is if it doesn’t load.</li> \n <li>Avoid menu bars</li> \n <li>Don’t stack links</li> \n <li>Test on multiple devices</li> \n</ol> \n<h3>Personalizing Your Email Content</h3> Another way to create killer email copy is by finding ways to personalize your emails to your subscribers. We're not just talking about inserting their names at the beginning of the copy. \n<span style=\"text-decoration: underline;\"><a href=\"https://www.campaignmonitor.com/blog/email-marketing/2017/08/15-email-personalization-stats-might-surprise-you/\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener noreferrer\">According to Campaign Monitor</a>,</span>&nbsp;emails with personalized subject lines receive 26% more opens than those that don’t. Not to mention, \n<span style=\"text-decoration: underline;\"><a href=\"https://dma.org.uk/uploads/ckeditor/National-client-email-2015.pdf\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener noreferrer\">according to DMA</a></span>, segmented and targeted emails generate 58% of revenue. What can you do to personalize your emails? \n<ol> \n <li>Include their name in your subject line.</li> \n <li>Address them directly in your email.</li> \n <li>Add in previous purchase information or items they may have recently looked at.</li> \n</ol> \n<h3>Writing A Better Subject Line</h3> Speaking of personalizing your subject lines, did you know that there’s a surefire way to write better subject lines? CoSchedule's \n<span style=\"text-decoration: underline;\"><a href=\"https://coschedule.com/email-subject-line-tester\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener noreferrer\">Email Subject Line Tester</a></span>&nbsp;is so easy to use. First, enter your subject line and click \n<span style=\"font-weight: bold;\">Score My Subject Line</span>\n<span style=\"font-weight: bold;\">:</span> \n<img class=\"drop-shadow aligncenter wp-image-55253 size-full\" src=\"https://media.coschedule.com/uploads/subject-line-tester.png\" alt=\"Try the Email Subject Line Tester\" width=\"770\" height=\"392\" /> After that, our tool will score your subject line on a variety of different factors and offer suggestions for improvement. \n<img class=\"aligncenter wp-image-54200 size-full\" src=\"https://media.coschedule.com/uploads/Email-Cal-Template-SS-13-1.png\" alt=\"An example of a headline from the headline analyzer\" width=\"769\" height=\"361\" /> Keep trying different combinations until you find the perfect subject line for your next email. \n<div class=\"link-callout\"> \n <strong>Action Items:</strong> \n <ol> \n  <li>Determine what writing style or format you want your copywriters to use. Include examples.</li> \n  <li>Create mobile optimization guides.</li> \n  <li>Identify how you are going to personalize your emails.</li> \n </ol> \n</div> \n<a href=\"https://coschedule.com/blog/?p=54247#toc\">Back to the Top</a> \n<a name=\"tests\"></a> \n<h2>Step Eight: Set Up A/B Tests</h2> A/B testing is an essential part of your email marketing strategy. What is A/B testing? A/B testing is a series of tests that allow email marketing teams to swap out different parts of their email, like a subject line, to see what kinds of copy performs best with their audience. You can A/B test a lot of different parts of your email including: \n<ul> \n <li>Your subject line (popular)</li> \n <li>Calls to action</li> \n <li>Testimonials</li> \n <li>Images</li> \n <li>Headlines</li> \n <li>Specific offers</li> \n</ul> Depending on the type of email tool you’re using, you may be able to A/B test some aspects of your email over others. \n<span style=\"text-decoration: underline;\"><a href=\"https://mailchimp.com/features/ab-testing/\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener noreferrer\">MailChimp</a></span>, \n<span style=\"text-decoration: underline;\"><a href=\"https://help.campaignmonitor.com/ab-test-your-email-campaigns\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener noreferrer\">Campaign Monitor</a></span>, and \n<span style=\"text-decoration: underline;\"><a href=\"https://knowledge.hubspot.com/email-user-guide-v2/how-to-utilize-ab-testing-in-email\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener noreferrer\">Hubspot</a></span>&nbsp;are just a few of the programs that allow you to A/B test parts of your emails. Decide which parts of your email you’d like to A/B test and record them in your template. \n<img class=\"drop-shadow alignnone wp-image-83749 size-full\" src=\"https://media.coschedule.com/uploads/2020/06/test-elements.png\" alt=\"Email A/B test elements\" width=\"1361\" height=\"771\" /> \n<div class=\"link-callout\"> \n <strong>Action Items:</strong> \n <ol> \n  <li>Choose which parts of your email campaign you want to A/B test.</li> \n  <li>Create copy or images for your test.</li> \n  <li>Record your results and adjust copy or images based on what performed best with your audience.</li> \n </ol> \n</div> \n<a href=\"https://coschedule.com/blog/?p=54247#toc\">Back to the Top</a> \n<a name=\"reports\"></a> \n<h2>Step Nine: Record Your Results and Adjust According to Performance</h2> The last step in your email marketing strategy will be to record your results and adjust based on the feedback you’ve gathered. Each email marketing platform should contain its own set of analytics where you can gather your data. You can look for and record results on: \n<ul> \n <li><span style=\"font-weight: bold;\">Email opens:</span>&nbsp;How many emails were opened vs. the number of emails that were sent.</li> \n <li><span style=\"font-weight: bold;\">Email deliveries:</span> How many emails from your send list were delivered?</li> \n <li><span style=\"font-weight: bold;\">Unsubscribers:</span>&nbsp;How many people unsubscribed from your email list?</li> \n <li><span style=\"font-weight: bold;\">New subscribers:</span>&nbsp;How many new subscribers have you gained?</li> \n <li><span style=\"font-weight: bold;\">Click through rates:</span>&nbsp;How many people clicked on the links in your email?</li> \n <li><span style=\"font-weight: bold;\">A/B test results:</span>&nbsp;What version of your A/B test won out?</li> \n <li><span style=\"font-weight: bold;\">ROI:</span>&nbsp;How much revenue has your email generated compared to how much you’ve spent?</li> \n <li><span style=\"font-weight: bold;\">The time they spent with the email open:</span>&nbsp;How long did a subscriber spend looking at your email?</li> \n <li><span style=\"font-weight: bold;\">Email bounces:</span> How many emails reached an inbox but were bounced back, unopened?</li> \n</ul> \n<h2>How to Manage Your Email With CoSchedule</h2> Once you have your strategy in place, you can move on to your execution. However, you have a lot of work to do, which can quickly become disorganized. Our new email integration allows you to plan, create, and send your emails at the best times and days for your audience. Managing your email schedule is easy. Follow these steps. \n<strong>Step 1</strong>: Go to your Integrations settings page. \n<img class=\"aligncenter wp-image-54338 size-full\" src=\"https://media.coschedule.com/uploads/Untitled-6-01.png\" alt=\"Listing the integrations you've made on your calendar\" width=\"769\" height=\"309\" /> \n<strong>Step 2</strong>: Find your email service provider in the integrations catalog. \n<img class=\"drop-shadow aligncenter wp-image-55461 size-full\" src=\"https://media.coschedule.com/uploads/email-integrations-catalog.png\" alt=\"Email integrations in the catalog.\" width=\"770\" height=\"532\" /> \n<strong>Step 3</strong>: Next, select a date on your calendar and click Email Marketing. \n<img class=\"aligncenter wp-image-54339 size-full\" src=\"https://media.coschedule.com/uploads/Untitled-6-03.png\" alt=\"Setting up email marketing in CoSchedule\" width=\"769\" height=\"268\" /> \n<strong>Step 4</strong>: Add a title to your campaign and create your email content. \n<img class=\"aligncenter wp-image-54340 size-full\" src=\"https://media.coschedule.com/uploads/Untitled-6-02.png\" alt=\"Adding a title to your campaign\" width=\"769\" height=\"543\" /> Your email will then deliver at your specified date and time. Pretty slick, huh? You can also set up a filtered view of your calendar just to see your email activities, so you know exactly what emails are going out and when. Choose \"create new saved view\" on the left-side menu. \n<img class=\"drop-shadow aligncenter wp-image-67441 size-full\" src=\"https://media.coschedule.com/uploads/Screenshot-2019-02-11-14.59.47.png\" alt=\"Creating a new saved view\" width=\"918\" height=\"735\" /> Next, name your saved view and add a filter category. \n<img class=\"drop-shadow aligncenter wp-image-67442 size-full\" src=\"https://media.coschedule.com/uploads/Screenshot-2019-02-11-15.01.31.png\" alt=\"Naming your saved view and adding a filter category\" width=\"778\" height=\"483\" /> &nbsp; Choose \"Type\" or \"Email Service Accounts\" in the drop-down menu. \n<img class=\"drop-shadow aligncenter wp-image-67444 size-full\" src=\"https://media.coschedule.com/uploads/Screenshot-2019-02-11-15.03.05.png\" alt=\"Dropdown menu from the filter category and select &quot;type&quot;\" width=\"730\" height=\"537\" /> &nbsp; Then, add all your email content types or email service accounts that are connected. \n<img class=\"drop-shadow alignnone wp-image-67445 size-full\" src=\"https://media.coschedule.com/uploads/Screenshot-2019-02-11-15.04.47.png\" alt=\"Adding email content types or email service accounts\" width=\"1704\" height=\"936\" /> &nbsp; Now you have a custom view of all your email messaging, who is responsible for it, and when they are going live. It's a marketing project manager's dream come true, really. \n<h2>Go Create Your Own Email Strategy</h2> With the information that you have and your strategy template in hand, you can create your own email marketing strategy. Now you can set goals, plan ahead, and create a strategy that helps boost the bottom line of your business. If you’re looking to create more than just your email marketing strategy, check out the following posts: \n<ul> \n <li><span style=\"text-decoration: underline;\"><a href=\"https://coschedule.com/blog/content-marketing-strategy-template/\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener noreferrer\">This is How To Build A Content Marketing Strategy You’ll Actually Use (Free Template)</a></span></li> \n <li><span style=\"text-decoration: underline;\"><a href=\"https://coschedule.com/blog/social-media-marketing-strategy/\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener noreferrer\">How to Create the Best Documented Social Media Marketing Strategy In Eight Steps</a></span></li> \n <li><span style=\"text-decoration: underline;\"><a href=\"https://coschedule.com/blog/video-marketing-strategy/\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener noreferrer\">How To Make A Video Content Marketing Strategy That Will Engage Your Audience</a></span></li> \n <li><span style=\"text-decoration: underline;\"><a href=\"https://coschedule.com/marketing-strategy\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener noreferrer\">How To Create A Marketing Strategy That Will Skyrocket Your Results By 9,360%</a></span></li> \n</ul> \n<i><span style=\"font-weight: 400;\">This blog post was originally published on April 23, 2018. 5.01.31.png":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx10/cdn39@2020_3/2020/08/24/21-56-26-206_5ef8715cb888f091.webp","https://media.coschedule.com/uploads/Screenshot-2019-02-11-15.03.05.png":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx24/cdn60@2020_6/2020/08/24/21-56-40-524_13bd78825e162a05.webp","https://media.coschedule.com/uploads/Screenshot-2019-02-11-15.04.47.png":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx19/cdn11@2020_6/2020/08/24/21-56-30-598_215ec87eba53d34b.webp"},"publishedOrCreatedDate":1598306169574},{"createdTime":"2020-08-25 196]","link":"https://coschedule.com/?p=84232","description":"<img class=\"alignnone size-full wp-image-85230\" line.\n\nToday’s guest is David Lemley, founder of Retail Voodoo. He has worked with beloved brands, including Starbucks, REI, and KIND. David describes what steps to take to future-proof business and brands to thrive and survive for sustained success.\n\n[podcast_motor_player]\n\n<strong>Some of the highlights of the show include:</strong>\n<ul>\n \t<li>Branding’s Value: More than a logo—develop a truly authentic brand built to last</li>\n \t<li>Past Background: Branding used to be all about making marks and doing things</li>\n \t<li>Present and Future Branding: Promises you make, keep, and feel</li>\n \t<li>New Things: Help food, beverage, wellness, and fitness brands win market share</li>\n \t<li>Future-proof Brand: Plan to survive and thrive during unforeseen circumstances</li>\n \t<li>Consequences: Loss of market share and impacts partner/customer relationships</li>\n \t<li>Essential Component: Data and research from brightest minds erodes resistance</li>\n \t<li>Future-Proof Process: Understand core audience to anticipate changing needs</li>\n \t<li>Building Blocks: People view brands as personal identity with values and morals</li>\n \t<li>Tasks, Tactics, and Tips: Read David’s book, <em>Beloved and Dominant Brands</em></li>\n \t<li>Vectors: Ingredient/technology, consumer preferences, worldwide, and relevance</li>\n</ul>\n<div class=\"link-callout\">\n\n<strong>Links:</strong>\n<ul>\n \t<li><a href=\"https://www.retail-voodoo.com/\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener Content Marketing Podcast! The podcast is also available on <a href=\"https://soundcloud.com/coschedule\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener noreferrer\">SoundCloud,</a> <a href=\"http://www.stitcher.com/s?fid=101560&#38;;refid=stpr\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener noreferrer\">Stitcher</a>, and <a href=\"https://goo.gl/app/playmusic?ibi=com.google.PlayMusic&#38;;isi=691797987&#38;ius=googleplaymusic&#38;link=https://play.google.com/music/m/Iks7nu4sb6gquwxy3purzwlitga?t%3DActionable_Content_Marketing\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener noreferrer\">Google Play</a>.\n<div class=\"link-callout\">\n\n<strong>Quotes:</strong>\n<ul>\n \t<li>“It is much more about the promises you make, if you keep them, and how people feel about it.”</li>\n \t<li>“The consequences are loss of market share to hungrier competitors, first and foremost. It also has an impact on your distribution relationships.”</li>\n \t<li>“Take your time and do not let social media or your social media team try to drive your brand. If you don’t know who you are, it’s better to keep your mouth shut.”</li>\n</ul>\n</div>\n[Tweet \"Future-proofing your brand for sustained success, with @davidlemley from @RetailVoodoo.\"]\n<h1><strong>Transcript:</strong></h1>\nBen: Hey, David. How's it going?\n\nDavid: I'm doing well, Ben. How are you?\n\nBen: I'm doing fantastic. It's Friday, so I'm looking forward to the weekend.\n\nDavid: Yeah, we've earned it.\n\nBen: Yeah, I would say so. Would you mind introducing yourself to our audience and explain what you do at Retail Voodoo?\n\nDavid: Sure. My name is David Lemley. I am a brand strategist who came up through the system. I've been doing this for about 30 years back before branding had a capital B, which means that it used to be all about making marks and doing things similarly to scouring cattle. Now, it is much more about the promise you should make, the way you keep them, and have people feel about it.\n\n<img class=\"alignnone size-full wp-image-85224\" src=\"https://media.coschedule.com/uploads/2020/08/196_David-Podcast-Graphics_quote-01.png\" alt=\"\" width=\"1361\" height=\"630\" />\n\nAt Retail Voodoo, we work in the food and beverage, wellness, and fitness spaces. We help brands with their unfair share of the market.\n\nBen: Would you mind mentioning a few of the brands you've worked with. I know from seeing the pitch that your team had sent over, there are a number of companies in that list that our audience might be familiar with.\n\nDavid: Sure. The ones that come to mind are recent favorites are Essentia Water, which is one that may or may not be known. Another one that I'm really pleased with is the way LesserEvil healthy snacks have turned out. Of course, we've worked with KIND, Pepsi, Walmart, and Starbucks, and many many well-known ones, but the ones that are really exciting right now are the ones that are doing new things in food and beverage. They’re really pushing those ingredients.\n\nBen: For sure. You're deep in the branding world, and what we're really going to be diving into deep over the course of this conversation is how to future proof your brand. Just briefly, would you mind explaining (your way of thinking), why should brands and companies be concerned with the concept of future-proofing their brand?\n\nDavid: It's a really good question. The pandemic is a great example of things that can happen in the world that you cannot expect. Having that future-proofing plan gives your brand a higher likelihood of not just surviving, but potentially thriving or increasing long term relevance through unforeseen circumstances.\n\nBen: Absolutely. What would you say are the potential consequences for neglecting this area or for just coasting on autopilot rather than putting appropriate investment into your branding?\n\nDavid: The consequences are the loss of market share to hungrier competitors (first and foremost). I think that it also has an impact on your distribution relationship, your key ingredients supplier relationships, your OEMs, and all of those people. If you are on autopilot and other people or brands are connecting with consumers better in your space, then ultimately, you will lose the sale and do it significantly repeatedly.\n\n<img class=\"alignnone size-full wp-image-85226\" src=\"https://media.coschedule.com/uploads/2020/08/196_David-Podcast-Graphics_quote-02.png\" alt=\"\" width=\"1361\" height=\"630\" />\n\nBen: Yeah, and I think what's interesting about that is it sounds as though branding really impacts every area of the business and every area of your relationships with all of your partners. Would you say that’s accurate?\n\nDavid: Yeah, I think it is. I'm so glad you said it that way because that is something that a lot of people don't necessarily understand. It's that when you have a brand, and that is your North Star (if you will). It defines your value system. It decides what you will or what you will not make, who you will or will not do business with, and how you will or will not treat humans—your consumers. Those are things that brand, and graphic design, or marketing systems don't typically think about when [...] something unless they have those guard rails in place ahead of time.\n\nBen: Yeah. You work with lots of awesome brands. I'm assuming those are very often brands that—at least are the base level—understand the value of branding. Thus, they are making an investment. But if I'm a listener to this episode, let's say I'm in a company where conversations about branding are essentially just like marketing—trying to convince the CEO that branding is not just their logo. It's not just these surface-level elements.\n\nWhat advice would you have for a marketer in that position to help them make a case for really investing and branding? Because if they can't get past that basic tumbling block, then everything else that we're going to talk about (I imagine) would be very difficult for them to duplicate.\n\nDavid: Sure. The best advice you can give is to have them understand it's a long term conversation, and there is a business case for everything. What I do whenever I encounter that, which I have not for quite a number of years now. I don't frequently run into that C-suite that thinks that way, but we would come up frequently before. I would just bring in the heavy hitters. I would bring in David Maister, who wrote the book Managing The Professional Service Firm, who is a prof at Harvard, and who wrote a book that said the brand is the only sustainable business asset in the world.\n\nI would pull from all of these experts and say, don't trust me, here's what the brightest minds in the world think about this. Bringing that data and research to the conversation will, over time, erode that wall of resistance to the idea that brand is an essential component in a business.\n\nBen: Absolutely. Let's say this hypothetical marketer. They’ve gotten past those initial hurdles. What would you say are some of the essential components of building a brand that is effectively future-proofed? Or maybe a better way of putting it is, how do you begin that process of future-proofing a brand?\n\nDavid: It's complicated, and one could argue that because we don't know the future, there are so many facets that it's an ongoing process. But if you start with and maintain a commitment to understanding your core audience, understanding who they are, and what they need. Therefore, if you know who they are, you're going to be able to anticipate their changing preferences as consumers and their changing needs as people.\n\nIf you are journeying with them rather than trying to sell them stuff, you are going to maintain a dialogue, which will keep you relevant for the long term.\n\nBen: David's thoughts on bringing data and research in the conversations with executive stakeholders and their C-suite is spot on. And it's applicable in so many areas anytime you're trying to build a case for taking a certain course of action or making an investment in a particular area of marketing or your business.\n\nSometimes, decision-makers just really want to see some outside validation, that your ideas are data-backed. They are supported by research. They are championed by industry experts. And you're not just pulling something out of your imagination before they are willing to sign-off on a budget and the resources that you need to really get things done.\n\nThat opens a whole other discussion around trust. If executives didn’t trust you as a marketer, why did they hire you? That's a very valid frustration, but if you can look at things from their perspective and give them the things they want to see, they can feel confident in really throwing their full support behind your ideas and just really showing that you've done your homework that way.\n\nYou'll find that those conversations around increasing your investment and branding, increasing your investment in really anything. Those conversations are going to grow much more successfully. Now, back to David.\n\nLet's say a company, let's say they have a strong brand right now. They feel pretty good about where their brand is at. But let's say that this concept of proactively trying to think long term, to think about it like it’s an ongoing conversation, or to really do those things to future proof the brand. What would you recommend they do? Say they’re advanced with branding, but maybe this is a new concept to them.\n\nDavid: If they're strong and want to think about the future, understanding that people today are looking to brands to have morals and values the way that previous generations looked to schools, churches, and social clubs. They are now using brands as building blocks of their own personal identity, so they want you to have a value system that allows them to look good or be good by association.\n\nWe call that citizen brandhood. For brands that want future proof, deciding what kind of citizen you are, and going out, picking a fight, and tackling society’s enemies is a great way to maintain long-term relevance.\n\nBen: That's a super interesting point. The CMO—or whoever in the marketing department is responsible for making these kinds of decisions—really wants to become a more values-driven type brand (like what you're describing). How would you recommend that they begin identifying what their own values are authentically rather than just trying to latch onto whatever thing seems to be the issue of the day they need to attach themselves to, whether it makes sense or not?\n\nDavid: The key thing is to have a cultural assessment of the organization and enroll all of the people who are going to have a stake in the decisions you are making. That might be the rest of the C-suite, it might be the entire marketing team, it might be the finance team and the procurement team. Everyone who can have an opinion needs to participate in that cultural assessment.\n\nFrom there, there will be clues. Oh, we all care about this. We're all here this way. We care about children. We care about social justice. We care about equality. Or we care about making sure there's food for the next generation. Something will come up.\n\nI'm using my food and beverage lens right now today (for whatever reason it's showing up), but it helps paint the picture. I think when we work with organizations who “don't have a value system in place,” we always promise them that it's there and our duty to help them unearth it and to do it in a way that is credible, authentic, and nobody is going to want to jump out a window.\n\nBen: Yeah. No jumping out the window. I'm just speaking anecdotally. This is something I feel like I see a lot. You can see a lot of brands on social media getting criticized when they do this wrong. Or if they try to attach themselves to a cause, to a value, or to an ethic that they just transparently don't embody beyond a tweet or an Instagram post here and there (or something like that).\n\nWhat do you see are the consequences of not being thoughtful with the way that you try to convey or communicate your brand's values?\n\nDavid: The consequences of trying to have values du jour—that is high risk because we live in a world where anything that can have ever said, thought, felt, or done can be weaponized through the web by people who want to prove that you're wrong. That is the risk. You will get a huge backlash.\n\nThe way to be mindful and not have that happen is to take your time and do not let social media or your social media team try and drive your brand. It is a tool and a tactic, and it's an amazing thing. However, if you don't know who you are, it's better to keep your mouth shut.\n\n<img class=\"alignnone size-full wp-image-85228\" src=\"https://media.coschedule.com/uploads/2020/08/196_David-Podcast-Graphics_quote-04.png\" alt=\"\" width=\"1361\" height=\"630\" />\n\nBen: Right. Switching back a little bit toward what does this actually look like? Brand building and future-proofing, what does it actually look like in terms of the actual tasks or tactics that a marketer might carry out? How would you recommend our listeners start assessing or auditing their brand in order to make sure that they are keeping themselves forward-focused and looking towards the future?\n\nDavid: You know, I read a book about this exact subject.\n\nBen: I thought it might come up.\n\nDavid: It’s called Beloved and Dominant Brands. My copy is covered in sticky notes right now, but Beloved and Dominant Brands, which is an ecosystem to help organizations think this through as individuals and as management teams. What it does is it gives the entrepreneur, the executive team, the marketing team, and the investment team all on the same page. It gives them the common vocabulary and helps them benchmark their organization as a brand against a competitive set or a future set.\n\nBen: Very cool. I would say, for anybody listening, I would definitely recommend checking out that book to get some of that more tactical guidance in this area. The last question that I’ll throw your way is what tips you might share with our listeners to ensure that their entire company plays? Everyone in the company who has a stake in embodying the company's brand, how do you manage to help the entire organization do its part to keep that brand consistent for the long haul?\n\nDavid: I'm a huge fan of having a playbook that is widely distributed, shared to, and co-authored by all. But that doesn't happen weekly. It happens in seasons. This is what we're doing now. We're going to collect and we're going to reimagine this in two years, in three years, or in five years. Doing it in that way is really important, but as they are thinking about tactics to employ, the one that I like to think about the most is getting organizations to start thinking about vectors.\n\nLet's say you make a product, and right now, you are the only one who has that ingredient supply, but you know that in two years, yours is going to be gone, so the entire pricing model is going to change. You can take that vector and crosshatch it with changing consumer preferences. Maybe you can say, oh, it's going to become international. Then there are three vectors. You start to say, what would the world look like then? What do I need to price it as? What does it need to be called? Do I need a different ingredient or a different technology?\n\nYou can start going after that based on your value system as an organization. Then you have that as a fourth vector. Now you start to say the sandbox is [...] rather than the world is my oyster, and you stay relevant over the long term.\n\nBen: Cool. That's great advice. Like I said, that's the last question that I had. But before I let you go, is there anything about this topic that you feel is really important for our listeners to take away from this conversation that you haven't had the opportunity to touch on yet?\n\nDavid: The thing that I would like listeners to know is brand building is a long term sport with no finish line.\n<a
