src=\"https://media.coschedule.com/uploads/2020/07/content-marketing-editorial-calendar-header.gif\" alt=\"Content marketing editorial calendar header (gif)\" width=\"1360\" height=\"580\" /> Using a content marketing editorial calendar sounds like a great idea, but do they really help? When it comes to content marketing, many companies that \n<a href=\"http://coschedule.com/blog/publish-more-consistent-content/\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener noreferrer\">struggle with consistency</a> have found an editorial calendar to be the perfect solution. Even those who don't have that problem have been using a content marketing editorial calendar for years. What about your organization? Could you benefit from adding an editorial calendar to your content marketing plan? Most of us know that the answer to that question is \"yes\". We know that the number one way to get traffic is through the very habits that an editorial calendar will help us develop —\n<a href=\"http://coschedule.com/blog/organize-your-ideas/\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener noreferrer\">organization</a>&nbsp;and consistency. However, a lot of marketers&nbsp;still struggle with knowing exactly how to set up and use a calendar to achieve their goals. If that sounds like you, it's time to learn what journalists have known for decades: editorial calendars are essential for maintaining busy, successful publishing schedules. [Tweet \"The Best Way to Get Organized With a Content Marketing Editorial Calendar via @CoSchedule\"] \n<div class=\"callout\"> \n <a name=\"toc\"></a>\n <strong>Table of Contents:</strong> \n <ul> \n  <li><a href=\"https://coschedule.com/blog/?p=55538#template\">Editorial Calendar Template</a></li> \n  <li><a href=\"https://coschedule.com/blog/?p=55538#need-to-build\">What Do You Need to Build an Editorial Calendar?</a></li> \n  <li><a href=\"https://coschedule.com/blog/?p=55538#content-marketing-definition\">What is Content Marketing?</a></li> \n  <li><a href=\"https://coschedule.com/blog/?p=55538#what-is-editorial-calendar\">What is a Content Marketing Editorial Calendar?</a></li> \n  <li><a href=\"https://coschedule.com/blog/?p=55538#why\">Why Should Content Marketers Use an Editorial Calendar?</a></li> \n  <li><a href=\"https://coschedule.com/blog/?p=55538#software-vs-spreadsheets\">Two Types of Editorial Calendars: Spreadsheets vs. Software</a></li> \n  <li><a href=\"https://coschedule.com/blog/?p=55538#getting-started\">Getting Started With Your Editorial Calendar Strategy</a></li> \n  <li><a href=\"https://coschedule.com/blog/?p=55538#execute\">Execute Your Plan With Your Content Marketing Editorial Calendar</a></li> \n  <li><a href=\"https://coschedule.com/blog/?p=55538#publishing-schedule\">Outline a Basic Publishing Schedule</a></li> \n  <li><a href=\"https://coschedule.com/blog/?p=55538#workflow\">Building Calendar-Based Workflows</a></li> \n  <li><a href=\"https://coschedule.com/blog/?p=55538#management\">Managing Your Calendar</a></li> \n </ul> \n</div> \n<a name=\"template\"></a> \n<h2>First, Download Your Editorial Calendar Template</h2> Planning is an essential step to finding success within your content — in both efficiency and relevancy. Creating better content more consistently goes hand in hand with the strategic use of an editorial calendar. If you don't have one yet, you're in the right place. You can build one quickly with this Excel-based template. When you're ready to upgrade, consider an alternative, like CoSchedule. Optimize your content with the best steps to seamless organization. This template bundle includes: \n<ul class=\"p-rich_text_list p-rich_text_list__bullet\" data-stringify-type=\"unordered-list\" data-indent=\"0\"> \n <li>Two content marketing editorial calendar templates</li> \n <li>Social media calendar template</li> \n <li>Email calendar template</li> \n <li>Printable calendar template</li> \n</ul> [Cookie \"Get Your Free Content Marketing Editorial Calendar Template || https://coschedule.com/blog/wp-content/uploads/editorial-MU-01.png || Download Template || https://coschedule.com/blog/wp-content/uploads/editorial-calendar-template.xlsx.zip\"] \n<div class=\"link-callout\">\n <strong><a href=\"https://coschedule.com/blog/?p=55538#toc\">Back to the Top</a></strong>\n</div> \n<a name=\"what-is-editorial-calendar\"></a> \n<h2>What is a Content Marketing Editorial Calendar?</h2> A traditional editorial calendar helps visualize content publishing on a calendar-like interface, but how does that differ from a content marketing editorial calendar? \n<img class=\"aligncenter wp-image-84754 size-full\" src=\"https://media.coschedule.com/uploads/2020/07/editorial-calendar-definition.png\" alt=\"Definition of a content marketing editorial calendar.\" width=\"1361\" height=\"763\" /> Content&nbsp;\n<a href=\"http://coschedule.com/blog/content-marketing-promotion-strategy/\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener noreferrer\">marketing is highly strategic</a>. That means you need to understand your audience, what motivates them, and what they need to hear to make a connection with your brand. A content marketing editorial calendar is essentially a planning document that gives your team a plan of attack. Like a traditional editorial calendar, it gives you a bird's-eye view of what is going on. However, it should be expanded to fit all the different marketing team channels. Overall, it should: \n<ul> \n <li>Provide a place to generate post ideas and key topics.</li> \n <li>Assign writing and other editorial tasks to key members of your team.</li> \n <li>Create a publishing schedule that helps you maintain a consistent presence.</li> \n <li>Allow you to make in-process adjustments with drag-and-drop ease.</li> \n <li>Visualize your marketing strategy in a way that everyone can understand.</li> \n <li>Act as a communication point to team members.</li> \n</ul> A content marketing editorial calendar gives you and your team a framework for building trust with your audience. In part, it is a strategic marketing tool, but it's also a place to keep your team organized and on top of things. \n<div class=\"link-callout\">\n <strong>Recommended Reading:</strong> \n <a href=\"https://coschedule.com/blog/content-marketing-software-tools/\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener noreferrer\">81 Most Essential Content Marketing Tools and Software You Need to Be Successful</a>\n</div> \n<div class=\"link-callout\">\n <strong><a href=\"https://coschedule.com/blog/?p=55538#toc\">Back to the Top</a></strong>\n</div> \n<a name=\"need-to-build\"></a> \n<h2>What You Need to Start a Content Marketing Editorial Calendar</h2> There is no shortage of templates available for creating your editorial calendar. Some are digital or written out on paper, but none are more prepared for the modern age than the fully digital options. The best part about using a&nbsp;paper editorial calendar is that it can help you start the habit of using one to plan your content marketing. Eventually, you'll need bigger and better tools, but this is a great way to start out without making a major financial investment. \n<div class=\"link-callout\">\n <strong>Recommended Reading:</strong> \n <a href=\"https://coschedule.com/blog/content-marketing-process/\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener noreferrer\">The Most Complete Content Marketing Process You Need to Get Organized</a>\n</div> \n<h3>No More Spreadsheets: The Digital&nbsp;Content Marketing Editorial Calendar</h3> When you're ready to upgrade, a tool like \n<a href=\"http://coschedule.com/#sign-up\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener noreferrer\">CoSchedule</a> can provide a fully-digital solution — connecting your content calendar directly to your WordPress blog and social media networks. This powerful tool combines social media and content marketing scheduling with a robust productivity tool that will allow you to share tasks with your team and leave comments or critiques on their work. You can also schedule your blog posts with a drag-and-drop ease. https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=W5yz_ZbMmrs \n<a href=\"https://coschedule.com/signup\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener noreferrer\">Start a 14-day trial</a> or \n<a href=\"https://coschedule.com/product-demo\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener noreferrer\">schedule a demo now</a>. [Tweet \"What makes @CoSchedule the best marketing calendar platform available right now?\"] \n<div class=\"link-callout\">\n <strong><a href=\"https://coschedule.com/blog/?p=55538#toc\">Back to the Top</a></strong>\n</div> \n<a name=\"why\"></a> \n<h2>Why Should Content Marketers Use an Editorial Calendar?</h2> Journalists and news publishers understand the value of editorial calendars. They’re essential tools for planning ahead and sticking to deadlines. Without them, it’s extremely difficult to plan content around centralized themes (think how magazines target themes each issue), or to even know who’s doing what, and when. In other words, \n<a href=\"http://coschedule.com/blog/remarkable-content/\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener noreferrer\">creating content consistently</a> without a calendar is like driving a car without a steering wheel. It doesn’t work. Smart content marketers understand this, too. However, even if you know why you need editorial calendar software, it’s possible your boss is tougher to convince. This may be especially true if the person holding the credit card isn’t actually a marketer. If this situation sounds familiar, stick with us through this post. We’re going to show exactly what you can accomplish with editorial calendar software. If you want to create great content consistently, it pays to know what you’re going to do before you do it. As we like to say at CoSchedule, “Plan your work, then work your plan.” \n<img class=\"alignnone wp-image-84691 size-full\" src=\"https://media.coschedule.com/uploads/2020/07/plan-quote.png\" alt=\"Plan your work, then work your plan.\" width=\"1361\" height=\"763\" /> When it comes to planning, too many content marketers just wing it. “Winging it” isn’t a real editorial strategy, though. It leads to creating directionless content that doesn’t produce results. Deadlines get missed, projects get planned haphazardly, and teams waste time spinning their wheels. [Tweet \"Winging it is not a real editorial strategy.\"] An editorial calendar helps create order out of chaos. It provides a simple planning tool for laying out: \n<ul> \n <li>What content you’ll create.</li> \n <li>Why you’re creating that content.</li> \n <li>Who will create each piece of content.</li> \n <li>When that content will be due.</li> \n</ul> That sums up the basic functionality of a content calendar. Take things a step further with editorial calendar software like CoSchedule, and you can also achieve the following: \n<ul> \n <li>Successfully plan out coordinated content campaigns and themes.</li> \n <li>Lay out your content publishing schedule alongside your social media promotion.</li> \n <li>Manage your team member’s workflow.</li> \n</ul> That’s just scratching the surface. Let’s dig deeper and see what an editorial calendar app can do for you. \n<h3>Keep All Your Content Ideas and Projects Organized</h3> Having a great idea, only to forget it later, is frustrating. Having a great idea and simply not executing on it may be even worse. At CoSchedule, when we have a great content idea, it goes straight on our editorial calendar. That way, nothing gets forgotten, and those ideas get turned directly into actionable content that helps our audience and makes us more successful. \n<h3>Stop Missing Deadlines and Get More Stuff Done</h3> According to Parkinson’s Law, “Work expands to fill the time available for its completion.” Without constraints, people take as much time as they have to get their work done. This isn’t necessarily because they’re lazy, but because it’s built into the way humans operate. \n<img class=\"alignnone wp-image-84692 size-full\" src=\"https://media.coschedule.com/uploads/2020/07/work-quote.png\" alt=\"Work expands to fill the time available for it's completion.\" width=\"1361\" height=\"763\" /> This is why we also often feel like we get more done under pressure. When deadlines are fast approaching, we’re more motivated to get the work done. With a clear content calendar to keep track of your deadlines, it’s a lot harder to forget when things are due. Clear deadlines, combined with a tool for ensuring they’re enforced, results in more content getting created. It’s as simple as that. \n<div class=\"link-callout\">\n <strong><a href=\"https://coschedule.com/blog/?p=55538#toc\">Back to the Top</a></strong>\n</div> \n<a name=\"software-vs-spreadsheets\"></a> \n<h2>Two Types of Editorial Calendars: Spreadsheets Vs. Software</h2> Spreadsheets are a common editorial calendar solution, and they're flexible. If you're just getting started, they're better than using nothing. \n<img class=\"aligncenter wp-image-57286 size-full\" src=\"https://coschedule.com/blog/wp-content/uploads/calendar-spreadsheet.png\" alt=\"Example of a content marketing calendar spreadsheet\" width=\"770\" height=\"309\" /> However, they do have some downsides: \n<ul> \n <li><strong>Lack of automation</strong>. There's no way to automate publishing or content promotion via spreadsheet.</li> \n <li><strong>Disconnected workflows</strong>. The calendar is separate from social networks and email platforms used to promote content.</li> \n <li><strong>Communication is missing</strong>. Without commenting functionality, teams must rely on outside communication tools.</li> \n</ul> Fortunately, there's a solution. \n<h2>Why Use Editorial Calendar Software?</h2> Technically, you can use spreadsheets to build editorial calendars. They work well enough, and they’re cost-effective. However, their functionality is fairly limited, they can be time-consuming to maintain, and ultimately, they aren’t a ton of fun to use. Using an app instead can turn your content calendar from something you have to use, to something you actually want to use. \n<h3>See Everything in One Place</h3> The value of seeing your entire editorial strategy in one place can’t be overstated. With CoSchedule, you can see all your content in one place. This includes blog posts, social media messages (which can be toggled on/off), and anything else you're working on. You can also \n<a href=\"http://help.coschedule.com/hc/en-us/articles/215281457-Connecting-CoSchedule-To-Google-Calendar\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener noreferrer\">connect your Google Calendar</a>, so events and meeting times can be synced on your CoSchedule calendar. \n<img class=\"drop-shadow alignnone wp-image-84601 size-full\" src=\"https://media.coschedule.com/uploads/2020/07/Screen-Shot-2020-07-14-at-1.15.32-PM.png\" alt=\"Connect your Google calendar with your CoSchedule Marketing Calendar.\" width=\"2868\" height=\"1634\" /> [Tweet \"See your entire editorial strategy in one place with @CoSchedule\"] \n<h3>Drag-and-Drop Convenience</h3> If you want to move something on a spreadsheet, you have to copy and paste it. When you have a lot of stuff on your content calendar, this can be a pain. With CoSchedule, you can drag-and-drop content anywhere you want on the calendar. This makes adjusting your calendar to reflect shifting priorities easy. \n<img class=\"drop-shadow alignnone wp-image-84618 size-full\" src=\"https://media.coschedule.com/uploads/2020/07/blog-REBPUBLISH-Content-Marketing-Editorial-Calender-Template-32.png\" alt=\"Drag and drop feature in CoSchedule.\" width=\"1363\" height=\"687\" /> \n<h3>Collaborate in One Place</h3> With spreadsheets, your calendar and communication tools are separate. As a result, discussion around projects can easily get lost. That’s why collaboration features are built directly into CoSchedule. \n<img class=\"drop-shadow aligncenter wp-image-84761 size-full\" src=\"https://media.coschedule.com/uploads/2020/07/discussion-thread-files.png\" alt=\"Discussion thread example\" width=\"1360\" height=\"402\" /> \n<h3></h3> \n<h3>Integrate With All Your Other Tools</h3> \n<a href=\"https://coschedule.com/integrations\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener noreferrer\">CoSchedule connects with other tools</a> you’re likely using to help you get more organized and save more time. Its integrations include: \n<ul> \n <li>WordPress</li> \n <li>Social Networks (Facebook, Twitter, LinkedIn, Pinterest, Tumblr, and Instagram)</li> \n <li>Email Service Providers (MailChimp, Active Campaign, Campaign Monitor, and Constant Contact)</li> \n <li>Evernote</li> \n <li>Google Docs / Office 365</li> \n <li>Google Drive / Dropbox / OneDrive</li> \n</ul> And more. \n<h3>Convenient Color-Coding</h3> It seems like a small detail. However, if you’re used to planning content in spreadsheets, you probably have elaborate color-coding schemes set up to make them easier to understand. You don’t have to lose this when moving up to CoSchedule. Every item you place on your calendar can easily be color-coded for quick recognition. \n<img class=\"drop-shadow aligncenter wp-image-84759 size-full\" src=\"https://media.coschedule.com/uploads/2020/07/color-coded-calendar-1.png\" alt=\"Example of a color-coded calendar\" width=\"1360\" height=\"278\" /> \n<h3></h3> \n<h3>Store Drafts for Later and Never Lose an Idea Again</h3> Have an idea for a post you don't want to lose, or do you have something in progress you won't be able to finish until a later date? No problem. Just add it to the Idea Board: \n<img class=\"drop-shadow aligncenter wp-image-84760 size-full\" src=\"https://media.coschedule.com/uploads/2020/07/idea-board-example.png\" alt=\"Example of the Idea Board\" width=\"1360\" height=\"516\" /> &nbsp; \n<h2>Plan How You'll Actually Do This</h2> Once you know why you're doing content marketing and how you're going to be successful, you can finally start \n<a href=\"https://coschedule.com/blog/blog-planning-saves-time/\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener noreferrer\">planning your actual content</a> schedule. Though we're really talking about content marketing editorial calendars here and only just getting started, skipping to this point without understanding how you'll be successful in the first place is kind of a waste of time. You need to have awesome ideas to plan awesome content, and that comes from knowing your goals and your audience. \n<h3>Find the Best Ideas For Your Content</h3> Start by simply finding the best ideas to plan them as content with your editorial calendar. The challenge is to find ideas that you already know are going to \n<a href=\"https://coschedule.com/blog/how-to-start-a-blog-with-no-audience/\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener noreferrer\">connect with your audience</a>. You can do that by searching for socially-inspired ideas, planning them in your editorial calendar, and writing to connect with your audience. By socially-inspired content, I mean \n<strong>really listening to your audience</strong>. These content ideas are based on what your audience actually needs help with, then writing content to help them out — building the trust you set out to create in the first place. This way, you start planning content that revolves around a problem or challenge your audience is facing. \n<div class=\"link-callout\">\n <strong>Recommended Reading:</strong> \n <a href=\"https://coschedule.com/blog/how-to-start-a-blog-with-no-audience/\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener noreferrer\">How To Start A Blog When You Have Absolutely No Audience</a>\n</div> Easy, right? Here are some quick things you can look into to find your audience's biggest problems: \n<div class=\"alert alert-info\"> \n <ul> \n  <li>Look through your latest support tickets.</li> \n  <li>Read, respond, and ask questions in blog post comments.</li> \n  <li>Stick around for event Q&amp;As (think about when people ask questions after people present webinars, conferences, etc.).</li> \n  <li>Check out what's going on with social media, and use it to ask your audience questions.</li> \n  <li>Interview them — just chat with your customers!</li> \n </ul> \n</div> I'm sure you could think of dozens of other ways to understand your audience's biggest challenges. \n<h3>Figure Out How You'll Tell Your Story</h3> By this point, you probably have a bajillion ideas you could write about. Now is the best time to plan the best way to write those ideas, so one piece of content carries on the story where another left off. \n<img class=\"alignnone wp-image-84766 size-full\" src=\"https://media.coschedule.com/uploads/2020/07/blog-REBPUBLISH-Content-Marketing-Editorial-Calender-Template-09-1.png\" alt=\"\" width=\"1361\" height=\"763\" /> Your blog posts are like chapters in a book. They should make sense together, so you can build your audience around a central topic — the biggest challenge they face. You need to find patterns to plan them in an ideal chronological order. That'll help you publish your content in the best order possible for your unique story. \n<div class=\"link-callout\">\n <strong>Recommended Reading:</strong> \n <a href=\"https://coschedule.com/blog/content-marketing-story/\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener noreferrer\">An Easier Way To Tell Your Story Using Content Marketing</a>\n</div> \n<h3>Get the Entire Marketing Team On Board</h3> Let me be clear on this from the get-go, you just need to get the \n<em>right</em> people on board. Sure, getting buy-in from the higher-ups is something that definitely needs to happen, but you only need to understand what resources you have available to you to create the content you're planning. You need to know who can help you out with strategy, text, graphics, editing, and social media. Maybe that's all up to you, or maybe there are some other awesome folks who can help you out. \n<img class=\"alignnone size-full wp-image-84774\" src=\"https://media.coschedule.com/uploads/2020/07/blog-REBPUBLISH-Content-Marketing-Editorial-Calender-Template-10-1-1.png\" alt=\"\" width=\"1361\" height=\"737\" /> These are the main roles you'll need to fill to \n<a href=\"https://coschedule.com/blog/team-blog/\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener noreferrer\">build a successful team</a> that creates awesome content, and one very busy person could do a ton of these on their own: \n<div class=\"alert alert-info\"> \n <ul> \n  <li><strong>Project manager:</strong> The person who helps the team understand your audience, goals, and the stories you're going to tell. This is more high-level stuff.</li> \n  <li><strong>Content writer:</strong> Think of the folks actually writing your awesome content. They take the project manager's vision and make it reality.</li> \n  <li><strong>Proofreader:</strong> These people proofread and make sure the content will connect with your audience the way your project manager dreamed up.</li> \n  <li><strong>Content designer:</strong> This person adds tons of value to the post to help your audience consume the hard-to-understand information at a glance (actually, 60,000 times faster than text alone).</li> \n  <li><strong>Social promoter:</strong> These are your friends who spread the word. If your content is a party, these folks send the invites to your attendees.</li> \n </ul> \n</div> You could probably think of a dozen more roles that might work better for your business. The point is, find out what works for you and plan how your team will work together to publish the content you need to create. Once you know how many hands you have to help you out, you can plan a realistic publishing frequency the entire team can handle. \n<div class=\"link-callout\"> \n <strong>Recommended Reading:</strong> \n <ul> \n  <li><a href=\"https://coschedule.com/blog/content-marketing-team-structure/\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener noreferrer\">How To Structure Your Marketing Team To Create The Best Content</a></li> \n  <li><a href=\"https://coschedule.com/blog/team-blog/\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener noreferrer\">How To Assemble A Content Marketing Team For Your Blog</a></li> \n </ul> \n</div> \n<h3>Plan a Realistic Publishing Schedule.</h3> You have a ton of ideas; you could try to publish a new blog post every day of the week to tell your story. Is that really possible with the resources you have available? Is that much content in a week really necessary? People don't wake up one day and run a marathon. Runners build up their ability to run long distances over time. They \n<strong>start small and plan</strong> for the large races. Content marketers and bloggers have to do the same thing. For someone brand new to the game, \n<a href=\"https://coschedule.com/blog/how-to-start-a-blog-from-nothing/\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener noreferrer\">this is a great plan for your first six months</a> to help you build up your content marketing endurance. \n<img class=\"alignnone size-full wp-image-84775\" src=\"https://media.coschedule.com/uploads/2020/07/blog-REBPUBLISH-Content-Marketing-Editorial-Calender-Template-11-1.png\" alt=\"\" width=\"1361\" height=\"1127\" /> Your \n<a href=\"https://coschedule.com/blog/publish-more-consistent-content/\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener noreferrer\">publishing frequency</a> is really dependent on the resources you can dedicate to content marketing objectives. Use your editorial calendar to set up a content schedule that you and your team can handle. Follow it. Decide how many blog posts you’ll publish each week, your social media post frequency, and how many larger pieces of content you’ll do each month/year (i.e. videos, ebooks, white papers, etc.). Schedules do a couple of amazing things. They force you to not let \n<a href=\"https://coschedule.com/blog/writers-block/\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener noreferrer\">writers block</a> win, and they guard against content gaps. \n<div class=\"link-callout\">\n <strong>Recommended Reading:</strong> \n <a href=\"https://coschedule.com/blog/publish-more-consistent-content/\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener noreferrer\">How To Publish More Consistent Content That Will Help You Grow A Successful Blog</a>\n</div> \n<h3>Your Organization’s Email Marketing Schedule</h3> You’re most likely sending marketing emails either daily or weekly per list segment. Here are the best times to send those emails (according to 10 studies): \n<img class=\"alignnone wp-image-84702 size-full\" src=\"https://media.coschedule.com/uploads/2020/07/email-timing.png\" alt=\"Finding the best time to send an email.\" width=\"1361\" height=\"1127\" /> \n<div class=\"link-callout\">\n <strong><a href=\"https://coschedule.com/blog/?p=55538#toc\">Back to the Top</a></strong>\n</div> \n<a name=\"getting-started\"></a> \n<h2>Getting Started With Your Editorial Calendar Strategy</h2> If you're going to try and implement an editorial calendar with your team, you will need to express how it will help you grow your traffic and improve your business. This will take you right back to some of the things we discussed earlier in the guide about the business value of content marketing as a whole. Here are some key benefits to communicate: \n<ul> \n <li><strong>Better visibility across projects and campaigns</strong>. Everyone knows when each piece is publishing and who is responsible for it.</li> \n <li><strong>Ability to finally get organized</strong>. Disorganization leads to frustration and lack of productivity.</li> \n <li><strong>Reducing the number of missed deadlines</strong>. No one likes missing deadlines; without a calendar to track them, it happens.</li> \n <li><strong>Spending less time planning and more time executing</strong>. Spending time planning and getting organized eventually saves time.</li> \n</ul> Those are some strong benefits that any marketing team could get behind. \n<h3>Understand Who You're Talking to With Personas</h3> It's cliché to say that you need to understand who your audience is, but it couldn't be more true. Not only do you need to make sure that you understand your audience, but so does your team. A good place to get started would be with some \n<a title=\"Find The Right Target Audience, And Make Writing Easy\" href=\"http://coschedule.com/blog/target-audience/\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener noreferrer\">basic customer profiles</a>&nbsp;or audience personas. \n<img class=\"alignnone size-full wp-image-84776\" src=\"https://media.coschedule.com/uploads/2020/07/blog-REBPUBLISH-Content-Marketing-Editorial-Calender-Template-13-1.png\" alt=\"\" width=\"1361\" height=\"1096\" /> \n<h3>Take an Inventory of Your Team</h3> Who's on your team, and how will each of them be contributing to the end product? This may sound simple, but it's an important question. If there is only one of you on your team, this step may be better spent writing down some of the required tasks, in the order in which you will do them. Here are some roles that'll likely be working off your calendar: \n<ul> \n <li>Writers</li> \n <li>Designers</li> \n <li>Project Managers</li> \n <li>Social Media Managers</li> \n <li>SEO Specialists</li> \n <li>Content Strategists</li> \n</ul> If they're on your marketing team, they can get value from your editorial calendar. \n<h3>Develop a Basic Channel Strategy</h3> Not all content is equal, so you should decide what yours will look like. The basic starting point is usually a WordPress blog, but you might have other channels, like: \n<ul> \n <li>Social media (broken down by network)</li> \n <li>Email marketing</li> \n <li>Video platforms</li> \n <li>Landing pages</li> \n <li>Webinars</li> \n <li>Courses</li> \n</ul> The world of content marketing is vast, and all of it can be planned on your calendar. \n<h3>Find Your Content Core</h3> The content core is the intersection between your brand's purpose and your customer's interests. \n<img class=\"alignnone wp-image-84706 size-full\" src=\"https://media.coschedule.com/uploads/2020/07/what-to-cover.png\" alt=\"What to cover in your content core.\" width=\"1361\" height=\"912\" /> Understanding this will help you plan content that's both: \n<ul> \n <li><strong>Relevant to your audience</strong>. What do they want from you?</li> \n <li><strong>Delivers results for your business</strong>. How will it attract the right audience to your company?</li> \n</ul> \n<h3>How Will You Plan?</h3> Most teams that use content marketing editorial calendars like to have regularly scheduled meetings to plan out their content. Decide if you'll do one of the following: \n<ul> \n <li><strong>Run group brainstorming meetings</strong>. Great ideas can come from anywhere.</li> \n <li><strong>Leave content planning to an editor or strategist</strong>. These folks are closest to the data that will guide you to success.</li> \n <li><strong>A mix of both</strong>. This way, you can take advantage of the pros for each approach.</li> \n</ul> \n<div class=\"link-callout\">\n <strong>Recommended Reading:</strong> \n <a href=\"https://coschedule.com/blog/coschedule-buyers-guide/\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener noreferrer\">How to Overcome Makeshift Marketing: The CoSchedule Buyer's Guide</a>\n</div> \n<div> \n <h3>Map Content to Marketing Funnel Stages</h3> Next, \n <a href=\"https://coschedule.com/blog/marketing-funnel/\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener noreferrer\">map each topic to a marketing funnel stage</a>. You'll need content that fits each of the following stages: \n <ul> \n  <li><strong>Top of funnel</strong>. This is content that broadly interests your audience, but is only loosely connected to your brand. People looking for this content are likely not aware of your company or product yet.</li> \n  <li><strong>Middle of the funnel</strong>. This is content that speaks to potential customers who are considering buying the type of product or service you offer.</li> \n  <li><strong>Bottom of the funnel</strong>. This is content that converts shoppers into customers.</li> \n </ul> Here's what a basic marketing funnel looks like: \n <img class=\"alignnone wp-image-84707 size-full\" src=\"https://media.coschedule.com/uploads/2020/07/marketing-funnel.png\" alt=\"What does the marketing funnel look like?\" width=\"1361\" height=\"1055\" /> The majority of your content will likely be top of the funnel, since these topics typically generate the most interest. However, content increases in value, even as it decreases in volume, the further down the funnel you go. \n <h3><img class=\"alignnone wp-image-84708 size-full\" src=\"https://media.coschedule.com/uploads/2020/07/content-quantity.png\" alt=\"How much content should be at the end of the funnel?\" width=\"1361\" height=\"1198\" /></h3> \n</div> \n<div class=\"link-callout\">\n <strong><a href=\"https://coschedule.com/blog/?p=55538#toc\">Back to the Top</a></strong>\n</div> \n<a name=\"execute\"></a> \n<h2>Execute Your Plan With Your Content Marketing Editorial Calendar</h2> One of the hardest things to do is change. Really, humans are inherently adverse to change. \n<img class=\"alignnone size-full wp-image-84768\" src=\"https://media.coschedule.com/uploads/2020/07/blog-REBPUBLISH-Content-Marketing-Editorial-Calender-Template-16-2.png\" alt=\"\" width=\"1361\" height=\"972\" /> One of the first things you need to do is develop effective habits with your content marketing editorial calendar. You — and I really mean you since you're the one who looked up this post and is reading it — can't be the only one on your team who uses your editorial calendar. These things are a million times better when everyone who's involved uses the same tool to create your content. You need to be the person who helps your team use your editorial calendar. Here's a look at how you can help them develop effective habits: \n<img class=\"alignnone wp-image-84769 size-full\" src=\"https://media.coschedule.com/uploads/2020/07/blog-REBPUBLISH-Content-Marketing-Editorial-Calender-Template-17-1.png\" alt=\"\" width=\"1357\" height=\"889\" /> A great way to develop effective habits is with a recommended-reading-defined workflow. \n<h3>Use a Workflow That Actually Works</h3> It's one thing to throw a post on your editorial calendar. It's another to \n<a href=\"https://coschedule.com/blog/content-marketing-workflow/\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener noreferrer\">assign specific tasks</a> that need to be completed to make sure that post gets published. Remember, content marketing is a team effort. \n<img class=\"alignnone size-full wp-image-84777\" src=\"https://media.coschedule.com/uploads/2020/07/blog-REBPUBLISH-Content-Marketing-Editorial-Calender-Template-18-1.png\" alt=\"\" width=\"1361\" height=\"1629\" /> That's your workflow, and your entire team needs to pitch in to help make it a reality. A clearly defined workflow will help your team communicate more efficiently, and it gives everyone something to be accountable for. You'll all know exactly what you need to do to create awesome content. Sounds complex, right? Thankfully, your marketing team’s workflow doesn’t have to be super difficult. A solid workflow helps you and your entire team: \n<div class=\"alert alert-info\"> \n <ul> \n  <li>Understand the big vision behind what you're doing.</li> \n  <li>Know what each person's role and responsibilities are.</li> \n  <li>Complete specific tasks to create content as a team.</li> \n  <li>Stick to one communication channel.</li> \n  <li>Focus on your own tasks instead of herding cats to get stuff done.</li> \n </ul> \n</div> To implement a workflow that actually works, you and your team need to: \n<div class=\"alert alert-info\"> \n <ul> \n  <li>Figure out exactly what tasks need to be completed for every piece of content you produce.</li> \n  <li>Understand what role would be the best for knocking out each task.</li> \n  <li>Assign those tasks to the people who fill those roles.</li> \n  <li>Assign due dates based on what needs to be done first, second, third, and so on.</li> \n  <li>Hold everyone accountable for getting their stuff done on time.</li> \n </ul> \n</div> Remember that you need to start with a \n<a href=\"https://coschedule.com/blog/publish-more-consistent-content/\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener noreferrer\">realistic publishing frequency</a>. If someone messes up the first couple of times, that's fine! That's why you're there to help them build effective habits for creating content. Work slow to begin with, then ramp up your \n<a href=\"https://coschedule.com/blog/content-creation-process/\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener noreferrer\">content creation</a> machine. \n<div class=\"link-callout\"> \n <strong>Recommended Reading:</strong> \n <ul> \n  <li><a href=\"https://coschedule.com/blog/content-marketing-workflow/\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener noreferrer\">Try This Breakthrough Content Marketing Workflow For Your Team</a></li> \n  <li><a href=\"https://coschedule.com/blog/blogging-workflow/\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener noreferrer\">Finding The Best Blogging Workflow For You And Your Team</a></li> \n </ul> \n</div> \n<h3>Start By Brainstorming Topics and Campaigns</h3> Before you can use your calendar, it needs content. One simple process that's worked well at CoSchedule is to run a \n<a href=\"https://coschedule.com/blog/content-marketing-brainstorming-process/\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener noreferrer\">30-minute content planning session</a>. Here's how the process works: \n<ol> \n <li><strong>Spend ten minutes writing down ideas</strong>. Have each team member jot down ideas on Post-It notes (one idea per note).</li> \n <li><strong>Spend ten minutes scoring those ideas</strong>. Put those ideas up on a board. Read each one out loud. Then, have each team member score them on a three-point scale (3 = Awesome, 2 = Meh, 1 = Dud). You'll end up with ideas that fall into all three categories, and that's okay. This isn't about shaming anyone.</li> \n <li><strong>Spend ten minutes selecting the very best topics</strong>. Take all your ideas that scored mostly 3's, and decide which are the very best. These will go on your calendar.</li> \n</ol> This video offers a more detailed breakdown on how this process works: https://coschedule.wistia.com/medias/awf6gqfh31?embedType=async&amp;videoFoam=true&amp;videoWidth=770 \n<h3>Then, Establish Clear Checklist-Based Workflows to Execute Your Ideas</h3> Figure out which steps are required to create a single piece of content. Then, determine how long each step should take. You can do this easily by first figuring out what needs to be done. Create a list: \n<div class=\"callout\"> \n <ul> \n  <li>Generate an idea.</li> \n  <li>Determine deadline.</li> \n  <li>Do keyword research.</li> \n  <li>Write an outline.</li> \n  <li>Write content.</li> \n  <li>Handoff for graphic design.</li> \n  <li>Review and content.</li> \n  <li>Ensure content is optimized.</li> \n  <li>Write social media posts to promote content.</li> \n  <li>Draft email copy to promote content to your list.</li> \n  <li>Schedule publish date and time.</li> \n </ul> \n</div> That's a hypothetical checklist for a single piece. Next, figure out who is responsible for each step. Now, this list might look like this: \n<div class=\"callout\"> \n <ul> \n  <li>Ideation (team/strategist).</li> \n  <li>Determine deadline (editor/manager).</li> \n  <li>Keyword research (strategist/SEO specialist).</li> \n  <li>Write outline (content writer).</li> \n  <li>Write content (content writer).</li> \n  <li>Design graphics (graphic designer).</li> \n  <li>Review content (content writer/editor/manager).</li> \n  <li>Ensure content is optimized (editor/SEO specialist).</li> \n  <li>Write social media posts (content writer/social media manager).</li> \n  <li>Draft email copy (content writer).</li> \n  <li>Schedule publish date and time (editor/manager).</li> \n </ul> \n</div> These don't necessarily need to be assigned to specific job titles; just tasks or roles different team members may fill, depending on your team size and structure. Now, figure out how long each step should take. Having your team use a time tracking app, like Toggl, can help you estimate this more accurately. To get started, determine how long each task usually takes right now, per step. At this point, the list might look like this: \n<div class=\"callout\"> \n <ul> \n  <li>Ideation (team/strategist – 30 minutes).</li> \n  <li>Determine deadline (editor/manager – 5 minutes).</li> \n  <li>Keyword research (strategist/SEO specialist – 2 hours).</li> \n  <li>Write outline (content writer – 2 hours).</li> \n  <li>Write content (content writer – 8 hours).</li> \n  <li>Design graphics (designer – 4 hours).</li> \n  <li>Review content (writer/editor/manager – 1 hour).</li> \n  <li>Write social media posts (writer/social manager – 1 hour).</li> \n  <li>Draft email copy (content writer – 1 hour).</li> \n  <li>Schedule publish date and time (editor/manager – 5 minutes).</li> \n </ul> \n</div> These times are completely hypothetical, for example purposes only. Next, determine how many work days this entire workflow will fill. Then, add two weeks. That's how far out in advance your content should be placed on your calendar. Finally, map this all out to a checklist your team can use. If you're a CoSchedule customer, this can be done with \n<a href=\"https://help.coschedule.com/hc/en-us/articles/215075408-Create-Task-Templates\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener noreferrer\">Task Templates</a>. These are reusable checklist templates that can be added to each piece of content on the calendar. \n<img class=\"drop-shadow aligncenter wp-image-84756 size-full\" src=\"https://media.coschedule.com/uploads/2020/07/task-template-example.png\" alt=\"\" width=\"1360\" height=\"645\" /> &nbsp; When you click each task, it'll show the whole team that step is complete. This will be reflected by the completion percentage on the calendar. \n<img class=\"drop-shadow aligncenter wp-image-84757 size-full\" src=\"https://media.coschedule.com/uploads/2020/07/task-completion.png\" alt=\"Example of task completion\" width=\"1360\" height=\"255\" /> &nbsp; \n<h2>Write, Design, and Edit Your Content</h2> There are some things your content writer, designer, and proofreader should keep in mind when they create and publish your content. \n<h3>1. Talk About Your Expertise.</h3> What you know best is your expertise. You don’t have to be the expert, but it’s likely you know more than the average person about your niche topic — otherwise you wouldn’t be in business. Therefore, you’re an expert. Let’s put feelings of inferiority aside, or you’ll never write a sentence worth anything to your customers. The beauty of you talking about what you know best is that you create value around your product or service. Would you rather hire a plumber who confidently talks about all things plumbing on his blog, or the guy who just has a website that says, “I’m a plumber. Hire me.”? \n<h3>2. Speak Your Customer’s Language</h3> If you have any empathy for your fellow human beings, leave the jargon at the door, please! If you’re selling light bulbs, you don’t talk about ohms and electrical resistance and how many electric trade associations in which you are a member; you talk about how long the lightbulb will last. Remember, no more corporate voice, meet your audience’s needs — these core concepts ought to prevent you from using jargon or purposefully trying to shame, confuse, or impress a customer with industry language, but it’s so easy to forget! You rattle off features when you could be telling them about the benefits. You’re not looking to be the industry expert — unless your audience is business-to-business — but an expert for your customer. \n<h3>3. Just Focus on the Bennies</h3> People don’t buy a toaster based on how hot the heating elements can get, but that it gets their toast done pretty fast in the morning, so they aren’t late for work. Heating element = feature, fast toast = benefit. When you write your content, talk about benefits, not features. People connect to benefits, because they tell them how your product meets their needs. Features only interest the sellers because they make an impressive list for those in the industry. The content you create has to find a way to translate those awesome features into real-world benefits so your audience can say, “Oh, yes, that would be helpful for me.” \n<h3>4. Yes, You Can Talk About That</h3> There’s a lot of peripheral content connected to what you think is your main focus. Yes, you can talk about that. Let’s say you sell running shoes. You could blog all day about the new shoe styles, shoe sales, shoe trends — you could be very shoe-centric. After all, that’s your gig, but think about your customer. The guy buying those shoes is... a runner. As a runner, he is interested in more than just shoes. He wants to know about running events, training options, the latest running mobile apps, outdoor trails, hydration, knee health… Wouldn’t you sell more shoes if you wrote about all of the things runners are interested in? Your content should definitely include your core content (in this case, the shoes), but also write about connected content (that other stuff). That’s what your audience wants. \n<div class=\"link-callout\"> \n <strong>Recommended Reading:</strong> \n <ul> \n  <li><a href=\"https://coschedule.com/blog/how-to-write-a-blog-post-checklist/\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener noreferrer\">How To Write A Blog Post: Your 5-Point Checklist To Rock A Perfect Post</a></li> \n  <li><a href=\"https://coschedule.com/blog/fun-to-read/\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener noreferrer\">14 Ways To Make Your Blog Content More Fun To Read</a></li> \n  <li><a href=\"https://coschedule.com/blog/non-designers-blog-graphics-guide/\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener noreferrer\">How To Make The Best Blog Graphics (For Non-Designers)</a></li> \n  <li><a href=\"https://coschedule.com/blog/create-great-images-blog-posts/\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener noreferrer\">5 Super Easy Ways To Create Images for Your Blog Posts</a></li> \n  <li><a href=\"https://coschedule.com/blog/editing/\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener noreferrer\">How Much Editing Is Too Much?</a></li> \n </ul> \n</div> \n<h3>Promote Your Content on Social Media</h3> “\n<a href=\"https://coschedule.com/blog/social-media-calendar/\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener noreferrer\">Complete social media content marketing in just an hour a day!</a>” Sounds gimmicky, but it’s not off. Do you really want to be spending more than an hour on tweets and Facebook posts? No. This plan is a tricky one, but returns great results when you get it right. Start by figuring out what your audience wants on each network. For example, five tweets an hour might be too much, and no tweeting after 6 p.m. Don’t give them an excuse to unfollow you. Know your audience, \n<a href=\"https://coschedule.com/blog/how-to-quadruple-your-traffic-with-a-social-media-editorial-calendar/\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener noreferrer\">know the social network’s unwritten etiquette</a>, and use that as your guide. Then, find social media marketing tools that shave time off of your plan. Time is money. Use one or two scheduling tools instead of five and an extra hour. Find good tools and spend the money. They’re going to be a workhorse for you, and you won’t regret an excellent tool that makes this easier. With your plan in place, you now know what happens when a blog post is published. It might go something like this: \n<img class=\"alignnone wp-image-84712 size-full\" src=\"https://media.coschedule.com/uploads/2020/07/timeline.png\" alt=\"Social sharing schedule timeline\" width=\"1361\" height=\"1508\" /> \n<div class=\"link-callout\"> \n <strong>Recommended Reading:</strong> \n <ul> \n  <li><a href=\"https://coschedule.com/blog/how-to-quadruple-your-traffic-with-a-social-media-editorial-calendar/\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener noreferrer\">How To Quadruple Your Traffic With A Social Media Editorial Calendar</a></li> \n  <li><a href=\"https://coschedule.com/blog/promote-your-blog-with-social-media/\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener noreferrer\">How To Promote Your Blog With Social Media</a></li> \n </ul> \n</div> \n<div class=\"link-callout\">\n <strong><a href=\"https://coschedule.com/blog/?p=55538#toc\">Back to the Top</a></strong>\n</div> \n<a name=\"workflow\"></a> \n<h3>Publish</h3> If you're using CoSchedule with the WordPress integration, your post will automatically publish at your specified date and time. If you have social media campaigns and email newsletters promoting your content, you can create and manage those in CoSchedule, too. For those using spreadsheets, you'll need to make sure everything is lined up in your Excel or Google Sheets calendar, your social scheduling tool, and email platform. \n<div class=\"link-callout\">\n <strong>Recommended Reading:</strong> \n <a href=\"https://coschedule.com/blog/marketing-workflow-management/\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener noreferrer\">Marketing Workflow Management: How to Prevent Last-Minute Emergencies</a>\n</div> \n<div class=\"link-callout\">\n <strong><a href=\"https://coschedule.com/blog/?p=55538#toc\">Back to the Top</a></strong>\n</div> \n<a name=\"management\"></a> \n<h2>Managing Your Content Marketing Editorial Calendar</h2> You've decided to take the plunge and start using an editorial calendar for your content marketing. You've made the right call. Not only will you find yourself producing better content, but you'll also become more consistent with your publishing. In turn, it should lead to a steady increase in traffic. As you go, there are six things that you are going to need to keep an eye on at all times. \n<h3>1. What's Happening This Week? What's Happening Next Week?</h3> If you are doing it right, you should have an answer to these questions at all times. How does your calendar make this easier? \n<h3>2. Does Your Team Know What to Do?</h3> Tools like CoSchedule allow you to assign tasks to each member on your team, making communication easier than ever. \n<a href=\"http://coschedule.com/blog/cross-functional-team/\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener noreferrer\">Everyone should know what they are supposed to do</a>&nbsp;and when they are supposed to do it. \n<h3>3. Is There Healthy Communication?</h3> Discussion about a new piece of content and how to make it better should be a normal part of the process. You should have something in place that allows you to have discussions and share thoughts with your team. \n<h3>4. What About the Assets?</h3> Images and graphics can be important elements for great content marketing. Who will be responsible for them, and how will they be assigned? Again, CoSchedule makes this pretty easy with simple tasks that can be assigned to each team member. \n<h3>5. Implementing Editorial Review</h3> At our office, we use a peer review process to improve the quality of our work. Gathering feedback from our peers is a low-cost way to constantly improve the content that we create. Your calendar and editorial plan should accommodate for a step like this. \n<h3>6. Reschedule as Needed</h3> One tip for users of a paper editorial calendar is to use colored sticky-notes rather that just writing on the paper calendar itself. This gives you the same drag-and-drop flexibility that you will find in a tool like CoSchedule. \n<div class=\"link-callout\">\n <strong>Recommended Reading:</strong> \n <a href=\"https://coschedule.com/blog/social-media-posting-schedule/\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener noreferrer\">The Social Media Schedule That Will Boost Your Traffic By 192%</a>\n</div> \n<div class=\"link-callout\">\n <strong><a href=\"https://coschedule.com/blog/?p=55538#toc\">Back to the Top</a></strong>\n</div> \n<h2>Start Creating More Consistent Content Now</h2> Content marketing editorial calendars aren't necessarily new, but you might be surprised at how many people choose to not use them. That's their loss and your advantage. The content marketers who dedicate themselves to \n<a href=\"http://coschedule.com/blog/marketing-calendar/\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener noreferrer\">great planning and content creation</a>&nbsp;will always come out ahead. Good luck! /2020/08/24/21-56-38-546_70dc73c9bd13653f.webp","https://media.coschedule.com/uploads/2020/07/blog-REBPUBLISH-Content-Marketing-Editorial-Calender-Template-10-1-1.png":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx31/cdn4@2020_4/2020/08/24/21-56-33-682_ede1500f3e543f13.webp","https://media.coschedule.com/uploads/2020/07/blog-REBPUBLISH-Content-Marketing-Editorial-Calender-Template-11-1.png":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx18/cdn15@2020_3/2020/08/24/21-56-26-259_08e8835558c4e073.webp","https://media.coschedule.com/uploads/2020/07/email-timing.png":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx/cdn48@2020_3/2020/08/24/21-56-32-031_7d5a451974500438.webp","https://media.coschedule.com/uploads/2020/07/blog-REBPUBLISH-Content-Marketing-Editorial-Calender-Template-13-1.png":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx22/cdn64@2020_5/2020/08/24/21-56-34-165_70f883bb82978a01.webp","https://media.coschedule.com/uploads/2020/07/what-to-cover.png":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx2/cdn12@2020_5/2020/08/24/21-56-33-544_ef6671220aebc23c.webp","https://media.coschedule.com/uploads/2020/07/marketing-funnel.png":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx12/cdn39@2020_6/2020/08/24/21-56-27-048_c6622f0dd76c9c66.webp","https://media.coschedule.com/uploads/2020/07/content-quantity.png":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx24/cdn80@2020_5/2020/08/24/21-56-33-293_460515cda3e3cf8c.webp","https://media.coschedule.com/uploads/2020/07/blog-REBPUBLISH-Content-Marketing-Editorial-Calender-Template-16-2.png":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx7/cdn79@2020_3/2020/08/24/21-56-26-462_5ef0f98f38af51d4.webp","https://media.coschedule.com/uploads/2020/07/blog-REBPUBLISH-Content-Marketing-Editorial-Calender-Template-17-1.png":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx22/cdn4@2020_3/2020/08/24/21-56-28-849_f074ae686a37c072.webp","https://media.coschedule.com/uploads/2020/07/blog-REBPUBLISH-Content-Marketing-Editorial-Calender-Template-18-1.png":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx/cdn4@2020_2/2020/08/24/21-56-37-436_d110103e0ed3d2c0.webp","https://media.coschedule.com/uploads/2020/07/task-template-example.png":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx11/cdn18@2020_6/2020/08/24/21-56-29-756_7e3a67b55bf16493.webp","https://media.coschedule.com/uploads/2020/07/task-completion.png":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx25/cdn83@2020_3/2020/08/24/21-56-30-329_23f73f4b4be53de1.webp","https://media.coschedule.com/uploads/2020/07/timeline.png":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx3/cdn100@2020_4/2020/08/24/21-56-34-535_f17340e8f117d82e.webp"},"publishedOrCreatedDate":1598306169552},{"createdTime":"2020-08-25 05:56:09","updatedTime":"2020-08-25 05:56:09","title":"The Best Way to Write a Creative Brief (With Templates)","link":"https://coschedule.com/blog/?p=47240","description":"<img class=\"alignnone wp-image-85613 size-full\" src=\"https://media.coschedule.com/uploads/2020/08/creative-brief-template-header.png\" alt=\"The best way to write a creative brief with templates (header)\" width=\"1361\" height=\"585\" /> Marketing projects can sometimes be a challenge to \n<a href=\"https://coschedule.com/blog/smash-creative-ruts-by-building-a-rock-solid-collaborative-ideation-process-with-sean-ironside-from-egym-amp-187/\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener noreferrer\">get off the ground</a>. Everyone has a different vision for what the campaign should be, what the creative will look like and what the objectives are. Not doing your prep work on the front-end can mean you might go too far down the wrong path, which means wasted time, lost money, and disgruntled clients. What’s a marketer to do? Create a clear creative brief before the work begins, of course. If this leaves you scratching your head, have no fear. You’ll find everything you need in this post, including a step-by-step process for completing a brief, several examples to follow, and templates to make getting started easy. \n<h2>Three Creative Brief Templates + Your Projects = Success</h2> Start off by downloading our creative brief templates. This kit includes three different templates you can use to write effective creative briefs the easy way (in Word, Excel, and Powerpoint format). Grab ’em below. Then, keep reading to learn how to use them effectively. [Cookie \"Get Your Creative Brief Template Bundle || https://media.coschedule.com/uploads/2020/08/Blog_Build-a-concise-creative-brief-with-free-templates-07.png || Download Bundle || https://media.coschedule.com/uploads/2020/08/Creative-Brief.zip\"] \n<div class=\"link-callout\"> \n <a name=\"toc\"></a>\n <strong>Table of Contents</strong> \n <ul> \n  <li><a href=\"https://coschedule.com/blog/?p=47240#why\">Why You Need a Creative Brief</a></li> \n  <li><a href=\"https://coschedule.com/blog/?p=47240#elements\">Elements of a Great Creative Brief</a></li> \n  <li><a href=\"https://coschedule.com/blog/?p=47240#how\">How to Write a Great Creative Brief</a></li> \n  <li><a href=\"https://coschedule.com/blog/?p=47240#irl\">“IRL” Creative Brief Example</a></li> \n  <li><a href=\"https://coschedule.com/blog/?p=47240#conclusion\">Conclusion</a></li> \n </ul> \n</div> \n<a name=\"why\"></a> \n<h2>Why You Need a Creative Brief</h2> A creative brief helps clarify expectations between your team and the project’s stakeholders. Not having one increases the likelihood of missed deadlines and means a heck of a lot more time wasted on making sure everyone is on the right track. The creative brief serves as the documentation for the project’s objectives and how you’re going to achieve success — the “what” and “how”, essentially. Marketing teams need to focus carefully on ROI to prove our worth. Creativity is often overlooked in this equation. As evidenced by the thrown together creative briefs copied and pasted from old campaigns. \n<img class=\"alignnone wp-image-85614 size-full\" src=\"https://media.coschedule.com/uploads/2020/08/creativity-quote.png\" alt=\"The purpose and impact of creativity\" width=\"1361\" height=\"584\" /> Doesn’t it seem odd that you’re willing to spending a bunch of money on a project, but not spend more than 5 minutes making sure your project is set up for success? \n<img class=\"aligncenter wp-image-65741 size-full\" src=\"https://media.coschedule.com/uploads/creative-brief-slide-deck-08.png\" alt=\"Rejecting a creative brief\" width=\"770\" height=\"484\" /> \n<h3>Reason 1: Define the Scope and Help Avoid Scope-creep</h3> The creative brief says a lot about what the project is, but it also provides insight into what the project isn’t. For example, let’s say your creative brief outlines a project to redesign your website’s blog. &nbsp;The scope of this project is clear; you’re not setting out to re-design any other area of the site. This avoids what we call \n<a href=\"https://www.wrike.com/project-management-guide/faq/what-is-scope-creep-in-project-management/\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener noreferrer\">scope-creep</a>. Scope-creep can be compared to the “might as-wells”. “If we’re redesigning the blog, we ‘might as-well’ redesign the about us pages, too.” This can be especially difficult if your project is on behalf of a client. You, as the project manager, need to make hard decisions about whether you need to adjust the cost and risk the client getting upset, or eat the cost and hurt your profitability. Your creative brief can help you avoid this conundrum. Collaborating with your client or team at the beginning helps prevent misunderstandings about deliverables and gives you a document to reference if scope-creep arises. \n<h3>Reason 2: Clarify the Project’s Timeline</h3> Most projects have a definitive delivery date, so it’s a good idea to include a timeline in your creative brief. Marketing teams juggle multiple projects at once, which means it can be a challenge for individuals to manage everything on their plate. It’s important for Marketing Managers to value their team member’s opinions regarding realistic timelines and workloads. Gain input while formulating the creative brief or use something, like \n<a href=\"https://coschedule.com/?utm_source=google&amp;utm_medium=paid-ppc&amp;utm_campaign=coschedule-success&amp;utm_content=brand-coschedule-known-v2&amp;gclid=EAIaIQobChMI6_fer4WC6wIVD9vACh0HBAJYEAAYASAAEgLNH_D_BwE\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener noreferrer\">CoSchedule’s Team Management Dashboard</a>, to make sure timelines are realistic. \n<h3>Reason 3: Mitigate Confusion and Answer Questions</h3> Have you ever been pulled into a project and felt confused about the who, what, where, when, and why? Or maybe those questions have lingered in your mind throughout the duration of the project? Let’s be honest, we’ve all been a part of a marketing project that has felt a little half-baked. The process of writing the creative brief itself helps you work through strategic questions that may otherwise go unanswered. Likewise, everyone involved in the project will have a clear idea of what’s going on and can understand the project’s reason for existence. Which makes your job as the de facto project manager a lot easier. \n<ul> \n <li>Questions about timeline? Check out the creative brief.</li> \n <li>Questions about target audience? Creative brief.</li> \n <li>Questions about process? You guessed it... creative brief.</li> \n</ul> BOOM. You’ve just saved some time by not having to re-answer the same questions over and over again. \n<div class=\"link-callout\">\n <strong>Recommended Reading:</strong> \n <a href=\"https://coschedule.com/blog/marketing-plan-samples-and-templates/\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener noreferrer\">34 Marketing Plan Samples and 7 Templates to Build Your Strategy</a>\n</div> \n<div class=\"link-callout\">\n <strong><a href=\"https://coschedule.com/blog/?p=47240#toc\">Back to the Top</a></strong>\n</div> \n<a name=\"elements\"></a> \n<h2>Elements of a Great Creative Brief</h2> Creative briefs can vary slightly in what they actually contain. Some opt for more information; others are more condensed. Here’s a running list of items you may consider including in your brief. \n<h3>Project Summary</h3> Describe the project in one or two sentences. Boil it down to the basics. This gives everyone who might come into the project (at any point in time) a high-level understanding of what the project is. It also makes it easier to iterate on the project down the road. \n<blockquote>\n “E-commerce research project intended to attract small business owners wanting to launch their own e-shop.”\n</blockquote> \n<h3>Target Audience</h3> Outline who you’re trying to reach with the campaign. This can be simply a certain user persona or it can be a demographic outline. This is important as it gives the project member an idea of who they’re talking to/ designing for. \n<blockquote>\n “Small business owners and ‘makers’ that are currently selling on \n <a href=\"https://www.etsy.com/?utm_source=google&amp;utm_medium=cpc&amp;utm_term=etsy_e&amp;utm_campaign=Search_US_Brand_GGL_General-Brand_Core_All_HP_Exact&amp;utm_ag=A1&amp;utm_custom1=_kenshoo_clickid_&amp;utm_content=go_227553629_16342445429_310396601160_kwd-1818581752_c_&amp;utm_custom2=227553629&amp;gclid=EAIaIQobChMI1JPU4YeC6wIVTL7ACh36yARWEAAYASAAEgL4lfD_BwE\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener noreferrer\">Etsy</a>, farmer’s markets, etc.”\n</blockquote> \n<h3>Problem</h3> What problem is the project trying to solve? Why do you need to do *this* project? This narrows down why the project exists and why the company needs to do this particular project. \n<blockquote>\n “{Insert company name} is finding it difficult to convince designers, makers, small business owners etc. of the benefits of creating their own webshops rather than selling via Etsy. This report will provide {the company} with original data to use throughout the year and will highlight the benefits of setting up an e-commerce site.”\n</blockquote> \n<h3>Goal<span style=\"font-weight: bold;\">&nbsp;</span></h3> Why are we doing this project? Make sure your goals are measurable and avoid setting too many. Stick to your one metric that matters. \n<blockquote>\n “The primary goal is to increase interest in using {company platform} as the go-to e-commerce platform. This will help position {company name} &nbsp;as the best solution for setting up an e-commerce website. We will create a comprehensive research report that aims to convert 5,000 new paid users by the end of 2019.”\n</blockquote> \n<h3>KPI</h3> How will success be measured? This sets the stage for how you will know if your project was successful or not. It also helps you understand if the project should be repeated. \n<blockquote>\n “This report will be measured based on the number of new accounts generated from gated downloads.”\n</blockquote> \n<h3>Process</h3> What are the general steps we must follow to finish the project? This is a good outline that can become a task template once the project kicks off. It also is a good way for each team member to visualize where they fit into the project. \n<ul> \n <li>Write survey questions</li> \n <li>Distribute survey</li> \n <li>Analyze data</li> \n <li>Write content for the report</li> \n <li>Design PDF</li> \n <li>Prepare promotion strategy</li> \n <li>Measure</li> \n</ul> \n<h3>Individuals/Teams Involved</h3> Who do you need to get this project done? This serves as a reminder to everyone that they need to be involved in order for the project to get off the ground. \n<blockquote>\n “PR, Graphic Design, Social Media, Analytics, Content Marketing, Email Marketing”\n</blockquote> \n<h3>Timeline</h3> What is the due date for this project? Every project needs to have a start and end date… they can’t drag on in perpetuity. This makes it easier for people to plan their workloads and get things finished on time. \n<blockquote>\n “End of Q2 2019”\n</blockquote> \n<h3>Budget</h3> How much can you spend on this project? This can either be a client’s budget or internal resources that are dedicated. You can also think of this in terms of hours devoted to this project. \n<blockquote>\n $25,000\n</blockquote> \n<div class=\"link-callout\">\n <strong><a href=\"https://coschedule.com/blog/?p=47240#toc\">Back to the Top</a></strong>\n</div> \n<a name=\"how\"></a> \n<h2>How to Write a Great Creative Brief</h2> Aside from including the right information, there are a couple things you should also think about when compiling a creative brief. \n<h3>Be Specific</h3> You want your creative brief to clear enough that anyone can understand the project. A vague creative brief will often produce results that fall far short of expectations. When a creative brief misses the necessary specifics, significant revisions often arise which makes for a frustrating process for all involved. \n<h3>Set S.M.A.R.T Goals</h3> Setting S.M.A.R.T goals help put your project on the fast track to success. \n<img class=\"alignnone wp-image-85615 size-full\" src=\"https://media.coschedule.com/uploads/2020/08/creative-brief-smart-goals.png\" alt=\"SMART goals in relation to creative briefs\" width=\"1361\" height=\"689\" /> An example of a S.M.A.R.T goal might be: \n<blockquote>\n We will create a comprehensive research report that aims to convert 5,000 new paid users by the end of 2019.\n</blockquote> The goal is specific by identifying that you want to help drive new paid users. It’s measurable because your team will be able to tell if you hit your 5,000 increase paid users or not. It’s attainable based on previous benchmarking for similar campaigns. The task is relevant because it’s contributing to the company’s bottom line. Finally, the task has a time limit to see if the project was successful or not. \n<h3>The Operative Word is Brief</h3> The creative brief is exactly what it says… brief. It doesn’t need everything and the kitchen sink. Offer an abridged summary that can be easily digested. It shouldn’t be TL;DR. You don’t need to link to a dozen planning spreadsheets, email chains, and related documents. Chances are, those supporting documents won’t even be looked at, so don’t waste your time. \n<img class=\"alignnone wp-image-85616 size-full\" src=\"https://media.coschedule.com/uploads/2020/08/leah-dekrey-brief-quote.png\" alt=\"Leah Dekrey quote about creative briefs\" width=\"1361\" height=\"549\" /> [Tweet \"Creative brief examples to help guide your next project.\"] \n<div class=\"link-callout\">\n <strong><a href=\"https://coschedule.com/blog/?p=47240#toc\">Back to the Top</a></strong>\n</div> \n<a name=\"irl\"></a> \n<h2>Show Me an “IRL” Creative Brief Example</h2> Now that some of the best practice issues have been discussed, let’s jump into a real-life creative brief example. Most creative briefs aren’t distributed externally, so we’re sharing one of our own examples with the world. \n<div>\n <img class=\"alignnone wp-image-85307\" src=\"https://media.coschedule.com/uploads/2020/08/Screen-Shot-2020-08-05-at-12.33.00-PM-770x664.png\" alt=\"Client and project info for creative brief\" width=\"7136070\" height=\"6155408\" />\n</div> \n<div>\n <img class=\"alignnone wp-image-85308\" src=\"https://media.coschedule.com/uploads/2020/08/Screen-Shot-2020-08-05-at-12.33.08-PM.png\" alt=\"Project overview and objective template\" width=\"1360\" height=\"1169\" />\n</div> \n<div>\n <img class=\"alignnone wp-image-85309\" src=\"https://media.coschedule.com/uploads/2020/08/Screen-Shot-2020-08-05-at-12.33.13-PM-770x614.png\" alt=\"Aesthetic and tone template\" width=\"1360\" height=\"1084\" />\n</div> \n<div>\n <img class=\"alignnone wp-image-85310\" src=\"https://media.coschedule.com/uploads/2020/08/Screen-Shot-2020-08-05-at-12.33.23-PM-770x600.png\" alt=\"Requirements, deadlines, and budget\" width=\"1360\" height=\"1060\" />\n</div> \n<div></div> \n<div class=\"link-callout\">\n <strong>Recommended Reading:</strong> \n <a href=\"https://coschedule.com/blog/internal-marketing-strategy-template/\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener noreferrer\">How to Plan an Internal Marketing Strategy That Makes an Impact</a>\n</div> \n<h3>Example 2: <a href=\"https://act-on.com/product/features/automation/?utm_channel=ppc&amp;utm_subchannel=search&amp;utm_medium=cpc&amp;utm_source=google&amp;parentcampaign=&amp;utm_campaign=na%20-%20brand&amp;utm_content=&amp;utm_adgroup=na%20-%20bofu%20-%20brand%20-%20exact&amp;utm_matchtype=e&amp;utm_adid=440744953637&amp;utm_term=act%20on\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener noreferrer\">Act-On</a></h3> \n<img class=\"aligncenter wp-image-65742 size-full\" src=\"https://media.coschedule.com/uploads/creative-brief-slide-deck-09.png\" alt=\"Act-on video creative brief\" width=\"770\" height=\"891\" /> \n<img class=\"aligncenter wp-image-65740 size-full\" src=\"https://media.coschedule.com/uploads/creative-brief-slide-deck-10.png\" alt=\"Further questions from Act-on for creative brief\" width=\"770\" height=\"891\" /> \n<img class=\"aligncenter wp-image-65739 size-full\" src=\"https://media.coschedule.com/uploads/creative-brief-slide-deck-11.png\" alt=\"Last set of questions from Act-on about creative briefs\" width=\"770\" height=\"892\" /> \n<h3>Example 3: <a href=\"https://www.paypal.com/us/webapps/mpp/sem/account-selection-signup?gclid=EAIaIQobChMIlJ34uIyC6wIVg8DACh1FQgdeEAAYASAAEgIW2vD_BwE&amp;gclsrc=aw.ds\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener noreferrer\">PayPal</a></h3> \n<p style=\"text-align: center;\">[slideshare id=10410824&amp;doc=paypalcreativebriefv3-111201013934-phpapp01&amp;type=d]</p> \n<h3>Example 4: Excel Template (Included in Download)</h3> \n<img class=\"aligncenter wp-image-65738 size-full\" src=\"https://media.coschedule.com/uploads/creative-brief-slide-deck-12.png\" alt=\"Excel template for creative brief\" width=\"770\" height=\"932\" /> \n<h3>Example 5: PPT Template (Included in Download)</h3> \n<img class=\"aligncenter wp-image-65750 size-full\" <strong><a href=\"https://coschedule.com/blog/?p=47240#toc\">Back to the Top</a></strong>\n</div> \n<a name=\"conclusion\"></a> \n<h2>All That's Left to Do...</h2> Is get started on your new and improved creative brief process. There isn't any benefit to barreling into a project without a proper plan. Use the provided templates and ideas to ensure you get the most out of your projects, and keep every contributor in the know. \n<div class=\"link-callout\">\n <strong>Recommended Reading:</strong> \n <a href=\"https://coschedule.com/blog/content-marketing-editorial-calendar-template/\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener noreferrer\">The Best Way to Get Organized With a Content Marketing Editorial Calendar (Template)</a>\n</div> \n<em>This post was originally created on January 2, 2019.
