wp-image-84926 size-full\" src=\"https://media.coschedule.com/uploads/2020/07/marketing-department-structure.png\" alt=\"How to Structure Modern Marketing Departments for Success\" width=\"1361\" height=\"585\" />\n\nCould an outdated <strong>marketing department structure</strong> hold you back from success?\n\nIt’s certainly possible. This industry moves fast. In order to keep up, you need the right people, with the <a href=\"https://coschedule.com/blog/marketing-skills/\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener noreferrer\">right skills</a>, doing the right tasks. <a href=\"http://adage.com/article/georgetown-university-school-of-continuing-studies/breakdown-creative-silos-save-marketing/312211/\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener noreferrer\">If silos prevent your team from doing its best work</a>, you could wind up spinning your wheels, without realizing why you’re not moving forward.\n\nUnfortunately, many organizations are <a href=\"https://www.benefitnews.com/news/most-firms-unprepared-for-the-changes-digital-transformation-brings\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener noreferrer\">unprepared to adapt to future changes</a>. Leaders will staff talent skilled in emerging technologies and <a href=\"https://coschedule.com/marketing-strategy/marketing-tactics\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener noreferrer\">tactics</a>, while followers catch up too late,  if at all.\n\nIf your business is going to thrive, both today and in the future, it’s imperative your org chart is built to scale. How can you make sure your company is built for the future of marketing? Start planning now to determine:\n<ul>\n \t<li><em>What skills will you need and who has those skills?</em></li>\n \t<li><em>How will you organize your team for maximum efficiency and success?</em></li>\n \t<li><em>What tools and software do you need to keep everyone in sync?</em></li>\n</ul>\nThis post will help answer those questions and more.\n\n[Tweet \"How to Structure Modern Marketing Departments For Success via @CoSchedule\"]\n<h2>Snag Your Free Marketing Org Chart Template...</h2>\nIt’s easier to achieve success when you can visualize it. Using this template, you can map out your org chart easily to help you and your company see what a successful team structure should look like. This also helps everyone understand their coworkers’ roles and big-picture value.\n\n[Cookie \"Get Your Free Marketing Department Org Chart Template || https://coschedule.com/blog/wp-content/uploads/Org-MU-01.png || Download Now || https://coschedule.com/blog/wp-content/uploads/Marketing-Department-Structure-Org-Chart-Template.xlsx\"]\n<h2>... And Manage Your Marketing Department With the Team Management Dashboard in CoSchedule</h2>\nManaging marketing teams effectively requires the right tools, and there's no better choice than <strong>CoSchedule with Team Management Dashboard</strong>.\n\nThis nifty new tool helps teams:\n<ul>\n \t<li><strong>Coordinate internal resources effectively</strong> to ensure the right team members are working on the right things.</li>\n \t<li><strong>Balance workloads and resource allocation,</strong> so your team can plan ahead without burning out.</li>\n \t<li><strong>Plan project timelines and monitor progress,</strong> so you can plan your work, work your plan, and measure productivity.</li>\n</ul>\nSee what you can do with it:\n\nhttps://coschedule.wistia.com/medias/t5nah1bdsb\n<h2>Why Pay Attention to Team Structure?</h2>\nWith so many competing priorities vying for your attention, what makes this so important?\n\nThe answer is simple: <strong>well-organized teams are better positioned to succeed than ones that aren't</strong>.\n\nHowever, getting it right isn't easy.\n\nWhat if...\n<ul>\n \t<li>You have the right people on the wrong team?</li>\n \t<li>You lack the right teams to support the right people?</li>\n \t<li>The right people can’t communicate because of a communication barrier between teams?</li>\n</ul>\nIf any of the above scenarios are true for your organization, <strong>you’re shortchanging your success</strong>.\n\nFortunately, correcting these issues can have an outsized impact on future success. Not only that, but getting on the track is within your reach.\n\n[Tweet \"A good team structure can have an outsized impact on future success.\"]\n<h2>What Do Common Marketing Team Structures Look Like?</h2>\nThere’s no such thing as an ideal one-size-fits-all team structure.\n\nDifferent models may work better for different organizations and industries. The size of your overall company plays an impact, too.\n\nIf you’ve spent much time searching for examples to follow, odds are you’ve felt overwhelmed. It’s not uncommon to hear advice suggesting you need a dozen roles for one team, and multiple teams spread across your entire marketing department.\n\nThat might make sense for large enterprises with tons of resources, but for the majority of companies, that may not be realistic.\n\nTo simplify things, here are some theoretical examples for companies of different sizes.\n<div class=\"link-callout\"><strong>Recommended Reading:</strong> <a href=\"https://coschedule.com/blog/marketing-file-folder-structure-organizational-system-template/\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener noreferrer\">The Best Way to Organize Marketing Assets With Simple Folder Structures</a></div>\n<h3>Small Business Marketing Team Structure: Lean and Scrappy.</h3>\nIn a small business, odds are you’re hiring one or two people to tackle marketing. If you’re fortunate, you may have three or more.\n\nWhen available talent is this thin, how do you prioritize what these folks should be doing?\n<ul>\n \t<li><span style=\"font-weight: bold;\">Content Creation</span>: Your marketer(s) will need to be able to <a href=\"https://coschedule.com/blog/website-content-template/\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener noreferrer\">update website content</a>, <a href=\"https://coschedule.com/blog/blog-post-templates/\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener noreferrer\">write blog posts</a>, and <a href=\"https://coschedule.com/blog/how-to-use-conversion-psychology-to-get-better-results-with-joanna-wiebe-from-copyhackers-amp080/\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener noreferrer\">craft catchy copy</a> for social media and email.</li>\n \t<li><span style=\"font-weight: bold;\">Graphic Design</span>: <a href=\"https://coschedule.com/blog/non-designers-blog-graphics-guide/\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener noreferrer\">At a minimum</a>, a working knowledge of Photoshop (or, failing that, free design apps like Canva) will be necessary.</li>\n \t<li><span style=\"font-weight: bold;\">Technical Skills</span>: A <a href=\"https://coschedule.com/blog/seo-content-strategy\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener noreferrer\">basic grasp of SEO</a> is likely essential. A general ability to use a content management system (like WordPress) will be useful, too.</li>\n \t<li><span style=\"font-weight: bold;\">Social Media Management</span>: This can easily consume tons of time. (<a href=\"https://coschedule.com/blog/social-media-scheduling-tools/\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener noreferrer\">Scheduling tools can help</a>).</li>\n \t<li><span style=\"font-weight: bold;\">Project Management</span>: How will you keep everything on track?</li>\n</ul>\nThis is just a handful of the different tasks they might be responsible for. What could this look like when its mapped out?\n\n<img class=\"alignnone wp-image-84838 size-full\" src=\"https://media.coschedule.com/uploads/2020/07/team-structure.png\" alt=\"Different elements of small marketing team structures.\" width=\"1361\" height=\"627\" />\n<h3>Mid-Level Marketing Team Structure: Building for Growth.</h3>\nAt this point, your marketing department may have multiple teams.\n\n<img class=\"alignnone wp-image-84839 size-full\" src=\"https://media.coschedule.com/uploads/2020/07/mid-level.png\" alt=\"Mid-level marketing team structures.\" width=\"1361\" height=\"534\" />\n<h3>Enterprise Marketing Team Structure: Specialists With Deep Expertise.</h3>\nLarge companies (200+ employees) may have more layers of management with more specialized teams with deep expertise in specific areas. Here’s a generic example:\n\n<img class=\"alignnone wp-image-84840 size-full\" src=\"https://media.coschedule.com/uploads/2020/07/enterprise.png\" alt=\"Enterprise marketing team structure.\" width=\"1361\" height=\"805\" />\n<h2>Take a Look at Example Marketing Org Charts (Courtesy of HubSpot)</h2>\nSo far, this post has presented a few, general examples. HubSpot did an excellent job <span style=\"text-decoration: underline;\"><a href=\"https://blog.hubspot.com/marketing/team-structure-diagrams\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener noreferrer\">breaking down seven common org structures</a>,</span> along with their respective pros and cons, getting a bit more granular into each one.\n<h3>Functional Org Chart</h3>\nThis example is broken down across business functions. One can assume each spoke under marketing leads to more sub-teams (e.g. content, social, analytics, and so forth). It’s also interesting to note how marketing and sales operate side-by-side. After all, someone has to close deals on the leads marketing generates.\n\n[caption id=\"attachment_84890\" align=\"alignnone\" width=\"1361\"]<img class=\"wp-image-84890 size-full\" src=\"https://media.coschedule.com/uploads/2020/07/functional-chart.png\" alt=\"Functional org chart.\" width=\"1361\" height=\"642\" /> Source: <a href=\"https://blog.hubspot.com/marketing/team-structure-diagrams\">HubSpot</a>[/caption]\n\n[Tweet \"How can you construct a functional marketing org chart?\"]\n<h3>Divisional Org Chart</h3>\nIn this next example, the company is organized based on product-category departments. Each department could presumably have its own marketing team. This type of structure is common at large enterprises that make lots of different types of products. For example, consider a company like Samsung, which produces everything from phones to refrigerators.\n\n[caption id=\"attachment_84891\" align=\"alignnone\" width=\"1361\"]<img class=\"wp-image-84891 size-full\" src=\"https://media.coschedule.com/uploads/2020/07/product-based-1.png\" alt=\"Divisional org chart: product-based.\" width=\"1361\" height=\"714\" /> Source: <a href=\"https://blog.hubspot.com/marketing/team-structure-diagrams\">HubSpot</a>[/caption]\n<h3>Market-Based Org Chart</h3>\nThis example is similar to the previous one, except teams are split up based on customer-centric divisions instead of product-based ones.\n\n[caption id=\"attachment_84892\" align=\"alignnone\" width=\"1361\"]<img class=\"wp-image-84892 size-full\" src=\"https://media.coschedule.com/uploads/2020/07/market-based-1.png\" alt=\"Divisional org chart: market-based.\" width=\"1361\" height=\"710\" /> Source: <a href=\"https://blog.hubspot.com/marketing/team-structure-diagrams\">HubSpot</a>[/caption]\n<h3>Geographical Org Chart</h3>\nFor extremely large enterprises or companies with offices around the world, a geographic org chart, like this one, may make sense. A company with different geographic-based teams within a country might use something similar as well.\n\n[caption id=\"attachment_84893\" align=\"alignnone\" width=\"1361\"]<img class=\"wp-image-84893 size-full\" src=\"https://media.coschedule.com/uploads/2020/07/geographical-1.png\" alt=\"Divisional org chart: geographical.\" width=\"1361\" height=\"754\" /> Source: <a href=\"https://blog.hubspot.com/marketing/team-structure-diagrams\">HubSpot</a>[/caption]\n\n[Tweet \"Is your marketing org chart based on geography and location?\"]\n<h3>Process-Based Org Chart</h3>\nNext up is a process-based structure, where teams are divided up based on where they fit in the production of a product, from ideation all the way through to customer service. In this example, however, it’s unclear exactly where marketing may fit — though content can certainly support all initiatives shown.\n\n[caption id=\"attachment_84894\" align=\"alignnone\" width=\"1361\"]<img class=\"wp-image-84894 size-full\" src=\"https://media.coschedule.com/uploads/2020/07/process-based-1.png\" alt=\"Process-based org chart.\" width=\"1361\" height=\"769\" /> Source: <a href=\"https://blog.hubspot.com/marketing/team-structure-diagrams\">HubSpot</a>[/caption]\n<h3>Matrix Org Chart</h3>\nIf this one reminds you of a certain early 2000s movie series, you’re not alone.\n\nThis example illustrates a different kind of matrix though. It’s similar to some of the examples above, but instead of different divisions having their own marketing teams, the marketing, sales, and service functions all answer to one department head. From there, smaller sub-teams work with each division. It’s a subtle, but important, distinction.\n\n[caption id=\"attachment_84895\" align=\"alignnone\" width=\"1361\"]<img class=\"wp-image-84895 size-full\" src=\"https://media.coschedule.com/uploads/2020/07/matrix-1.png\" alt=\"Matrix org chart.\" width=\"1361\" height=\"969\" /> Source: <a href=\"https://blog.hubspot.com/marketing/team-structure-diagrams\">HubSpot</a>[/caption]\n<h3>Circular Org Chart</h3>\nIn a circular organizational structure, a marketing services department responds to work requests from other areas.\n\n[caption id=\"attachment_84896\" align=\"alignnone\" width=\"1361\"]<img class=\"wp-image-84896 size-full\" src=\"https://media.coschedule.com/uploads/2020/07/circular.png\" alt=\"Circular org chart.\" width=\"1361\" height=\"1105\" /> Source: <a href=\"https://blog.hubspot.com/marketing/team-structure-diagrams\">HubSpot</a>[/caption]\n\n[Tweet \"Have you tried using a circular marketing org structure?\"]\n<h2>Team-Based Org Charts</h2>\nNext, let’s look at what individual teams could look like when mapped out.\n<h3>Content Marketing Team</h3>\nYou don’t need an enormous team to start content marketing, but the work requires lots of different tactics and disciplines, and the more help you have, the better.\n\nWhat can this type of team look like at a large organization? Here’s an example from Hubspot, a company that certainly knows how to do content marketing via <a href=\"http://www.revenify.com/decide-structure-content-marketing-team-marketing-organization/\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener noreferrer\">Revenify</a>:\n\n<img class=\"alignnone wp-image-84897 size-full\" src=\"https://media.coschedule.com/uploads/2020/07/team-chart.png\" alt=\"Content marketing team org chart.\" width=\"1361\" height=\"1618\" />\n<h3>Social Media Team</h3>\nSeem a little complex? This example from <a href=\"http://webershandwickseattle.com/2012/11/a-crash-course-on-social-content-planning/social-content-team-structure-3/\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener noreferrer\">Weber Shandwick</a> takes a more high-level view:\n\n[caption id=\"attachment_85013\" align=\"aligncenter\" width=\"500\"]<img class=\"wp-image-85013 size-full\" src=\"https://media.coschedule.com/uploads/2020/07/Social-Content-Team-Structure2.png\" alt=\"Social media team structure from Weber Shandwick\" width=\"500\" height=\"334\" /> <a href=\"https://webershandwickseattle.com/2012/11/a-crash-course-on-social-content-planning/social-content-team-structure-3/\">Weber Shandwick</a>[/caption]\n\n&#160;\n\n<a href=\"https://www.originoutside.com/insights/what-should-your-social-media-team-look-like\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener noreferrer\">Origin</a> offers another way of looking at your social media team, introducing an analyst role:\n\n[caption id=\"attachment_84899\" align=\"alignnone\" width=\"1361\"]<img class=\"wp-image-84899 size-full\" src=\"https://media.coschedule.com/uploads/2020/07/social-media-roles.png\" alt=\"The different roles that make up a social media team.\" width=\"1361\" height=\"689\" /> <a href=\"https://www.originoutside.com/insights/what-should-your-social-media-team-look-like\">Origin Outside</a>[/caption]\n<h3>Public Relations Team</h3>\nIt’s easy to think of PR as nothing more than media relations, which is a complex discipline unto itself, but this would be a misnomer. Modern public relations is multi-faceted and spans lots of areas, as this illustration of the <a href=\"https://spinsucks.com/peso-model-image/\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener noreferrer\">PESO model from Spin Sucks</a> illustrates:\n\n[caption id=\"attachment_85012\" align=\"aligncenter\" width=\"1360\"]<img class=\"wp-image-85012 size-full\" src=\"https://media.coschedule.com/uploads/2020/07/peso-model-spin-sucks.png\" alt=\"Spin Suck's PESO Model\" width=\"1360\" height=\"771\" /> Source: <a href=\"https://spinsucks.com/peso-model-image/\">Spin Sucks</a>[/caption]\n\n&#160;\n\n[Tweet \"What does your PR team org chart look like?\"]\n\nFollowing this diagram, several staffers would likely divide up work across paid, earned, shared, and owned media strategies. The diagram below, from <span style=\"text-decoration: underline;\"><a href=\"https://www.slideshare.net/MMIAgency/alternative-media-and-public-relations-texas-am-university/16\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener noreferrer\">MMI</a>,</span> breaks down in a bit more detail how a team might be structured:\n\n[slideshare id=56210910&#38;doc=alternativemediaandpublicrelationsfinalsept2015-151216165100]\n<h3>Inbound Marketing Team</h3>\nNow, what about holistic inbound teams that bring paid and organic strategies together, under one roof? Here’s how <span style=\"text-decoration: underline;\"><a href=\"https://www.mojomedialabs.com/blog/what-does-an-ideal-inbound-marketing-team-structure-look-like\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener noreferrer\">Mojo Media Labs</a></span> breaks it down:\n\n[caption id=\"attachment_84902\" align=\"alignnone\" width=\"1361\"]<img class=\"wp-image-84902 size-full\" src=\"https://media.coschedule.com/uploads/2020/07/anatomy.png\" alt=\"The anatomy of the idea inbound marketing team.\" width=\"1361\" height=\"1215\" /> Source: <a href=\"https://resources.mojomedialabs.com/blog/what-does-an-ideal-inbound-marketing-team-structure-look-like\">Mojo Media Labs</a>[/caption]\n<h3>SEO Team</h3>\nSearch engine optimization is interesting because it often spans several teams across an organization. <span style=\"text-decoration: underline;\"><a href=\"https://builtvisible.com/build-a-great-seo-team/\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener noreferrer\">BuiltVisible</a></span> breaks down four different areas a single SEO team needs to cover: technical SEO, content, outreach and off-site SEO (links), and analytics.\n\n[caption id=\"attachment_84903\" align=\"alignnone\" width=\"1361\"]<img class=\"wp-image-84903 size-full\" src=\"https://media.coschedule.com/uploads/2020/07/seo-team.png\" alt=\"The roles that make up an SEO team.\" width=\"1361\" height=\"685\" /> <a href=\"https://builtvisible.com/build-a-great-seo-team/\">Source: BuiltVisible</a>[/caption]\n\n[Tweet \"How should SEO teams be structured?\"]\n\nWhat makes this intriguing?\n\nThe technical aspects may require assistance from a development team. Content might be created by a content team or a separate marketing department — although, SEO should be aligned with marketing. A PR team or specialist might help with link acquisition and other off-site strategies, even if the terms a link builder and a PR pro use may differ according to their goals. Analysts often measure all aspects of a company’s marketing efforts. While this may look like a simple diagram, there’s more than meets the eye.\n<h2>What’s the Problem With Following Someone Else’s Org Chart?</h2>\nIt’s easier to know what to do when you have a good example to follow.\n\nWhen it comes to organizing <em>your</em> marketing department, you have to do what makes the most sense for <em>your</em> company. That may or may not entail following a template down to a T.\n<div class=\"link-callout\"><strong>Recommended Reading:</strong> <a href=\"https://coschedule.com/blog/email-marketing-calendar-template/\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener noreferrer\">The Best Email Marketing Calendar Template You Need to Organize Your Newsletters</a></div>\nCollectively, the examples above illustrate one overarching point: <span style=\"font-weight: bold;\">there are a lot of different types of companies and organizations out there</span>. Different sizes. Different industries. Different teams spread across different departments.\n\nHow can one-size-fit-all recommendations work for your business?\n\nAt best, they may offer either a starting point, or something to compare yourself against. If your current team structure doesn’t work, and it also looks nothing like what’s considered standard, you know where to start diagnosing issues.\n\nWhat will always work best is <span style=\"font-weight: bold;\">figuring out what your specific organization needs to succeed</span>.\n\n[Tweet \"The best marketing org structure is the one that's designed specifically for what your organization needs.\"]\n<h2>How Did CoSchedule Grow Its Marketing Teams?</h2>\nWhen CoSchedule first started, Nathan Ellering (now Head of Demand Generation) was a one-person team. While CEO and co-founder, Garrett Moon, contributed content and guidance, all things marketing were owned by a single staffer.\n\nTalk about a high-pressure environment.\n\nThe upside? Nathan had total creative control and free reign to test what worked and what didn’t. He’d learn a new tactic or get started with a new channel. Then, once he figured it out, another team member would be brought on board to take it over.\n\nEventually, more teams were added to tackle new tasks, each strategically selected to support business growth for a fast-moving startup.\n\n<img class=\"alignnone wp-image-84904 size-full\" src=\"https://media.coschedule.com/uploads/2020/07/demand-generation.png\" alt=\"The &#34;hierarchy&#34; of a content marketing team.\" width=\"1361\" height=\"540\" />\n\nProduct Marketing promotes the CoSchedule product itself:\n\n<img class=\"alignnone wp-image-84905 size-full\" src=\"https://media.coschedule.com/uploads/2020/07/product-marketing.png\" alt=\"The different roles that make up a product marketing team.\" width=\"1361\" height=\"539\" />\n\nWhile Branding and PR helps tell CoSchedule's story to the world:\n\n<img class=\"alignnone wp-image-84906 size-full\" src=\"https://media.coschedule.com/uploads/2020/07/branding.png\" alt=\"The different roles that make up a branding and pr team.\" width=\"1361\" height=\"539\" />\n\n[Tweet \"Is it time to rethink your marketing org chart? See how @Coschedule structures its marketing teams and get inspired:\"]\n<h2>How to Build Your Own Marketing Department</h2>\nThe best marketing team layout is the one you build yourself. A structure that’s tailored to your own needs is going to work better than rigidly sticking to the way things have always been done, or filling roles you think you need because they’re what everyone else is doing.\n<h3>Start With Jobs to Be Done</h3>\nBefore thinking about specific roles, think about the work that needs to be completed.\n\nThis doesn’t necessarily mean figuring out what’s the next hot marketing trend and hiring to fill that gap. <span style=\"font-weight: bold;\">It means figuring out what makes the most sense for your business, and finding talent to fit your own needs</span>.\n\nThat’s what the CoSchedule team did when it started out. The results speak for themselves, and they might not have been attained as easily — had the company followed a traditional hiring pattern.\n\nIn the early days (and even now), CoSchedule leaned heavily on inbound marketing; creating top-notch blog content to attract leads. The strategy was simple:\n<ul>\n \t<li><em>Do basic keyword research.</em></li>\n \t<li><em>Create content answering those queries.</em></li>\n \t<li><em>Promote it via social media and email.</em></li>\n</ul>\nThat’s effective for bringing in an audience, and eventually converting that audience into a paid customer base. It then added product marketers to help sell the product once an audience had been built. Next, a PR team was built out to help manage key relationships, 10X the buzz around the product, and more.\n<div class=\"link-callout\"><strong>Recommended Reading:</strong> <a href=\"https://coschedule.com/blog/10x-marketing-growth-formula/\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener noreferrer\">The Best Formula for 10X Marketing Growth is Here</a></div>\n<h3>Research Your Industry</h3>\nYour competition got where they are somehow. Copying them isn’t necessarily a recipe for duplicating success, but studying them might give you ideas on which roles you need to hire.\n\nStart by searching names and job titles on LinkedIn. Enter a company of similar size to your own, one you admire, or perhaps a competitor, into the search bar:\n\n<img class=\"aligncenter wp-image-58511 size-full\" src=\"https://media.coschedule.com/uploads/Blog_Structure-marketing-15.png\" alt=\"Research CoSchedule on LinkedIn.\" width=\"770\" height=\"201\" />\n\nNext, scroll through the results to find <span style=\"font-weight: bold;\">Job Titles</span>:\n\n<img class=\"aligncenter wp-image-58510 size-full\" src=\"https://media.coschedule.com/uploads/Blog_Structure-marketing-14.png\" alt=\"Searching CoSchedule job titles.\" width=\"770\" height=\"477\" />\n\nThen, build a spreadsheet mapping out roles you find and where they might logically fit:\n\n<img class=\"aligncenter wp-image-58509 size-full\" src=\"https://media.coschedule.com/uploads/Blog_Structure-marketing-13.png\" alt=\"Spreadsheet org chart to be filled in with the different roles at CoSchedule.\" width=\"770\" height=\"272\" />\n\nThis can help you sketch out a loose idea of how a marketing department like yours might be structured. You might also reveal roles or opportunities you hadn’t considered before.\n<div class=\"link-callout\"><strong>Recommended Reading:</strong> <a href=\"https://coschedule.com/blog/marketing-research-process/\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener noreferrer\">The Marketing Research Process That Will Take Your Content to the Next Level</a></div>\n<h3>Determine the Most Important Work That Will Make the Most Impact</h3>\nCoSchedule focuses on 10X marketing.\n\nThis means <a href=\"https://coschedule.com/blog/getting-10x-results-from-your-content-with-garrett-moon-of-coschedule-amp076/\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener noreferrer\">prioritizing projects that deliver 10X improvements</a>, rather than 10% improvements. It has allowed the company to grow immensely and guides how decisions get made.\n\nThe goal: <span style=\"font-weight: bold;\">figure out the <a href=\"https://coschedule.com/marketing-strategy/marketing-channels/\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener noreferrer\">channels</a>, <a href=\"https://coschedule.com/marketing-strategy/marketing-tactics/\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener noreferrer\">tactics</a>, and <a href=\"https://coschedule.com/marketing-strategy/\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener noreferrer\">strategies</a> that will contribute to 10X business growth</span>.\n\nAny marketer or team can follow a similar framework for determining which roles should be filled first. <a href=\"https://coschedule.com/blog/10x-marketing-growth-formula/\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener noreferrer\">Here’s a brief explanation of how it works</a> from our CEO Garrett Moon:\n\nhttps://coschedule.wistia.com/medias/ec86m1i4zf?embedType=async&#38;videoFoam=true&#38;videoWidth=770\n<div class=\"link-callout\"><strong>Recommended Reading:</strong> <a href=\"https://coschedule.com/blog/seo-traffic-generation/\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener noreferrer\">SEO Traffic Generation: How to Boost Your Organic Search Traffic</a></div>\n<h3>Prioritize Channels</h3>\nHere are some findings from a survey conducted by Get Response:\n\n<img class=\"aligncenter wp-image-58508 size-full\" src=\"https://media.coschedule.com/uploads/Blog_Structure-marketing-12.png\" alt=\"Survey through Get Response about digital marketing channels.\" width=\"770\" height=\"607\" />\n<h3>Determine the Roles That Fit Each Channel</h3>\nBroadly speaking, which roles will own which tactics and channels?\n\nSome channels might touch multiple teams (e.g. customer service, PR, and content might all use social media for different purposes).\n<h3>Determine the Tasks in Which Each Role Should Be Responsible</h3>\nYou know what needs to be done. Now, who will own which tasks?\n\nThis ties back into your \"Jobs to be Done\". For each job or task, list the steps required to complete it. Here’s an example of what this might look like for creating a blog post:\n<ol>\n \t<li><em>Generate an idea.</em></li>\n \t<li><em>Do keyword research.</em></li>\n \t<li><em>Write an outline.</em></li>\n \t<li><em>Execute post based on outline.</em></li>\n \t<li><em>Design visual content.</em></li>\n \t<li><em>Editing and review.</em></li>\n \t<li><em>Schedule on editorial calendar.</em></li>\n \t<li><em>Measure performance.</em></li>\n</ol>\nEach of these tasks could fall onto different team members:\n<ul>\n \t<li><em>Ideation and writing execution might fall onto content marketing.</em></li>\n \t<li><em>Keyword research might, too, if the organization doesn’t have a dedicated SEO specialist.</em></li>\n \t<li><em>A graphic designer would be best for creating stunning visual content.</em></li>\n \t<li><em>An editor or manager would need to review and schedule content.</em></li>\n \t<li><em>If a team has a dedicated analyst or analytics team, they’d own measuring performance and extracting actionable insights from data.</em></li>\n</ul>\nBeyond knowing what you need done, understand what it will take to complete the work effectively. Then, hire accordingly, and divide tasks between the team members best suited to handle each one.\n<div class=\"callout\"><strong>Do This With CoSchedule:</strong> Task Templates are reusable checklists you can build directly into your marketing management platform with CoSchedule. <span style=\"text-decoration: underline;\"><a href=\"https://help.coschedule.com/hc/en-us/articles/215075408-Create-Task-Templates\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener noreferrer\">See how they work</a></span>.</div>\n<h3>Find the Best Talent</h3>\nSports teams sometimes draft talent using what’s called a “best available player” approach. This means that regardless of current talent gaps on their roster, they’ll take the best overall players they can find. Then, they’ll strategize on how to make the best use of those players. It’s all about doubling down on strengths and finding ways to mitigate weaknesses, if they can’t be eliminated completely.\n\nBusinesses often do something similar, where they’ll make room for talented team members, even if they weren’t initially hiring for their role.\n\nWhere can you find these folks? Consider the following places:\n<ul>\n \t<li><span style=\"font-weight: bold;\">Networking Events</span>: Are there any relevant professional groups or marketing meetups in your area?</li>\n \t<li><span style=\"font-weight: bold;\">Conferences</span>: Large marketing conferences, like Inbound and Content Marketing World, may be great places to find talent.</li>\n \t<li><span style=\"font-weight: bold;\">Social Media</span>: Reach out to your network for referrals. Someone you know might pass along your next great hire. Be sure to post about job opportunities on LinkedIn, or even consider doing some cold outreach to promising prospects you find.</li>\n</ul>\n<div class=\"callout\">\n\n<strong>Looking to find the best talent in your area or beyond? Use these resources:</strong>\n<ul>\n \t<li><span style=\"text-decoration: underline;\"><a href=\"https://www.indeed.com/\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener noreferrer\">Indeed</a></span></li>\n \t<li><span style=\"text-decoration: underline;\"><a href=\"https://www.workable.com/\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener noreferrer\">Workable</a></span></li>\n \t<li><span style=\"text-decoration: underline;\"><a href=\"https://www.jobvite.com/\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener noreferrer\">Jobvite</a></span></li>\n</ul>\n</div>\n<h3>Group Talent Into Logical Teams</h3>\nAs you add staff and roles, you may find different people fit better on different teams.\n\nNow, here’s the kicker: <span style=\"font-weight: bold;\">your org chart might not look exactly like anyone else’s</span>.\n\nYou’re not your competition, so why be beholden to copying a rigid structure, when you could custom tailor your own talent to your own needs?\n\nTake this as permission to put people where they’re best suited to succeed, not where a chart says they have to be.\n\n[Tweet \"When planning marketing team structures, put people where they're best suited to succeed, not where a chart says so.\"]\n<h3>Add More Capabilities as You Grow</h3>\nThe more your business grows, the more complex your needs may become.\n\nIf you start small with a generalist marketing team, you may find certain areas or tasks drive particularly strong results, or you might not be able to execute certain tactics, without specialized help.\n\nIn either case, you may be in the position to do one of the following:\n<ul>\n \t<li><span style=\"font-weight: bold;\">Add another hire with the skills you need</span>. They might be rolled into your marketing team, or act as a team of one until additional hires are brought on board.</li>\n \t<li><span style=\"font-weight: bold;\">Build another team in your department to focus on a particular area</span>. For example, you might add dedicated analytics or a marketing project management team.</li>\n \t<li><span style=\"font-weight: bold;\">Hire an agency</span>: Sometimes, it’s best to partner with an agency for external expertise. This guide, from TeamWork, provides insight for when to go <span style=\"text-decoration: underline;\"><a href=\"https://blog.teamwork.com/agency-vs-in-house-marketing/\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener noreferrer\">in-house vs. hiring outside help</a></span>.</li>\n</ul>\n<h2>Training Marketing Teams With CoSchedule Academy</h2>\nTeams of all sizes need the right marketing knowledge to manage team projects effectively. <span style=\"font-weight: 400;\">Take your learning up a notch. Unlock 30+ exclusive courses packed with premium content.</span>\n\nJoin <a href=\"https://academy.coschedule.com/p/academy-pro\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener noreferrer\">Academy Pro</a>.\n\nhttps://www.youtube.com/watch?v=W5yz_ZbMmrs\n\nWhat exactly can you do in Academy Pro?\n\nThere are a variety of courses in the academy that will help you expand your marketing knowledge.\n\n<span style=\"font-weight: 400;\">Academy students complete thousands of courses every month. Check out our most popular courses:</span>\n<ul>\n \t<li><span style=\"font-weight: 400;\">Marketing Plan </span></li>\n \t<li><span style=\"font-weight: 400;\">Marketing Ideas </span></li>\n \t<li><span style=\"font-weight: 400;\">Blog Growth </span></li>\n \t<li><span style=\"font-weight: 400;\">Social Media Posting Schedule</span></li>\n</ul>\nIn short, CoSchedule is mission control for your entire marketing department. More than a simple content scheduling tool, it’s an entire platform for managing marketing teams and workflows. Cost: $497 \n<h3>7. Conversion Copywriting 101 (Copyhackers)</h3> \n<img class=\"drop-shadow alignnone\" src=\"https://media.coschedule.com/uploads/2020/08/40ccab7a-1364-43d5-ae04-3d1f2617ee17_pasted20image200.png\" alt=\"Conversion Copywriting 101 from CopyHackers.\" width=\"901\" height=\"1016\" /> Folks at Copyhackers don’t really need an introduction, so when there’s a chance to learn copywriting from them for free, you better take it! In this \n<span style=\"text-decoration: underline;\"><a href=\"https://school.copyhackers.com/courses/conversion-copywriting-101\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener noreferrer\">Conversion Copywriting 101</a></span>&nbsp;course, you’ll get the hang of all facets of copywriting for conversions. Think: value proposition, awareness stages, page goals, formatting, headlines, testimonials, opt-ins, email campaigns, and search advertising tips. Cost: Free \n<h3>8. Copywriting For Beginners (Skillshare)</h3> \n<img class=\"drop-shadow alignnone\" src=\"https://media.coschedule.com/uploads/2020/08/8a4711c8-6f59-45b7-8ccc-1e9143ab8d4a_pasted20image200.png\" alt=\"Skillshare's copywriting for beginners course.\" width=\"1311\" height=\"627\" /> \n<span style=\"text-decoration: underline;\"><a href=\"https://www.skillshare.com/classes/Copywriting-For-Beginners-How-To-Write-Web-Copy-That-Sells-Without-Being-Cheesy/627184083?via=browse-rating-copywriting-layout-grid\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener noreferrer\">Copywriting For Beginners</a></span>&nbsp;is an hour-long Skillshare course that helps you write in a way that cuts through the noise. \n<div class=\"link-callout\">\n <strong>Recommended Reading:</strong> \n <a href=\"https://coschedule.com/blog/marketing-project-management-skills/\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener noreferrer\">8 Marketing Project Management Skills You Need to Lead a Successful Team</a>\n</div> In 17 bite-sized videos, you’ll learn how to write headlines, subheadings, CTA copy, testimonials, and more in order to build trust with your audience. You’ll also get to brush up on copywriting essentials. The class project worksheet gives you fill-in-the-blanks writing templates, so you can write your headlines and share them on the class dashboard for feedback and encouragement. Cost: This course is part of Skillshare Premium — $15/month or $99/year, 14-day free trial available \n<h3>9. Content Writing Masterclass (Copyblogger)</h3> \n<img class=\"drop-shadow alignnone\" src=\"https://media.coschedule.com/uploads/2020/08/ff8adccd-7eb0-4d46-8e79-61d67d296845_pasted20image200.png\" alt=\"Content writing masterclass from Copybloggers.\" width=\"1069\" height=\"714\" /> This recorded \n<span style=\"text-decoration: underline;\"><a href=\"https://copyblogger.com/masterclass-content-writing/\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener noreferrer\">Content Writing Masterclass</a></span> workshop will give you in-depth techniques for writing that builds an engaged audience ready to buy. You’ll master crafting impactful drafts, faster writing, the editing process, and fixing dull writing, so you can differentiate yourself from your competitors. This isn’t a course to collect dust in your digital library — you’ll get specific instructions you can implement in your writing the same day. Cost: $149 \n<h3>10. Copywriting Basics (Kopywriting Kourse)</h3> \n<img class=\"drop-shadow alignnone\" src=\"https://media.coschedule.com/uploads/2020/08/a554342c-d76c-47f6-bf8d-7dcc1cc99585_pasted20image200.png\" alt=\"Copywriting Basics from Kopywriting Kourse.\" width=\"767\" height=\"662\" /> If you feel like there’s never enough time for learning, you’ll love this \n<span style=\"text-decoration: underline;\"><a href=\"https://kopywritingkourse.com/free-copywriting-course/\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener noreferrer\">free copywriting course</a></span>. You only need about half an hour to go through the videos. With them, you’ll get additional templates, resources, checklists, and books to dive deeper into specific topics. Learn how to use the AIDA formula, write about benefits instead of features, and write like you talk. Cost: Free \n<div class=\"link-callout\">\n <strong><a href=\"https://coschedule.com/?p=84289#toc\">Back to the Top</a></strong>\n</div> \n<a name=\"seo\"></a> \n<h2>SEO Courses</h2> In this list of SEO courses, there’s something for any level of SEO knowledge: \n<ul> \n <li>Search Engine Optimization Starter Guide (Google)</li> \n <li>SEO and Content Marketing (CoSchedule Academy)</li> \n <li>SEO Specialization (Coursera / UC Davis)</li> \n <li>Moz Academy (Moz)</li> \n <li>Online SEO Training (Yoast)</li> \n</ul> \n<h3>11. You’ll get a framework to follow, so you can improve your marketing efforts and align every project and campaign with your business goals and aspirations. Cost: Part of a paid plan, $XX/month or $XXX/year, all plans come with a 7-day trial for $1 \n<h3>35. Project Management Training (DPM)</h3> \n<img class=\"drop-shadow alignnone\" src=\"https://media.coschedule.com/uploads/2020/08/418f6f1b-552a-4129-a482-4bddcaa0b561_pasted20image200.png\" alt=\"DPM project management training.\" width=\"1338\" height=\"399\" /> Gain control of your projects with the \n<span style=\"text-decoration: underline;\"><a href=\"https://thedigitalprojectmanager.com/project-management-training/\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener noreferrer\">project management training</a>,</span>&nbsp;by the Digital Project Manager. You’ll start your seven-week learning process by defining your role, tools, and approach. You’ll work your way towards project kick-off, timelines, and estimates. You’ll also learn how to create functional statements of work and deal with challenges that come your way during the project. Higher tiers of the course also give you access to panel discussions, templates, office hours, and coaching. Cost: From $750 to $2,450 for one-year course access \n<div class=\"link-callout\">\n <strong><a href=\"https://coschedule.com/?p=84289#toc\">Back to the Top</a></strong>\n</div> \n<a name=\"conclusion\"></a> \n<h2>Future-Proof Your Marketing Career</h2> With these online marketing courses, you’ll always be equipped with the best tools, strategies, and processes to hit your goals. If you’re looking for an all-in-one hub of courses that will help you stay competitive and drive results, check out \n<span style=\"text-decoration: underline;\"><a href=\"https://coschedule.com/academy\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener noreferrer\">CoSchedule Academy</a></span>. Use it to power up your entire marketing process, from idea brainstorming, to campaign planning, and much more. \n<div class=\"link-callout\">\n <strong>Recommended Reading:</strong> \n <a Examples)</a>\n</div>\n<p>The post <a rel=\"nofollow\" href=\"https://coschedule.com/blog/online-marketing-courses-guides/\">35 Online Marketing Courses and Guides to Grow Your Career Right Now</a> 0/08/35cca658-5d1d-4212-94da-dabe0a86f1ea_pasted20image200.png":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx12/cdn99@2020_3/2020/08/24/21-56-32-632_5c356051f29f8fc4.webp","https://media.coschedule.com/uploads/2020/08/9acd4a39-b329-454b-9650-d4d518b24ab2_pasted20image200.png":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx22/cdn8@2020_6/2020/08/24/21-56-39-707_c037599f70d6c980.webp","https://media.coschedule.com/uploads/2020/08/75468183-5bee-4b51-9c9a-f76875445062_pasted20image200.png":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx/cdn36@2020_4/2020/08/24/21-56-30-819_b62ebb5120245688.webp","https://media.coschedule.com/uploads/2020/08/835ac51f-51ca-4c28-a8a1-ccebebd78938_pasted20image200.png":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx13/cdn11@2020_5/2020/08/24/21-56-27-594_b133df1a377f8b61.webp","https://media.coschedule.com/uploads/2020/08/172bc721-a3e5-4c1e-b34e-4b73ee82375f_pasted20image200.png":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx7/cdn3@2020_4/2020/08/24/21-56-38-160_d5a94b3ec94af7bb.webp","https://media.coschedule.com/uploads/2020/08/7b6f8229-6fe2-4108-a38b-e75894a692b0_pasted20image200.png":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx32/cdn59@2020_6/2020/08/24/21-56-25-223_1c04d947a72d7bbd.webp","https://media.coschedule.com/uploads/2020/08/2d2e82e2-63b2-49cb-b6d1-1fd9998e94de_pasted20image200.png":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx8/cdn48@2020_4/2020/08/24/21-56-35-810_6711c09898eebbc8.webp","https://media.coschedule.com/uploads/2020/08/ab77ed51-3745-4214-a011-3050598dff49_pasted20image200.png":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx22/cdn20@2020_6/2020/08/24/21-56-39-590_a5bc04c024bdab50.webp","https://media.coschedule.com/uploads/2020/08/ec044e84-4531-471b-92c6-0e0c9bd8fe08_pasted20image200.png":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx5oss/cdn15@2020_6/2020/08/24/21-56-28-785_408ed79947e1a4fc.webp","https://media.coschedule.com/uploads/2020/08/4ee4f1d8-112c-4b04-99b5-90b3b0402bcc_pasted20image200.png":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx27/cdn23@2020_6/2020/08/24/21-56-27-964_ca786df4c13bcba2.webp","https://media.coschedule.com/uploads/2020/08/00a0002b-3aef-4888-8492-af4dee97c99b_pasted20image200.png":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx/cdn72@2020_5/2020/08/24/21-56-34-103_e0a7aef9ac1f3520.webp","https://media.coschedule.com/uploads/2020/08/fef1f786-6d00-4236-b63e-4099d09130f1_pasted20image200.png":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx6/cdn47@2020_5/2020/08/24/21-56-26-554_e88a45735e62895e.webp","https://media.coschedule.com/uploads/2020/08/blog-35-Online-Marketing-Courses-to-Grow-Your-Career-Right-Now-11.png":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx31/cdn48@2020_6/2020/08/24/21-56-28-440_bcf209db0196b770.webp","https://media.coschedule.com/uploads/2020/08/44bb3316-7203-4a28-a7c9-eb6b8fd5cc79_pasted20image200.png":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx22/cdn32@2020_4/2020/08/24/21-56-40-595_18bf3e81de910ea1.webp","https://media.coschedule.com/uploads/2020/08/f664fdc0-5a5d-49cd-a4d6-08218bfff42f_pasted20image200.png":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx30/cdn95@2020_6/2020/08/24/21-56-25-672_89b165a192ead9cf.webp","https://media.coschedule.com/uploads/2020/08/418f6f1b-552a-4129-a482-4bddcaa0b561_pasted20image200.png":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx8/cdn72@2020_1/2020/08/24/21-56-38-207_70b85e08c5b6b7ac.webp"},"publishedOrCreatedDate":1598306169466},{"createdTime":"2020-08-25 05:56:09","updatedTime":"2020-08-25 05:56:09","title":"The Two Things Every Remote Marketing Team Needs to Succeed (And How to Bring Them Together) With Lars Helgeson From GreenRope [AMP 195]","link":"https://coschedule.com/?p=84201","description":"<img class=\"alignnone size-full wp-image-84983\" src=\"https://media.coschedule.com/uploads/2020/07/195_Lars-Podcast-Graphics_header.png\" alt=\"\" width=\"1361\" height=\"581\" />\n\nHow can you make remote work actually work? The right technology stack and the right processes to work from home on a distributed team.\n\nToday’s guest is Lars Helgeson from GreenRope. Based on Lars’ two decades of 100% remote work experience, he offers simple and practical advice to pair technology with  processes that establish a solid, remote-working foundation.\n\n[podcast_motor_player]\n\n<strong>Some of the highlights of the show include:</strong>\n<ul>\n \t<li>GreenRope: CRM/marketing automation software in single, unified platform</li>\n \t<li>Simplify Complexity: Successfully scale company by shifting toward remote work</li>\n \t<li>Advantages: Freedom and flexibility to work when and where you want</li>\n \t<li>Disadvantages: Not ideal for those needing space, structure, and office/cubicle</li>\n \t<li>Remote Work Necessities: Internet connection and quiet workspace</li>\n \t<li>Focus: What do you need to get work done? Requirements and right tools</li>\n \t<li>Data: How to create and distribute it to hold people accountable?</li>\n \t<li>Processes: Manage, control, understand, and document how people do things</li>\n \t<li>Structure: People need to have structure and know what they’re working toward</li>\n \t<li>Key to Success: Solid CRM that has all data fully integrated, built into platform</li>\n \t<li>Work-from-Home Policies: Mistakes made due to lack of structure and planning</li>\n</ul>\n<div class=\"link-callout\">\n\n<strong>Links:</strong>\n<ul>\n \t<li><a href=\"https://www.greenrope.com/\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener noreferrer\">GreenRope</a></li>\n \t<li><a href=\"https://zoom.us/\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener noreferrer\">Zoom</a></li>\n \t<li><a href=\"https://apps.apple.com/us/app/facetime/id1110145091\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener noreferrer\">FaceTime</a></li>\n \t<li><a href=\"https://www.gotomeeting.com/\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener noreferrer\">GoToMeeting</a></li>\n \t<li><a href=\"https://www.microsoft.com/en/microsoft-365/microsoft-teams/group-chat-software\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener noreferrer\">Microsoft Teams</a></li>\n \t<li><a href=\"https://www.linkedin.com/in/ben-sailer-b05a9528\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener noreferrer\">Ben Sailer on LinkedIn</a></li>\n \t<li><a href=\"https://coschedule.com/\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener noreferrer\">CoSchedule</a></li>\n</ul>\n</div>\nIf you liked today’s show, <a href=\"https://itunes.apple.com/us/podcast/actionable-content-marketing/id1162659795\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener noreferrer\">please subscribe on iTunes</a> to The Actionable Content Marketing Podcast! The podcast is also available on <a href=\"https://soundcloud.com/coschedule\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener noreferrer\">SoundCloud,</a> <a href=\"http://www.stitcher.com/s?fid=101560&#38;;refid=stpr\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener noreferrer\">Stitcher</a>, and <a href=\"https://goo.gl/app/playmusic?ibi=com.google.PlayMusic&#38;;isi=691797987&#38;ius=googleplaymusic&#38;link=https://play.google.com/music/m/Iks7nu4sb6gquwxy3purzwlitga?t%3DActionable_Content_Marketing\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener noreferrer\">Google Play</a>.\n<div class=\"link-callout\">\n\n<strong>Quotes:</strong>\n<ul>\n \t<li>“Remote work isn't for everybody.”</li>\n \t<li>“Usually, the big part is the integration of that data. If you have no disciplined process to do that, you're going to end up with a spaghetti mess of chaos.”</li>\n \t<li>“It's good to have people involved in some way to feel that interpersonal connection in the business.”</li>\n</ul>\n</div>\n[Tweet \"Two things every remote marketing team needs to succeed, and how to bring them together with @larshelgeson from @GreenRope.\"]\n<h2><strong>Transcript:</strong></h2>\nBen: Hi, Lars. Welcome to the show.\n\nLars: Thanks for having me, Ben.\n\nBen: Absolutely. Would you mind taking a moment to introduce yourself and explain what your team does over at GreenRope?\n\nLars: Sure. We are a CRM and marketing automation software platform. We help customers of all sizes, businesses of all sizes, non-profits, government, organizations with sales, marketing, customer service, project management, event management, knowledge management, and learning management all in a single unified platform.\n\nWe've been around for about 20 years and have grown organically. We've never taken any seed funding. Currently, we have about 1000 customers in 40 countries and are slowly growing organically. Just happy to be here, shed some light on remote work, and how the right software tools can help businesses scale.\n\nBen: Absolutely. Are you 100% remote or do you have some office location?\n\nLars: We have been 100% remote since the very beginning.\n\nBen: Very cool. Having been all remote for two decades now, I feel like you're a bit ahead of the curve relative to the development of remote work becoming more common, certainly in the technology industry. What would you say are some of the benefits of working remotely and having a fully distributed team?\n\nLars: I came out of the military and am working in the government. Back in those days, which was a long time ago, there were a lot of cubicle farms there. I'm sure that at some point, some of us have been in the prairie doggie thing where somebody says let’s dance up in a cubicle.\n\nI think one of the big advantages of working remotely is that you have the freedom and the flexibility to work when and where you want. The key is not everybody can do it. There are some people who love to go into an office and they want to be in a cubicle. They want their space. Sometimes, it's because they want to get away from their home or their family. Sometimes, they need the structure. So, remote work isn't for everybody.\n\n<img class=\"alignnone size-full wp-image-84984\" src=\"https://media.coschedule.com/uploads/2020/07/195_Lars-Podcast-Graphics_quote-03.png\" alt=\"\" width=\"1361\" height=\"630\" />\n\nI think for those who want that freedom, who want that flexibility, the freedom to be able to work from anywhere is so liberating in how you can choose to live your life. If you can do your job remotely, that means that you can be on the road somewhere. You can travel. You can be in another country. Or you can just be home and be with your dogs or your family if that's what you want.\n\nUsually, the biggest requirement is that you have a good internet connection and you have a quiet workspace. As long as you can get those things, you can be working in the back of your car at a campsite somewhere. You can be working in a coffee shop somewhere, in some foreign country. You can be anywhere. As I said, it's not for everybody but if you can embrace that, that freedom, schedule your life around that, have the freedom and the self-discipline to do it, it's life-changing.\n\nI could not go back to working in a cubicle. I couldn't do it. Once you have the taste of freedom, how could anyone go back to that? I'm sure there are people who do, but I have a hard time identifying that. I really enjoy the freedom.\n\nBen: Yeah, just getting out of the office space-esque cubicle farm-type environment. Something that you touched on that's really important is that it's not for everyone. But with the advent of the pandemic, a lot of people are forced to work remotely. They are forced to work remotely whether or not they feel that's how they work best. It's not a choice for a lot of people. It's also forced a lot of companies to have to very quickly readapt the way that they work in order to facilitate an entire mode of operating that they were (maybe) never prepared for before.\n\nWith that in mind, let's say that if I'm a marketing manager and I'm in a situation where, as of three months ago, I've had to manage a marketing team remotely, and we were previously in an office location, what would be the single most important thing that you would advise that person to focus on in order for them to help their teams stay focused?\n\nLars: Whenever I talk to any business about how to use technology, how to manage what needs to be done, the thing that I always come back to is understanding the requirements, knowing what has to get done. Most marketing departments, you've got some creative that needs to get done. You have some account management work that has to get done. You have to deploy whether you're posting in social media, whether you’re launching your website, landing pages, ads, whatever. You have to have the tools to have all that together.\n\nI think the main thing comes down to what are your requirements and understanding that there are tools to do all of those things. You just have to find the right tools. You have to figure out what they are.\n\nOne of the important things from a marketing manager's perspective is how the data gets created and distributed. You have to know if you're going to be using different pieces of software. Where does that data go? How was it used? How was it reported? What are the metrics? How are you holding people accountable in what they're actually doing?\n\nUsually, the big part is the integration of that data. If you have no disciplined process to do that, you're going to end up with a spaghetti mess of chaos. Nobody wants that. Nobody wants that uncontrolled hope that a person does their job kind of thing. That's not how businesses operate. That's not how you scale. It's not how you create a consistent brand experience. Everything has to be in some sort of a process, some sort of a documented way of understanding how people do things. Otherwise, it's the wild west.\n\n<img class=\"alignnone size-full wp-image-84985\" src=\"https://media.coschedule.com/uploads/2020/07/195_Lars-Podcast-Graphics_quote-01.png\" alt=\"\" width=\"1361\" height=\"630\" />\n\nOne of the common phrases that I've heard before and I'll say it again is having the inmates run the asylum. If you're a marketing manager and you have people who work for you, maybe they use a particular piece of software that they really like but nobody else uses it, they really like it and they really own it, there's going to be a little bit of this battle back and forth because the end-user—the junior person—is going to say I'd really love to do this this way. I really like the software. I want to do this. The manager doesn't want to upset the apple cart, doesn't want to upset this person who works for them and says that's okay. You can use that. We'll do whatever makes you feel most comfortable.\n\nAfterward, they're starting to accumulate this data on this platform. This person may be the only person who knows how to get that data, how to access the platform, how to use that, how you transfer that data into the rest of the information that you're trying to use. If you have inmates running into the asylum, that problem gets magnified by every time someone does that. The complexity of the system with that many degrees of freedom turns into a nightmare.\n\nIt's funny because we talked about the freedom of being remote. The freedom of how you manage data has to be controlled. You can't have one without the other. Often, that's what usually happens. In an office, you can really control the environment. You can walk over to somebody's cubicle and say you better go and do this for me right now. I need this data right now in Excel or upload it in a CSV or whatever. Then, the person will be like, okay. I'll go do that. You can't do that if the person is working a thousand miles away, they're at home, or whatever. You have to rely on controls. If you're going to give people personal freedom, you have to have control over the way that data is generated and manipulated.\n\nBen: That's a very interesting point. Without that, nothing else works. That's great insight. I think on the flip side of that, as an individual contributor on a team, say, I'm someone with the boss, essentially, and I'm suddenly finding myself having to work remotely. I've never worked remotely before. No one else in the team has worked remotely before. What is the single most important thing that you think someone in that position can do to make that transition as successful as it possibly can be, both for themselves and for their organization?\n\nLars: I'm a little biased in this because I own a CRM company. I think the key to the success of any business—it doesn't matter if you're remote or if you're working in the office—is a solid CRM. A CRM that has all the data fully integrated, built into the platform.\n\nIf you have a marketing person that's working somewhere else and they're sending emails out, that data instantaneously gets back to the CRM and is used by other people in the marketing team, other people in the sales department, people doing customer service. You can call the contact and you can see a history of every interaction with that contact, every relationship, everything that's associated with that relationship.\n\nIf you're working in project development, you have to have a good project management system. If you're managing events, you have to have a good events management system. If you're an HR compliance or if you're trying to onboard and train new employees or even train existing customers or new customers, you need to have a learning management system that (again) is tied into the CRM. All of these components work together. If you have any of them that are off playing in the lead just doing their own thing, you've lost control of that data. Part of that is from a usability perspective.\n\nAs a senior manager or a boss, you have to see what's happening, but you also have to see how the other pieces play with each other. So, to define customer service, I can access all that other data. But then, you also have the IT department and how important it is to control your data, to know where it is, and from a privacy perspective, to know that your customers, that you're a good steward of your customer’s data because they trust you.\n\nSomeone is going to write you some amount of information about who they are. We do this all the time. We sign up for a product or service and we give them our email address, our phone number, maybe our social media information, our name, whatever it is. All that data is now held in that system. If that data then gets shared because you have inmates from the asylum or whatever, you've got a complicated system, you have other pieces of software, now you have to control the data, not only in one system but in 10. What happens if somebody leaves? What happens if somebody exports the data and you don't know if they exported that data? The more splits in the data, the more places that your data sits, the more vectors there are for the loss of that data.\n\nAs a business owner, as a boss, as a manager, C-level executive, wherever you are in the work corporate structure, even if you're a startup, you have to understand where that data is being stored. You have to understand how it's being used. You have to share it with the people who need to have it so that if you need someone to look up a contact record, you can see the history of every phone call that you ever had, every email they've ever opened, every meeting you ever had with them, every product demo, every video they've watched, every webpage, every project they've been associated with, all of that needs to be in one place so you can access it when you need it, and also to limit the ability of that data to just go flying off on its own if someone were to go walk in that data. That's where companies lose customers. They lose trust. In the longer run, that's one of those things that truly does impact both of your top and bottom line.\n\nAdding another tool to your marketing stack isn't always the solution to every problem, but I think in this case Lars is spot-on. If you don't have the right technology to facilitate effective remote work, then nothing else that you do is really going to matter. That's true no matter what tool or what type of software it is. If there's a gap, if there's something you really need and it's missing, that pain point is going to be felt much more sharply in a remote work environment that it would've been if you're all in a shared office space.\n\n<img class=\"alignnone size-full wp-image-84986\" src=\"https://media.coschedule.com/uploads/2020/07/195_Lars-Podcast-Graphics_quote-04.png\" alt=\"\" width=\"1361\" height=\"630\" />\n\nIt's equally important to have documented processes in place to make sure that your team can make the most of that technology. I think that believing that you can have one or the other but not both together in conjunction is a potentially ruinous mistake. Find the technology you need. Absolutely do that. But make sure that you are also helping your team understand how to use it. Now, back to Lars.\n\nIf someone was new to working remotely, they were just having to adapt everything with the way that they work and the way that they interact with their coworkers, maybe if they're feeling kind of lost in the sea of all that change, what would be the single most important thing that you would recommend that person do in order for them to be able to work from home successfully?\n\nLars: I think a lot of it comes down to structure. Again, it’s tied to the CRM, it's all connected. It doesn't matter at what level you are. You're part of a team that's generating information. You're generating content. Maybe you're generating statistics. Like you're saying, if you're developing content, maybe that content is for print. Maybe it's for email. Maybe it's for websites. Maybe it's for social media. Whatever you're doing, someone is managing the development of that content.\n\nPeople need to have structure to work. We all need to know what we are working towards. What's the overall goal? [...], why are we here? We need to know the why and we need to know the how. It depends on what kind of project, what kind of person, what kind of company. There may be varying degrees of directiveness that a manager has to have over their employees or their subordinates. If there needs to be a lot of direction to people, then you have a project management system put in place where there are many tasks that are laid out for them with deadlines. You can create your codependent tasks. You can do all the things that you need to build a liquid project management.\n\nIf there's a way to take other data that is related to that, that relates back to the CRM, make that part of that whole structure. It really comes down to providing structure. I think that's one of the things when people go to the office, they feel like there's a sense of structure. They feel like I'm walking into my office on this day. I'm clocking in. I'm going to be giving these tasks. I'm going to be told what to do. At the end of the day, I'll be done and I'll go home.\n\nWhen you work from home, you don't have quite the same physical structure. You have to replace that with a software-related type of a structure. Having a really good project management system, having a good CRM is something that flows to every single level, from the most junior person in the company all the way up to the senior management because you need to be able to roll that data up to a high level, get reported, and see we're working on these projects. What sort of utilization of percentages do we have? What's our overhead looking like? What's our expense ratio look like? All these different things related to actually executing. They tie into the rest of the way the business operates.\n\nWith people on remote it’s scattered all over the place, that software has to be the unifying thing that pulls them all together.\n\nBen: Sure. What are some of the top mistakes that you see companies make when they attempt to implement work from home policies? And how can those problems be avoided?\n\nLars: I think really it comes down (again) to a lack of structure and planning. I think that's what happened with a lot of companies when the pandemic hit because there was not a lot of warning. One week where everything's looking like it could be bad, then the next week everyone's told to go home. Everything from our education system, we have teachers that don't have the tools they need to teach remotely, to businesses where people were working remotely. They don't really know what to do, they're not really tracked. You've got all these issues that suddenly have to be resolved very, very, quickly. Unfortunately, it was a lot of these kinds of things that took planning to do it right.\n\nI think a lot of businesses did a knee jerk reaction and said, okay, we're going to get Zoom. We're going to get Microsoft teams. We're going to get Meet or whatever. We're going to have our meetings and talk. Those are important to have. It's good to have FaceTime. It's good to have people involved in some way to feel that interpersonal connection in the business.\n\n<img class=\"alignnone size-full wp-image-84987\" src=\"https://media.coschedule.com/uploads/2020/07/195_Lars-Podcast-Graphics_quote-02.png\" alt=\"\" width=\"1361\" height=\"630\" />\n\nOn the other side of that, you have to come up with the process and the structure to help people have a way to bound their day. What are they doing? How are they supposed to be doing all of it? Make sure that you have a maintained structure of management. Every business has people that do stuff and people that manage stuff. [...] obviously, but people have to know where they fit. And that takes planning.\n\nWhat I always tell companies to do and with our customers—we work with them when they come on board, set them up with the CRM and marketing automation systems—is before you even go down that road, have a good understanding of who your target market is. Know your market segment. Have your buyer personas defined. Look at your buyer’s journey and your process both from a buyer’s perspective and internal process.\n\nHave stuff written down. Documentation. It doesn't have to be complicated. It doesn't have to be super fancy or lots of flowery words or whatever. Just have it written down so that you can then translate that into an actual system, actual software. I would recommend using the CRM as the core for that and having all the pieces connect back to the CRM.\n\nThe last part is understanding your data model, understanding what data you are accumulating, how you are going to use it because as you go through this finder’s journey, you have to know how you're going to use that. If the number of likes, shares, reads, clicks, website visits, or whatever it is, impacts the business, make sure you have a way to collect that data and store it in a useful way.\n\nBen: That's all solid advice. That does it for all the questions I have prepared. Before I let you go, is there anything else on this topic you think could be important to throw out there or to share with our audience?\n\nLars: I think a manager has to be very aware of the personalities of the people that work around and underneath them. I was saying before, there's so much to a business that goes beyond software. It really has to do with understanding people, how they work, and I think that's very much a conversation. They don't work as well when you have this hammer approach ruled by fear kind of thing. It's about how you create an environment where the people who are in the company feel like they're part of a team, feel like they're heard, and feel like they're valued. I think that's really one of the important things when you're talking about creating a good company culture.\n\nIt's harder when people don't go to the office. It's harder to set the tone because you're not seeing them every day. I think that if every manager were to take a few minutes and think about each of the people they work with, think about their personalities, think about what really motivates them, even if it just means opening the door, having conversations, and saying hey, how are you doing, extended remote work can be hard. How did you feel? Is there anything we can do to make you feel better? Do you feel like you have enough structure in your day? Do you feel like you have enough tools to accomplish what you need to accomplish?\n\nSimple conversations like that go a long way. The more human-centric approach, especially now where we feel very isolated, goes a long way towards helping a company operate and just be more efficient and be happier. People like to feel valued and that's how we do that.\n\nBen: Absolutely. That's great advice. Thank you so much for coming on this show, and sharing your insight into making remote work actually work. Like I was saying before we actually jumped into the interview, even though we are a few months into the pandemic, I think this is really continuing to be something else at the top of a lot of people's minds right now.\n\nLars: Yes. It's definitely not going away. We're going to be in this situation for quite some time. Not that the pandemic is good or that anyone getting sick is good, but I think the direction that it's pushed our culture and our society as a whole has actually had some positive effects on it. There's less traffic, there's less impact on the environment, people are spending more time at home, there are more pet adoptions, things like that. The little things.\n\nWhen you have everyone starting to work from home, the positive impact can be really substantial. I'm a surfer. The idea of catching a wave, of how society is changing, take a look at where the direction the society is going and build your business around that. Catch the wave of how things are changing and make your company fit the culture that you want it to be. I think that, as leaders, we all set that. It doesn't matter if you're the CEO or a junior person. You have an impact on all of those things.\n\nI think the more we think long-term, we think more in terms of how we ride this wave in a way that can help our business grow, scale, provide us with advantages, and the quality of life we enjoy from being able to work remotely. Whether that means we're at home with our family and we're able to travel more, then those are all things that can impact both our lives, the company, and the people around us.\n\n<a
