Sailer","articleImgCdnMap":{"https://media.coschedule.com/uploads/2020/07/195_Lars-Podcast-Graphics_header.png":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx14/cdn19@2020_1/2020/08/24/21-56-11-068_4f443a0fcf88775a.webp","https://media.coschedule.com/uploads/2020/07/195_Lars-Podcast-Graphics_quote-03.png":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx7/cdn71@2020_2/2020/08/24/21-56-35-132_8df0a42a07ec95c7.webp","https://media.coschedule.com/uploads/2020/07/195_Lars-Podcast-Graphics_quote-01.png":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx27/cdn27@2020_2/2020/08/24/21-56-37-871_5b20a790c8be4857.webp","https://media.coschedule.com/uploads/2020/07/195_Lars-Podcast-Graphics_quote-04.png":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx15/cdn67@2020_5/2020/08/24/21-56-33-177_231f9e0fd0005266.webp","https://media.coschedule.com/uploads/2020/07/195_Lars-Podcast-Graphics_quote-02.png":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx11/cdn92@2020_6/2020/08/24/21-56-36-134_abf8aa6edeca9282.webp","https://media.coschedule.com/uploads/2020/07/195_Lars-Podcast-Graphics_CTA.png":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx4/cdn44@2020_3/2020/08/24/21-56-32-923_08fd85c35ba2886e.webp"},"publishedOrCreatedDate":1598306169466},{"createdTime":"2020-08-25 05:56:09","updatedTime":"2020-08-25 05:56:09","title":"Making Sponsorships Successful By Picking the Right Partners With Ken Ungar From CHARGE [AMP 193]","link":"https://coschedule.com/?p=84027","description":"<img class=\"alignnone size-full wp-image-84510\" src=\"https://media.coschedule.com/uploads/2020/07/193_Ken-Podcast-Graphics_header.png\" alt=\"\" width=\"1361\" height=\"581\" />\n\nWhat does it take to make sponsorships successfully work? Turn one-off transactions into powerful, long-term relationships between brands by picking the best partners and proving ROI.\n\nToday’s guest is Ken Ungar, founder and president of CHARGE, a sponsorship marketing agency. Also, Ken’s a former chief executive for the Indianapolis Motor Speedway and author of <em>Ahead of the Game: What Every Athlete Needs to Know About Sports in Business</em>.\n\n[podcast_motor_player]\n\n<strong>Some of the highlights of the show include:</strong>\n<ul>\n \t<li>Take CHARGE: Unlock power of sponsorship to accomplish business objectives</li>\n \t<li>Third-Party Validation: Marketers convince consumers, sponsors transfer affect</li>\n \t<li>Partners and Collaborators: Choose wisely to create a positive relationship</li>\n \t<li>Potential Sponsors: Know/share audiences; identify brand/property reputation</li>\n \t<li>Pitch Perspectives: Create win-win attitude when attracting or selling sponsors</li>\n \t<li>Relationship Results: Both sides benefit; if nothing’s invested, nothing’s gained</li>\n \t<li>Strategy, Plan, Work: Leverage and activate relationship to make it mutually beneficial</li>\n \t<li>Mindful Mistakes:\n<ul>\n \t<li>Understand audiences via discussions, surveys, and data</li>\n \t<li>Activate sponsorship to advertise benefits</li>\n \t<li>Measure success or plan to fail</li>\n</ul>\n</li>\n \t<li>Stakeholder Sponsorship Skepticism: Convince with case studies, testimonials</li>\n</ul>\n<div class=\"link-callout\">\n\n<strong>Links:</strong>\n<ul>\n \t<li><a href=\"https://chargesponsorship.com/\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener noreferrer\">CHARGE</a></li>\n \t<li><a href=\"https://chargesponsorship.com/insights/\">CHARGE Sponsorship Insights</a></li>\n \t<li><a href=\"https://www.amazon.com/Ahead-Game-Athlete-Sports-Business/dp/0979883032\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener noreferrer\">Ahead of the Game: What Every Athlete Needs to Know About Sports in Business</a></li>\n \t<li><a href=\"https://www.surveymonkey.com/\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener noreferrer\">SurveyMonkey</a></li>\n \t<li><a href=\"https://coschedule.com/\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener noreferrer\">CoSchedule</a></li>\n</ul>\n</div>\nIf you liked today’s show, <a href=\"https://itunes.apple.com/us/podcast/actionable-content-marketing/id1162659795\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener noreferrer\">please subscribe on iTunes</a> to The Actionable Content Marketing Podcast! The podcast is also available on <a href=\"https://soundcloud.com/coschedule\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener noreferrer\">SoundCloud,</a> <a href=\"http://www.stitcher.com/s?fid=101560&#38;;refid=stpr\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener noreferrer\">Stitcher</a>, and <a href=\"https://goo.gl/app/playmusic?ibi=com.google.PlayMusic&#38;;isi=691797987&#38;ius=googleplaymusic&#38;link=https://play.google.com/music/m/Iks7nu4sb6gquwxy3purzwlitga?t%3DActionable_Content_Marketing\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener noreferrer\">Google Play</a>.\n<div class=\"link-callout\">\n\n<strong>Quotes by Ken Ungar:</strong>\n<ul>\n \t<li>“We help organizations unlock the power of sponsorship to help them accomplish their business objectives.”</li>\n \t<li>“By virtue of their association, that’s one way that that brand can grow.”</li>\n \t<li>“Whether attracting a sponsor, or selling a sponsor, that’s what you want to keep in mind.”</li>\n \t<li>“Sponsorship is definitely a two-way street. It works for both because it’s a relationship.”</li>\n</ul>\n</div>\n[Tweet \"Making sponserships successful by picking the right partners with @kungar from @CHARGE_Agency\"]\n<h1><strong>Transcript:</strong></h1>\nBen: <span style=\"font-family: -apple-system, BlinkMacSystemFont, 'Segoe UI', Roboto, Oxygen-Sans, Ubuntu, Cantarell, 'Helvetica Neue', sans-serif;\">Hi, Ken. Welcome to the show.</span>\n\nKen: Ben, it's great to be here. Thank you.\n\nBen: Absolutely. Would you mind taking a moment to introduce yourself to our audience and explain what you do at CHARGE?\n\nKen: Sure. My name is Ken Ungar and I'm the president and founder of CHARGE. CHARGE is a sponsorship marketing agency. We help organizations unlock the power of sponsorship to help them accomplish their business objectives, whether that's revenue growth or image enhancement. Whatever they want sponsorship to do, we help them accomplish that.\n\n<img class=\"alignnone size-full wp-image-84524\" src=\"https://media.coschedule.com/uploads/2020/07/193_Ken-Podcast-Graphics_quote-02.png\" alt=\"\" width=\"1361\" height=\"630\" />\n\nBen: Very cool. If I'm a marketer, I'm listening to this episode, and I've never delved into sponsorships before, or just never really considered that being an avenue that I would consider going down, why should I consider sponsorships? If I'm either skeptical or unaware, what makes that an area of marketing that I should really strongly consider making part of my strategy?\n\nKen: That's a great question and it's obviously a question we get a lot. I'll start with defining some terms for everybody. A sponsorship is a type of marketing. It's a marketing platform. I know you're based in Fargo, North Dakota, so let's just say North Dakota State. North Dakota State, the Bisons are a property and they might give a brand or sponsor the right to speak to its audience (the property's audience), in exchange for a fee.\n\nJust boiling it down, that's what a sponsorship is. It happens that sponsorship is one of the most powerful marketing platforms for a couple of reasons. First, if you look at something like advertising. Now, advertising is a great marketing platform. It's obviously the most prolific and the most used marketing platform as defined by dollars.\n\nThe marketer in advertising has to convince the consumer that the marketer’s company, its product or service has a great image. It is the marketers speaking directly to the consumer, but the convincing that has to happen is the marketer has to convince the consumer.\n\nWith sponsorship, the positive image of the property—the case we used before, North Dakota State—the positive image of North Dakota State is transferred to the sponsor simply by virtue of the relationship.\n\nI'll use another example. I'm a baseball fan. I love the Chicago Cubs. If you love the Chicago Cubs by virtue of the sponsorship, you will love their sponsor. We call that effect transfer. But sometimes there's image transfer where if the Cubs or North Dakota State has a positive image, automatically the consumer's going to ascribe that positive image to the sponsor.\n\nIt's a lot more powerful than advertising in the sense that it's third-party validation. I, as a marketer, don't have to convince anybody of anything. Just by virtue of the relationship, the consumer feels better about the sponsor.\n\nBen: Sure. I think that's a pretty thorough explanation there. Our CEO, Garrett Moon, also happens to be a massive Cubs fan. I think he would appreciate hearing that for sure. Something that you touch on a little bit there is the idea of a sponsorship being a relationship. As it’s essential for any positive relationship of any sort, you need to really choose partners and collaborators wisely.\n\nLet's say I'm sold on sponsorships as a strategy or as a tactic. What would be the first thing that you would recommend that I do to identify potential partners that might really be strong candidates for my business to partner with?\n\nKen: That's a great question. In that respect, we usually advise people to start with one thing and I'm going to mention this a number of times during our discussion today, and that's the audience. A marketer knows his or her audience in terms of the customers of their brand and that's super important because the most important aspect in choosing a partner to sponsor is to understand their audience. In order for sponsorship to really work, there has to be a shared target audience.\n\nIf your consumers are ages 25–44, predominantly male, have a certain household income, from a psychographic perspective they like certain pursuits, certain hobbies, your audience and the property's audience have to match pretty much like a hand in glove. When that happens, that's when all the good impacts that we talked about earlier happen. The first thing you're going to do is you're going to identify a property that has the same or similar audience to you.\n\nThe next thing you're gonna do is look at a property. If you're a brand marketer, you're going to look at a property and you're going to say, what is the reputation of that property? Whether it's a Cubs, the North Dakota State Bisons, what is the reputation of that property? Because we talked about image transfer, that great reputation is going to be transferred to you as a brand.\n\nYou're going to want to find properties that share your values, that stand for the same things that you do, but potentially are more well-known because they're in sports, entertainment, music, or fine arts. Those two things start with the audience, and then understand the brand and the reputation of the property. Those are the two best things to get you started in terms of identifying a potential partner.\n\nBen: I think it makes a lot of sense to start with partners that have the same or similar audiences. I guess a follow-up question I would have to that is, do you have any advice on researching potential partners or sponsorships that can really also help you grow your own audience?\n\nI imagine if there is already some overlap there, there’s that thought of trying to use that to get in front of people who don't already know who you are. I imagine that might get a little bit complicated if you're speaking to the same people twice, so to speak, if they are already aware of you because your audiences do overlap so much.\n\nKen: Yeah, a great question. Let's break that down into its component parts. There's a difference between the audience being the same in terms of its demographics and psychographics and the size of the audience. Let's stick to professional sports. Probably about 75% of all sponsorship are in sports, either amateur youth, college, professional, and then the remaining part are in not-for-profits, museums, festivals, concerts, things of that nature. We'll stick with some sports examples and I'll stick with Cubs because I love the Cubs.\n\nLet's just say that they're a family-oriented brand, so their audience are families. If I'm a company and the audience for my customers, for my products, or services or also families, that's an alignment of the audience in terms of how it's composed, but the size is really different. I might be a smallish company, maybe I sell in only a certain part of the Chicago area, but the Cubs reach millions of families.\n\nNow, they're both family-oriented brands—the Cubs and this magical sponsor—but the Cubs are now opening the door to its significantly larger audience. Now, the company can convert many new customers, people who may not have heard of this company before by virtue of their association. That's one way that brand can grow is just by virtue of an introduction to a much bigger audience than that company could ordinarily reach by advertising or other means, digital advertising or otherwise.\n\n<img class=\"alignnone size-full wp-image-84526\" src=\"https://media.coschedule.com/uploads/2020/07/193_Ken-Podcast-Graphics_quote-03.png\" alt=\"\" width=\"1361\" height=\"630\" />\n\nBen: That makes a lot of sense. Let's say I've identified a potential sponsorship partner. In this hypothetical example, let's say I'm a mom-and-pop shop in the greater Chicago area, and I want to make a pitch to the Chicago Cubs for why I should be considered a partner to start a partnership program. In a case like that, I'm a lot smaller, as you said, than the Cubs. I imagine my pitch to the marketing department within the Cubs organizations, I probably got to be pretty compelling.\n\nHow would you advise a marketer in that sort of situation? Or maybe some business owner who's taking on a marketing function? How would you advise them to make that pitch and really make a strong first impression, to maybe tilt the odds in their favor of that interaction going positively?\n\nKen: Let's look at that question from two perspectives. I'll give you two scenarios. One is a property trying to sell a sponsor and buying that sponsorship and then I'll flip it, then it's a sponsor, a company, that wants to use a property to extend its brand. I'll look at it from both perspectives.\n\nIn the first one, I'm a mom-and-pop hamburger shop. I'm not McDonald's. Maybe I have a few restaurants, but now I want to convince the mighty Chicago Cubs that I want to be their sponsor. The first thing we mentioned before, the audience. If the Cubs or another organization like that is a family-oriented brand, that small hamburger shop is going to demonstrate that it has the same audience every Friday night. You can find all the families in the neighborhood at that hamburger shop. They support families throughout the neighborhood, they do all these things, that their brand is a family brand. Right there, you're showing that that audience is the same.\n\nBut next, that hamburger shop would want to understand the Chicago Cubs and understand what its goals are. It might be a professional sports organization that wants to maximize the amount of money that it gets from potential sponsors. In that case, that mom and pop hamburger shop might not be able to help them because they don't have the resources of a McDonald's. But they might have other things that would benefit the Cubs.\n\nFirst, it's authenticity. That might be something that the Cubs want to align with authentic brands, that it's not necessary for them to align with multinational corporations like McDonald's. But instead, they want to really demonstrate they're all about families, so their sponsors are family-oriented businesses and that is authentic.\n\nUnderstanding where the Cubs are coming from, and their goals, and how they market their brand, that's what a sponsor wants to think about in terms of what's in it for the property. That's kind of an example of that from the small sponsor, large property perspective. Let's flip that.\n\nNow a Double-A baseball team or Single-A baseball team wants to convince McDonald's. McDonald's needs to sponsor that particular small baseball team. Same process. Number one is the audience. The audience has to be the same. McDonald's is a family-oriented brand, so that baseball team needs to demonstrate that family orientation. But then, that property, in the case of the small baseball team, they need to understand McDonald's objectives and help McDonald's achieve what it wants to do.\n\nIn this case, it might be that in the geography where that team plays, McDonald's is not the strongest hamburger chain or not the strongest quick service restaurant in the area. But this small baseball team has a really loyal following. Again, Sunday afternoon, every Monday night, the entire community can be found at their ballpark enjoying the game.\n\nWhat could be in it for McDonald's is that they're going to get greater penetration in a certain geographic area because it aligns with this smaller, yes, but very popular property in the area. Again, the audience is aligned, but understanding both marketing objectives, in this case, the large sponsor that's McDonald's, creating that win-win marketing attitude, that's in terms of creating a pitch, either attracting a sponsor or selling a sponsor. That's what you want to keep in mind.\n\n<img class=\"alignnone size-full wp-image-84527\" src=\"https://media.coschedule.com/uploads/2020/07/193_Ken-Podcast-Graphics_quote-04.png\" alt=\"\" width=\"1361\" height=\"630\" />\n\nBen: That makes a lot of sense. I really appreciate how you can take a look at that from both perspectives. I think there are a lot of important considerations there for both sides to keep in mind.\n\nKen: That's another important aspect of sponsorship, is it's definitely a two-way street. It works for both because it's a relationship. It's not the marketers speaking to the consumer. These are two institutions talking to each other by virtue of their relationship. They're creating magic for both. In the case the baseball team sells more tickets, the sponsor gets more business or enhances its brand, and that's because it's a relationship. It's got to be seen from both sides.\n\n<img class=\"alignnone size-full wp-image-84528\" src=\"https://media.coschedule.com/uploads/2020/07/193_Ken-Podcast-Graphics_quote-01.png\" alt=\"\" width=\"1361\" height=\"630\" />\n\nThe best sponsorships that I see are when there's that win-win, that both sides benefit from it and the worst that I see is either no one cares to work the relationship—if nothing is invested, nothing is gained—or there really isn't any activity between the two in terms of really making that relationship come to life.\n\nBen: Whether you're looking to place some signage at a local sports stadium or maybe work with a top-performing Twitch streamer or whatever type of sponsorship opportunity you might be looking at, success always starts by putting the audience first. A key point that Ken makes, though, that you need to consider is not only the similarities and audiences between your brand and your partner but the size of your own audience relative to theirs as well.\n\nWhether you're a small sponsor looking to partner with big brands or a large sponsor looking to work with smaller brands, I love what Ken has to say about finding ways to make sure that those relationships can benefit both parties without the pitch of looking lopsided right from the start.\n\nI think what's great about that too is how much it reveals about the potential value of sponsorships in general because if you're a small brand, it's tough to imagine too many other channels that can scale as effectively. For larger brands, there’s an opportunity in a lot of ways to demonstrate your values and maybe to connect on a closer level with your audience and with your potential consumers than what might be possible otherwise.\n\nIt is as Ken says, a two-way street and that's really the way that you have to think about it. Now, back to Ken.\n\nOnce a partnership program is up and running, let's say McDonald’s and the Single-A baseball team in town are hitting it off, or it's a local chain that's landed. There's this big deal with the Chicago Cubs. What should those companies be doing or keeping in mind to ensure that they are proactively fostering that relationship in order to make sure that it really is mutually beneficial in the long term success rather than just like a one-off transactional sort of thing that just fizzles out and doesn't really provide results?\n\nKen: This is a really important point. What I recommend to everyone is strategy, planning, and work, work, work. Because it's a relationship, you go in with certain expectations. What we find is that the mere fact of the association doesn't necessarily make it work.\n\nIf I'm the official sponsor of your podcast, it may not work for me to just say that I'm the official sponsor of your podcast. What I want to do is create an entire plan around that to do what we call either leveraging or activating the relationship. That takes many forms and there's a strategy behind it. There's obviously plans behind it and there's a lot of work. I'll give you some examples of that.\n\nLet's stick with McDonald's and the small baseball team. They're going to activate it in a lot of different ways. From a physical perspective, they're probably going to put signs in the ballpark that McDonald's is the official sponsor of this baseball team. They're going to put things on displays, jumbotrons, and public address announcement reads. All these different things to announce to the audience that, yes, McDonald's is the sponsor of this team and is proud to do so.\n\nBut the audiences really want to know about authenticity and they want to know why McDonald’s wants to sponsor this baseball team. So McDonald’s is going to do things from a public relations and an audience relations perspective to demonstrate that they wanted to be involved with this baseball team because they wanted to make sports a better experience for this audience. They wanted to do something to improve this community, to improve entertainment opportunities, to provide more access to quality entertainment in the community.\n\nThey're going to do various things that you see sponsors do. They might provide premiums or giveaways. Free baseball bats with the McDonald's logo on it, or free hats, free sunscreen. Do all kinds of things for the audience. Maybe free Wi-Fi that enhances the audience’s experience. From a public relations perspective, there are plans that go in to make activating or leveraging that relationship.\n\nThere may be television commercials where McDonald's is going to tag at the end of its commercial that it is the official sponsor of this particular baseball team. It might help them advertise. They might have premium giveaways, like if there are two home runs at a certain game, bring your ticket stub in and you get 25% off on your next Big Mac.\n\nThere are all these different things that go into activating a relationship. It takes that strategy like, how am I going to really speak to this audience, planning to pull it all together. Email marketing, inbound marketing, there might be a variety of different things, and then there's the work. There is work to make this relationship come alive. But again, that's to get all that benefit that I talked about, to grow your business, to improve your image. Once you do those things, you get those great outcomes.\n\nBen: Those are all the things that companies should be doing to make sure that they're putting in the effort into those relationships to make them successful. On the flip side, are there any common sponsorship, marketing mistakes that you sometimes see that you can offer any advice on how to avoid? What are the common pitfalls that people get tripped up on, that they should be mindful of going into any sponsorship-type arrangement?\n\nKen: I think there are three things that I have people keep in mind. First, you're not going to be surprised. I've used this word a lot in this discussion and that's the audience, knowing your audience. If you're a brand, you need to really understand your customer. You should if you're a really good marketer; you already know that. But to have that really front of mind from a demographic, psychographic perspective, to really know what makes your customer tick.\n\nIf you're property—let's just say that Single-A or Double-A baseball team—it's for you to really understand your audience. Sometimes that's harder. We find with smaller properties, for example, that they don't necessarily have the marketing resources to really understand their customer the way that McDonald's does. A company like that knows everything about their customer.\n\nWe find a lot of properties. Sometimes they struggle a bit, but they shouldn't have to struggle because there are relatively easy ways to avoid this pitfall. One of the things we recommend is surveying, so they can survey their email list. They can survey before an event, they can survey at an event, or they could survey after.\n\nA lot of times, we find that email marketing is the key to this. There are even free resources. Things like a free account on SurveyMonkey or even just one step up to get their paid account. There are survey templates all over the place about how to survey your audience and get some good baseline data. Find out how old they are. Find out how much—if they will share with you—what's their household income. Find out things like do you intend to buy a car in the next 6–12 months? If you understand those things about your audience, then all of a sudden car companies and auto dealerships might be more interested in aligning with you if they know that your significant audience is ready to buy a new car in the next 6–12 months up.\n\nFind out things that they care about. Hobbies, camping, video games, playership, all these different things. But the more that you can survey as a property and find that out, wow, you've got some incredible ammunition. The pitfall is not doing that. We see properties just go to a sponsor and go, here, I've got these three packages: gold, silver, and bronze. It costs $100,000, $50,000, and $25,000. We're going to give you these things, and not understand what audiences both parties are talking to. Avoid that first pitfall.\n\nSecond is not activating the sponsorship. We find that sometimes, especially in a little bit of larger sponsorship, some sponsors think hey, I've got it covered. I just spent $100,000 or $50,000. I just spent money on what's called a rights fee—that is the money that you pay to a property for the right to use their logo, to use their name—that I have paid money. I now have the right to use it and I'm all set. I'm not going to do anything else because now I have the right to use the logo.\n\nWe talked about before, if you don't activate, leverage that relationship, and really communicate to that audience of the property why you're proud to be a sponsor, the benefits you're conferring, all these different things, you never bring the sponsorship to life.\n\nYou're really, in that case, depending on that property, that baseball team (for example) to advertise your presence and for the audience to accidentally find out that you're a sponsor. The second pitfall is companies that don't activate. They just buy the rights. And what we say is if you're at the front of the relationship. For some of your listeners who have never done this before, we talk about a minimum ratio of either 0.5:1 or 1:1 of rights fees to the amount you spend on leverage or activation.\n\nFor example, if you spend a dollar to become the official sponsor of a baseball team, you want to spend at least a dollar in activating it, whether it's the premiums you give away, or email marketing that you do, the inbound marketing, or all these different things that you do, you want to do at least $1 of rights to $1 of activation.\n\nIf in the front of the relationship, the sponsorship costs you $50,000 and you're like, whoa, that's my budget. I don't have any other money, don't do it. If you only have $50,000 as a budget to activate this relationship, then divide that by two. I can only afford to buy the relationship for $25,000 because I need to keep at least $25,000 to bring it to life. The second pitfall is not activating.\n\nThen the third is not measuring. It's interesting, 80% of sponsors that you ask would say one of the most important things in the sponsorship relationship is to measure success. But then you find the same surveys will tell you that they only dedicate 3%–6% of their entire budget to measure it.\n\nThey all say how important it is, but they never measure enough. Not measuring success is the third pitfall, because if you fail to plan, you plan to fail in the sense that you're going to spend all this money. If you're a marketer, the CEO or the president is going to come to you and say hey, I saw that sponsorship. It looked good on TV. But what did it get us? As a marketer, it's incumbent upon us to measure results.\n\nHow do we avoid that pitfall? Determine what success looks like. If you're a brand, are you going into it for sales lift? If you are, measure your sales before the sponsorship, measure your sales during, and measure after.\n\nIf you're looking for image enhancement, you're probably going to do that through surveys. So you're going to survey before, you're going to survey during, and you're going to survey after to demonstrate because then, when your CEO comes to you, you go, hey, boss. Look, we have a 25% lift in awareness. We have a 30% lift in purchase consideration and all these great metrics is a result of this sponsorship. So don't you think that it was money well spent? That's the third pitfall. Failing to measure for success, so make sure you measure.\n\nBen: I think that last point applies to so many areas of marketing. I feel like it's very easy to get caught up in the excitement of doing stuff and not spend so much time looking at things like, well, I did that. It probably worked. Actually, taking a look and analyzing what happened and why as a result of your actions.\n\nKen: I have quite a few clients who are engineers. So I kept this all the time because in their world, if you can't measure it, it doesn't happen. If you can't use a formula, you can't do it. They look at us as marketers and sometimes there's all this magic that goes on behind the scenes or when someone asks, hey, you did an advertisement but did it really work?\n\nEspecially now, especially in the digital age, it's so incumbent upon us to measure and really demonstrate that here is the result of what we do, and here's how we can prove it. Sponsorship is no different, but the great thing is, if you do it, you can then form a strategy perspective, make it even better because from what you've done, you know what the results are from your activity.\n\nBen: Absolutely. So one last question I'll throw your way. I think that this is something that would be very pertinent to anything with sponsorships or advertising, but I think that this also applies to a lot of different areas in marketing.\n\nLet's say that you are working with a client or you are working for a boss or a business owner who's a little bit skeptical of marketing in general because they're maybe of the mindset that there's got to be a clear process or an action you take that drives this really predictable outcome. Like with engineers. I imagine in their world they follow a schematic. They can see that process from start to finish, and in the end, they have a concrete product or a result of their actions so that they can point to saying like, I did this and then this happened.\n\nWhereas with marketers, as you say, there's this perception that we just kind of go behind the curtain and a bunch of magic happens and then money gets made somehow. That's what it looks like to them. When in reality, if you're doing your job correctly, there's a lot of strategic thought, a lot of processes, and a lot of repeatable methodologies that go into making that work.\n\nTo bring this back to our topic here of talking about sponsorships, if you're trying to convince a stakeholder who is skeptical, that sponsorships are a good idea or that you can honestly measure the impact of what you're doing, measurement means showing data and all of that after you've done some things that are super important.\n\nBut let's say that if you're getting stuck on not being able to get started because you can't pass that barrier with somebody, because they're like, well, I'm not going to put money into this if you can't do a better job of explaining how this is all going to work upfront. If someone's in that position, how would you advise that they make the case?\n\nKen: We see that often especially when the boss or the CEO does not necessarily have a marketing background. They might approach it with a bit of skepticism which, hey, skepticism in business is a good thing. It's incumbent upon us to prove it. The way I approach it is there are two things, case studies and testimonials.\n\nDon't trust me. I'm here telling your boss that if we do this type of activity, you'll get this kind of result. Don't trust me. Trust all these organizations that are independent third parties. This is a case of third-party validation which we find in marketing always is more persuasive than if we say it. Bring them case studies and testimonials.\n\nI'll give you an example. When I was on the property side, I used to work for the Indianapolis Motor Speedway and the IndyCar Series back in the day. We had an aerospace sponsor and that aerospace sponsor was selling private jets.\n\nIt was a pretty target-rich environment because anywhere you look, there was a race car driver who makes millions of dollars a year or a race team owner who is a millionaire or a billionaire, and all of them want to fly in private jets. There is a sponsor who had exclusive access because they were the exclusive aerospace sponsor and they will tell you, there is a case study that for every dollar they spent on the sponsorship, they got $32 back in terms of the sales they made directly related to the sponsorship.\n\nThat's an example from a sales perspective. You bring in that case study and you go, hey, boss. I can't necessarily prove to you or guarantee a 32 to 1 return on investment, but I can guarantee that this technique, that sponsorship can provide this kind of return on investment. We just have to go in and we have to see. Or you find a case study in your industry that gets closer to the potential ROI that you would have. Or a testimonial.\n\nWhen properties want to sell sponsors, they might reference other sponsors. You might have your CEO call the CEO of a current sponsor and ask them, hey, what's been your experience in the sponsorship? Have you sold more stuff? Has your image been enhanced? Is this property good to work with? And the other CEO says, oh, yeah. They've been fantastic.\n\nAgain, I recommend those two different cases of third-party validation to demonstrate, listen, these are the results that others are getting. Can't promise that we'll get them, but I can promise you the technique works.\n\nBen: I think that's great advice. That's really bringing it back to just the fundamentals with testimonials and case studies. I love it.\n\nThat's all I had for you, but before I let you go, were there any other lingering thoughts or anything else that you've got on your mind as it pertains to this topic, that you'd maybe like to share with our audience?\n\nKen: Obviously, I'm a true believer in sponsorship because I know it works and I know the power of it, especially in terms of things like image transfer and all those things that really help sponsors take their businesses to the next level.\n\nOne thing is I just recommend listeners to not be afraid of it. If they're uninitiated, they just haven't experienced it before. There are lots of ways to put your toe in the water. For example, on our website at chargesponsorship.com, in the insight section. We have dozens and dozens of blogs, ebooks, and all these different things, completely free, kind of help people get started, help them get a toe in the water.\n\nThere are books. We have one coming out next month called Sponsorship Strategy: Practical Approaches to Powerful Sponsorships. That's a $24.99 way to get your feet wet and understand it. But really, it's kind of to educate yourself a little, seek out a professional like our agency if you need one, but really try it.\n\nThere is an old expression: “Try it, you'll like it.” Our parents used to tell us that. Dip your toe in the water. Get some experience. It is a valuable addition to us to a marketer's tool belt if you don't already do it.\n\n<a href=\"https://podcasts.apple.com/us/podcast/actionable-marketing-podcast/id1162659795?mt=2\"><img Right Partners With Ken Ungar From CHARGE [AMP 193]</a> appeared first on <a rel=\"nofollow\" href=\"https://coschedule.com\">CoSchedule Blog</a>.</p>\n","descriptionType":"html","publishedDate":"Tue, Sailer","articleImgCdnMap":{"https://media.coschedule.com/uploads/2020/07/193_Ken-Podcast-Graphics_header.png":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx11/cdn52@2020_5/2020/08/24/21-56-11-028_8f3308747844c828.webp","https://media.coschedule.com/uploads/2020/07/193_Ken-Podcast-Graphics_quote-02.png":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx7/cdn67@2020_6/2020/08/24/21-56-25-290_22aea137e941f481.webp","https://media.coschedule.com/uploads/2020/07/193_Ken-Podcast-Graphics_quote-03.png":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx5oss/cdn95@2020_3/2020/08/24/21-56-26-645_15d642eaa3b4519e.webp","https://media.coschedule.com/uploads/2020/07/193_Ken-Podcast-Graphics_quote-04.png":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx12/cdn51@2020_5/2020/08/24/21-56-28-410_6f6e83a048b8f79d.webp","https://media.coschedule.com/uploads/2020/07/193_Ken-Podcast-Graphics_quote-01.png":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx22/cdn60@2020_2/2020/08/24/21-56-25-507_6a033a5d7e3a81a6.webp","https://media.coschedule.com/uploads/2020/07/192_Jim-Podcast-Graphics_CTA.png":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx4/cdn76@2020_6/2020/08/24/21-56-26-981_e291f8d82725af71.webp"},"publishedOrCreatedDate":1598306169469},{"createdTime":"2020-08-25 05:56:09","updatedTime":"2020-08-25 05:56:09","title":"Digital Asset Management: The Complete Non-Boring Guide For Marketers","link":"https://coschedule.com/?p=82586","description":"<img class=\"alignnone wp-image-84249 size-full\" src=\"https://media.coschedule.com/uploads/2020/07/digital-asset-management-header.png\" alt=\"Digital asset management guide for marketers header.\" width=\"1361\" height=\"581\" /> \n<span style=\"font-weight: bold;\">Have you ever searched endlessly for that one elusive marketing asset? </span> Maybe it’s a new version of a logo your coworker needs to add to your redesigned website, or a chart for a presentation that you literally need RIGHT NOW. \n<span style=\"font-weight: bold;\">You decide to go on a hunt for that treasured asset.</span> One that leads you through tangled webs of randomly named files, images, videos, you name it. They’re EVERYWHERE: in emails, Google Drive, Dropbox, your company’s server, your personal folders, your coworker’s folders… \n<img class=\"alignnone wp-image-82691 size-full\" src=\"https://media.coschedule.com/uploads/asset-hunt.png\" alt=\"Treasure map with a magnifying glass and treasure chest\" width=\"1361\" height=\"576\" /> \n<span style=\"font-weight: bold;\">Before you know it, it’s been two hours, and you’re totally frustrated.</span> You missed the opportunity to update your marketing materials before that presentation. Your coworker is still waiting for that file. You still have no idea where it is. Everyone involved is stressed out. Fortunately, there’s a solution to help you keep your internal assets organized, accessible, and easily shareable with \n<span style=\"font-weight: bold;\">digital asset management</span>. What the heck IS digital asset management, and how can it help you finally get all of your files straight? Let’s dig into it together. [Tweet \"What the Heck is Digital Asset Management, and How Can It Make Your Life Less Frustrating?\"] \n<img class=\"alignnone wp-image-82692 size-full\" src=\"https://media.coschedule.com/uploads/treasure-chest-open.png\" alt=\"Treasure map with the treasure chest open with asset icon\" width=\"1361\" height=\"576\" /> \n<div class=\"link-callout\"> \n <a name=\"toc\"></a>\n <strong>Table of Contents</strong> \n <ul> \n  <li><a href=\"https://coschedule.com/?p=82586#definition\">What the Heck is Digital Asset Management?</a></li> \n  <li><a href=\"https://coschedule.com/?p=82586#why\">Why Does Digital Asset Management Matter, Anyway?</a></li> \n  <li><a href=\"https://coschedule.com/?p=82586#bundle\">Download Our Digital Asset Management Template Bundle</a></li> \n  <li><a href=\"https://coschedule.com/?p=82586#easy\">How to Easily Get Started With DAM</a></li> \n  <li><a href=\"https://coschedule.com/?p=82586#action\">DAM in Action: 3 Digital Asset Management Examples</a></li> \n  <li><a href=\"https://coschedule.com/?p=82586#dig\">How to Dig Deeper Into Digital Asset Management Vendors</a></li> \n  <li><a href=\"https://coschedule.com/?p=82586#wins\">10 Wins You’ll Achieve With Digital Asset Management</a></li> \n  <li><a href=\"https://coschedule.com/?p=82586#conclusion\">How CoSchedule Can Help You Do DAM</a></li> \n </ul> \n</div> \n<a name=\"definition\"></a> \n<h2><span style=\"font-weight: bold;\">What the Heck is Digital Asset Management?</span></h2> Digital asset management (DAM) is simply the process of storing and categorizing digital files, so they’re easy to access whenever you need them. DAM can also refer to the software used to manage digital assets. \n<img class=\"alignnone wp-image-84250 size-full\" src=\"https://media.coschedule.com/uploads/2020/07/dam-definition.png\" alt=\"Digital asset management definition.\" width=\"1361\" height=\"624\" /> In other words, you can create your own DAM process to organize your digital assets, or you can use a DAM tool to help you get there. You could say both are good DAM options. \n<span style=\"font-weight: bold;\">Just so we’re clear… what are some examples of digital assets?</span> Digital assets are all the different types of content you store digitally. If you’re a marketer, digital assets are an essential part of your business. They might include: \n<ul> \n <li>Logos</li> \n <li>Graphics</li> \n <li>Photos</li> \n <li>Videos</li> \n <li>Spreadsheets</li> \n <li>Newsletters</li> \n <li>White papers</li> \n <li>Brochures</li> \n</ul> [Tweet \"Digital assets are all the different types of content you store digitally.\"] \n<img class=\"alignnone wp-image-82693 size-full\" src=\"https://media.coschedule.com/uploads/digital-asset-examples.png\" alt=\"8 examples of digital assets for marketers\" width=\"1361\" height=\"1165\" /> \n<div class=\"link-callout\">\n <strong><a href=\"https://coschedule.com/?p=82586#toc\">Back to the Top</a></strong>\n</div> \n<a name=\"why\"></a> \n<h2><span style=\"font-weight: bold;\">Why Does Digital Asset Management Matter, Anyway?</span></h2> Why should you care about digital asset management? \n<span style=\"font-weight: bold;\">Because DAM will revolutionize the way you work.</span> Organized marketers are \n<span style=\"text-decoration: underline; font-weight: bold;\"><a href=\"https://coschedule.com/marketing-statistics/\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener noreferrer\">397% more likely to be successful</a></span>. That’s HUGE. When you successfully manage your digital assets, you’ll gain that success and solve some of your most frustrating marketing problems. Problems like: \n<ul> \n <li>Not being able to find the assets you’re looking for.</li> \n <li>Trying to identify files with names that make no sense.</li> \n <li>Having to create the same assets over and over again.</li> \n <li>Wasting hours searching through assets to find the right one to share.</li> \n <li>Sharing the wrong version of a file that’s out-of-date.</li> \n</ul> \n<span style=\"color: #ff00ff;\"><img class=\"alignnone wp-image-84251 size-full\" src=\"https://media.coschedule.com/uploads/2020/07/determine-solution.png\" alt=\"Check all that apply to determine if you need DAM as a solution.\" width=\"1361\" height=\"1652\" /></span> With the help of digital asset management, you’ll slay all of those problems and replace them with real, lasting DAM solutions. It’ll feel AWESOME. \n<ul> \n <li><span style=\"font-weight: bold;\">You’ll find all of the assets you need, when you need them, in one place. </span>No more wasted hours spent searching multiple locations for files that seem to have disappeared into thin air. All your assets will finally be managed in one place.</li> \n <li><span style=\"font-weight: bold;\">Searching will be simple with new file naming conventions. </span>When your file is named “011520_XYZ,” it’s impossible to know what it is without taking the time to click on it. Correctly naming files with DAM is a game-changer. When all of your assets have consistent names, you can organize, categorize, and search them in a snap.</li> \n <li><span style=\"font-weight: bold;\">You’ll reuse assets instead of always creating new ones. </span>When you can clearly see which assets already exist, you can easily reuse them as needed — instead of losing them and having to create new ones to replace them.</li> \n <li><span style=\"font-weight: bold;\">You’ll easily share digital assets, and make your team happy. </span>Now, instead of responding to “Can you find this file for me?” with “Give me a few hours,” you’ll find and share files in just <span style=\"font-style: italic;\">seconds</span>. Y<span style=\"font-family: -apple-system, BlinkMacSystemFont, 'Segoe UI', Roboto, Oxygen-Sans, Ubuntu, Cantarell, 'Helvetica Neue', sans-serif;\">ou and your team can collaborate quickly, and everyone will stay happy and productive.</span></li> \n <li><span style=\"font-weight: bold;\">You’ll maintain brand consistency. </span>If you create and share files between multiple teams or locations, you know how hard it can be to keep EVERYTHING on-brand. When your assets are organized, you can easily check for consistency, and make sure everyone has access to the right assets.</li> \n</ul> \n<img class=\"alignnone wp-image-82695 size-full\" src=\"https://media.coschedule.com/uploads/revolutionize-work-with-dam.png\" alt=\"How DAM will revolutionize the way you work\" width=\"1361\" height=\"1165\" /> \n<strong><a href=\"https://coschedule.com/?p=82586#toc\">Back to the Top</a></strong> \n<h2><span style=\"font-weight: bold;\">10</span><span style=\"font-weight: bold;\">&nbsp;Wins You’ll Achieve With Digital Asset Management</span></h2> You’ve audited your content. You’ve added up the cost. You’ve found the perfect tool and approved it with your stakeholders. You’ve found your muse, renamed your files, and fancied up those folders. \n<div class=\"link-callout\">\n <strong>Recommended Reading:</strong> \n <a href=\"https://coschedule.com/blog/coschedules-asset-organizer/\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener noreferrer\">Getting To Know CoSchedule’s Asset Organizer</a>\n</div> Now, it’s time to sit back and soak up all the rich rewards of your new DAM process. You’re well on your way to winning with digital asset management. \n<ol> \n <li><span style=\"font-weight: bold;\">Manage all of your assets in one place</span><span style=\"font-weight: bold;\">.</span> You can easily see, organize, and search for the files you need, exactly when you need them.</li> \n <li><span style=\"font-weight: bold;\">Make collaboration seamless</span><span style=\"font-weight: bold;\">. </span>Your team members can easily communicate the asset they need, get access to it fast, and stay happy.</li> \n <li><span style=\"font-weight: bold;\">Shorten production timelines</span><span style=\"font-weight: bold;\">.</span> Your team will complete work more quickly instead of spending hours looking for assets.</li> \n <li><span style=\"font-weight: bold;\">Search and find assets in a snap</span><span style=\"font-weight: bold;\">.</span> You can get back to what matters rather than wasting time searching.</li> \n <li><span style=\"font-weight: bold;\">Reuse assets as needed</span><span style=\"font-weight: bold;\">.</span> You don’t always have to create new assets from scratch when the old ones get lost in the shuffle.</li> \n <li><span style=\"font-weight: bold;\">Cut extra effort and save costs</span><span style=\"font-weight: bold;\">.</span> You can put $30,000 or more per year back into your company instead of letting it go to waste.</li> \n <li><span style=\"font-weight: bold;\">Share assets easily</span><span style=\"font-weight: bold;\">.</span> Cross-functional teams, departments, and locations can easily send assets back and forth.</li> \n <li><span style=\"font-weight: bold;\">Maintain brand consistency</span><span style=\"font-weight: bold;\">. </span>Your marketing team can keep every version of every asset on-brand — without the risk of publishing something that’s not.</li> \n <li><span style=\"font-weight: bold;\">Improve your ROI</span><span style=\"font-weight: bold;\">.</span> You can deliver a measurable result by completing work more quickly and streamlining your asset searches.</li> \n <li><span style=\"font-weight: bold;\">Control access to your assets</span><span style=\"font-weight: bold;\">.</span> The right stakeholders, customers, or clients see the right assets at the right time.</li> \n</ol> \n<img class=\"alignnone wp-image-82701 size-full\" src=\"https://media.coschedule.com/uploads/dam-wins.png\" alt=\"10 wins you'll achieve with digital asset management\" width=\"1361\" height=\"1308\" /> \n<div class=\"link-callout\">\n <strong><a href=\"https://coschedule.com/?p=82586#toc\">Back to the Top</a></strong>\n</div> \n<a name=\"bundle\"></a> \n<h2>Common Features of DAM Platforms</h2> Most software options that are designed for businesses include some kind of file storage option. This could include the ability to attach documents to client accounts or help individuals access a web-based content library. [Tweet \"Most software options that are designed for businesses include some kind of file storage option.\"] These integrated file management solutions are pretty primitive compared to the functionality you will get from a full-fledged DAM platform. You also might be thinking… Why can’t I just use OneDrive, Dropbox, or Google Drive? These tools do help overcome hurdles to file sharing, but they don’t provide in-depth features like advanced search capabilities and version control. Which, in turn, don’t really solve the problems companies face when trying to improve ROI on their assets and breakdown silos. Here are some common functionalities of DAM software solutions. \n<h3>Ability to Manage Metadata</h3> Much like metadata provided to search engines, DAM metadata is information that provides details about the asset’s contents. Metadata can describe many different details about the file, including who owns it, who has rights to access the file, keywords associated with the document, etc. \n<h3>Ability to Track and Record Version History</h3> How many times have you encountered a document saved as Sales_Slide_Deck_Final_Final2_Final-FOR-REAL \n<img class=\"alignnone wp-image-84252 size-full\" src=\"https://media.coschedule.com/uploads/2020/07/asset-final-copy.png\" alt=\"Faux final copy of a document.\" width=\"1361\" height=\"729\" /> Or something similar. There’s nothing more frustrating, as a marketing team member, to think this is the final revision just to have another stakeholder come in and make additional changes — totally messing up the naming convention you had going. As a non-marketing team member, it's also frustrating trying to find a document and encountering that each designer has a different way of naming their files, or finding that they haven’t bothered to upload it to the shared drive, and the asset is saved on their desktop. One of the major strengths of digital asset management software is that it syncs changes in real-time, while also keeping reversion history and the ability to revert back if needed. [Tweet \"Digital asset management software syncs changes in real-time, while also keeping reversion history and the ability to revert back.\"] \n<h3>Advanced Search Capabilities</h3> A cloud storage solution, like Dropbox, is usually limited to retrieving files based on searching for the document’s title. Honestly, who can remember the name of that document from last year? With custom metadata, keywords, categories, and more, you can make sure that the right files will always show up — regardless if you know the file name or not. \n<h3>Security and Customer Usage Rights</h3> Let’s say you want some people to have full editing access to certain documents and not others, or certain images are reserved for the use of specific departments. DAM software sets clear details about which departments can access and edit each document. \n<strong><a href=\"https://coschedule.com/?p=82586#toc\">Back to the Top</a></strong> \n<h2><span style=\"font-weight: bold;\">Download Our Digital Asset Management Template Bundle</span></h2> Before we dive into the depths of DAM, download our helpful digital asset management bundle. It’s a collection of three actionable templates created by marketers, for marketers, and made to expedite your journey to DAM success. \n<ul> \n <li>Take stock of the assets you already have with the <span style=\"font-weight: bold;\">Content Audit Template.</span></li> \n <li>Easily name your assets with the <span style=\"font-weight: bold;\">File Naming Convention Template.</span></li> \n <li>Create organized folders for your assets with the <span style=\"font-weight: bold;\">File Folder Structure Template.</span></li> \n</ul> [Cookie \"Get Your Digital Asset Management Templates || https://media.coschedule.com/uploads/2020/07/blog-digital-asset-management_the-complete-non-boring-guide-for-marketers-07.png || Download Now || https://media.coschedule.com/uploads/digital-asset-management-templates-1.zip\"] \n<div class=\"link-callout\">\n <strong><a href=\"https://coschedule.com/?p=82586#toc\">Back to the Top</a></strong>\n</div> \n<a name=\"easy\"></a> \n<h2><span style=\"font-weight: bold;\">How to Easily Get Started With DAM</span></h2> Now that you know WHY digital asset management matters, it’s time to figure out what your own DAM process could look like. What exactly do you need to start implementing DAM? We have six starting points that’ll help you successfully get your marketing assets in order. Begin with these steps to start building your own DAM process. \n<h3>1. Audit the Content You Already Have</h3> By taking stock of the assets you have, you’ll better understand how you should structure your new DAM system and which files will need to be updated. We included a \n<span style=\"font-weight: bold;\">Content Audit Template </span>in our bundle to help you easily audit your assets. Download it — if you haven’t already! \n<div class=\"link-callout\">\n <strong>Recommended Reading:</strong> \n <a href=\"https://coschedule.com/blog/getting-started-with-digital-asset-management/\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener noreferrer\">Getting Started With Digital Asset Management for Marketers</a>\n</div> Before you implement a digital asset management tool, you’ll want to get a better understanding of what content you already have. This helps you clear out outdated content, gives you a laundry list of things that need to be updated, and an idea of how to structure the metadata for your new DAM platform. In the content upgrade above, you’ll find a Content Audit Template Spreadsheet. \n<img class=\"drop-shadow alignnone\" src=\"https://media.coschedule.com/uploads/18b0000b-6f0e-44e1-94b8-5ea191ad5c74_Screenshot202019-07-172013.49.49.png\" alt=\"Content audit template spreadsheet.\" width=\"1327\" height=\"480\" /> Here’s how you use it. Begin filling out the columns. Add the title of the document, who produced it, who it was produced form, etc. Here’s what it will look like as you start. \n<img class=\"drop-shadow alignnone\" src=\"https://media.coschedule.com/uploads/bafb51e5-4389-4433-adfb-c1e3644b7d5e_Screenshot202019-07-172013.56.35.png\" alt=\"DAM content audit spreadsheet.\" width=\"1361\" height=\"215\" /> As you start your DAM content audit, be on the lookout for the following items: \n<ol> \n <li>Is the asset professional looking and on-brand?</li> \n <li>Is it supporting your business objectives?</li> \n <li>Does it need to be updated in anyway?</li> \n</ol> \n<h3><span style=\"font-family: -apple-system, BlinkMacSystemFont, 'Segoe UI', Roboto, Oxygen-Sans, Ubuntu, Cantarell, 'Helvetica Neue', sans-serif;\">2. Add Up the Cost of All That Wasted Time (Hint: It’s <em>E</em></span><em><span style=\"font-family: -apple-system, BlinkMacSystemFont, 'Segoe UI', Roboto, Oxygen-Sans, Ubuntu, Cantarell, 'Helvetica Neue', sans-serif;\">xpensive</span></em><span style=\"font-family: -apple-system, BlinkMacSystemFont, 'Segoe UI', Roboto, Oxygen-Sans, Ubuntu, Cantarell, 'Helvetica Neue', sans-serif;\">)</span></h3> Digital assets are often duplicated or re-created due to the inability of users to find what they need. This wastes precious time and resources. [Tweet \"Digital assets are often duplicated or re-created due to the inability of users to find what they need.\"] Here’s how to calculate the cost of duplicating work. Say you have 5,000 assets and 5% of them, on average, are re-created or duplicated due to inefficient file storage. This means that every year, approximately 250 resources are unnecessarily duplicated. Now, let’s say that your designer’s salary broken down to an hourly wage is about $25/hour and it takes them approximately 2 hours to re-create assets. This amounts to $12,500 lost per year. \n<img class=\"alignnone wp-image-84253 size-full\" src=\"https://media.coschedule.com/uploads/2020/07/calculate-cost.png\" alt=\"Calculate cost of duplicating assets.\" width=\"1361\" height=\"924\" /> \n<h3>3. Reduce Time Wasted Searching for Documents</h3> Team members spend a huge amount of time each day searching for information. When they can’t find what they’re looking for, they interrupt someone else to help them, which wastes additional resources. Here’s how to calculate those costs. Say you have 20 users who need to find assets and it takes them 10 minutes per day trying to find what they’re looking for. This means the team spends approximately 16 hours per week looking for things. This is 832 hours per year or about 41 hours per person per year. That’s a full week of work wasted every year. Now, let’s say that the average hourly wage of that team of 20 is $20/hour. This amounts to $16,640 lost per year. \n<img class=\"alignnone wp-image-84254 size-full\" src=\"https://media.coschedule.com/uploads/2020/07/search-for-documents.png\" alt=\"Calculate the cost of the time wasted searching for lost documents.\" width=\"1361\" height=\"923\" /> \n<span style=\"color: #000000;\">With just these two things alone, the example company will save over $29,000/year. That’s not to mention the additional productivity created through time-saving.</span> \n<h3>4. Check in with your stakeholders</h3> If your company is planning on implementing a new DAM process, it’ll likely be used by other people and teams across your organization. In addition to sharing the cost above with essential stakeholders, check in with them to determine a DAM solution that works for everybody. Start with people like the Head of Technology and Head of Finance. \n<div class=\"link-callout\">\n <strong>Recommended Reading:</strong> \n <a href=\"https://coschedule.com/blog/digital-asset-management-software/\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener noreferrer\">How to Get Better ROI on Your Marketing Assets With Digital Asset Management Software</a>\n</div> \n<h3>5. Start researching DAM tools</h3> If you’re looking for a tool to help you implement DAM, start researching different DAM providers and scheduling demos to test out those tools. We’ll highlight a few of those later in this blog. In the meantime, this \n<span style=\"text-decoration: underline;\"><a href=\"https://coschedule.com/blog/digital-asset-management-software-comparison/\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener noreferrer\">DAM software comparison</a></span>&nbsp;is a great starting point. \n<h3>6. Take your file naming to the next level</h3> When you create a file naming convention for your marketing assets, you’ll make them easy to find and organize whenever you need them. That saves you a TON of time. See \n<span style=\"text-decoration: underline;\"><a href=\"https://coschedule.com/blog/marketing-file-naming-conventions/\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener noreferrer\">how to develop your own naming structure</a></span>&nbsp;— and how to make sure your team follows it. \n<img class=\"alignnone wp-image-84255 size-full\" src=\"https://media.coschedule.com/uploads/2020/07/marketing-convention.png\" alt=\"Definition of a marketing file name convention.\" width=\"1361\" height=\"688\" /> \n<h3>7. Spruce up your marketing asset folders</h3> We know what you’re thinking; creating a bunch of new folders for your files from scratch sounds… honestly… BORING. Having those nice, clear, simple folders to house all of your assets will make you feel surprisingly accomplished. Guess what? We’ve made it way easier for you to create those folders with our \n<span style=\"font-weight: bold;\">Folder Structure Template</span>&nbsp;(it’s also part of our bundle). It’s a collection of pre-made folders that’ll get you organized even faster. \n<img class=\"alignnone wp-image-84256 size-full\" src=\"https://media.coschedule.com/uploads/2020/07/folder-structure.png\" alt=\"An example of a basic folder structure.\" width=\"1361\" height=\"1351\" /> \n<div class=\"link-callout\">\n <strong><a href=\"https://coschedule.com/?p=82586#toc\">Back to the Top</a></strong>\n</div> \n<a name=\"action\"></a> \n<h2><span style=\"font-weight: bold;\">DAM in Action: </span><span style=\"font-weight: bold;\">3</span><span style=\"font-weight: bold;\">&nbsp;Digital Asset Management Examples</span></h2> \n<strong>Recommended Reading:</strong> \n<a href=\"https://coschedule.com/blog/marketing-file-folder-structure-organizational-system-template/\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener noreferrer\">The Best Way to Organize Marketing Assets With Simple Folder Structures</a> Need an idea of exactly HOW digital asset management might look for certain marketing teams? Here are 3&nbsp;before-and-after use cases of DAM software in action. \n<h3><span style=\"font-weight: bold;\">1. Agencies</span></h3> \n<span style=\"font-weight: bold;\">Before DAM:</span>&nbsp;Agency marketers juggle a lot of clients--and a ton of files for each of those clients. Time is money, but there’s no quick way to find and distribute the right versions of those assets to the right people. \n<span style=\"font-weight: bold;\">After DAM: </span>With functional file naming and organizing, agency marketers always know where to find each asset for each client. Less time wasted searching for files means shorter production timelines and money saved. \n<img class=\"alignnone wp-image-84257 size-full\" src=\"https://media.coschedule.com/uploads/2020/07/agencies.png\" alt=\"What agencies look like after DAM.\" width=\"1361\" height=\"1165\" /> \n<h3><span style=\"font-weight: bold;\">2. Colleges and Universities</span></h3> \n<span style=\"font-weight: bold;\">Before DAM: </span>Marketers in higher ed need to create materials for many departments at once while maintaining overall brand consistency. A catalog of hundreds of photos and videos is needed to connect with students, staff, and alumni, but is nearly impossible to manage. \n<span style=\"font-weight: bold;\">After DAM:</span>&nbsp;With one place to store their entire collection of assets, marketers can easily divide them among folders for each department or campaign. And because&nbsp;they’re so easy to sort and share across departments, the assets stay totally on-brand. \n<img class=\"alignnone wp-image-84258 size-full\" src=\"https://media.coschedule.com/uploads/2020/07/schools.png\" alt=\"What colleges and universities look like after DAM.\" width=\"1361\" height=\"1165\" /> \n<h3><span style=\"font-weight: bold;\">3. In-House Marketing Teams</span></h3> \n<span style=\"font-weight: bold;\">Before DAM:</span>&nbsp;Marketers at tech companies can experience frustrating silos between teams. The latest assets can get lost in the shuffle between marketing, sales, and support teams, and customers can be misled by inaccurate versions of files. \n<span style=\"font-weight: bold;\">After DAM:</span>&nbsp;Sharing assets internally between teams is a breeze, so everyone has access to the latest product photos or marketing collateral. Because&nbsp;they’re used more effectively, these assets help marketers boost their ROI. \n<img class=\"alignnone wp-image-84259 size-full\" src=\"https://media.coschedule.com/uploads/2020/07/tech-companies.png\" alt=\"What tech companies look like after DAM.\" width=\"1361\" height=\"1165\" /> \n<div class=\"link-callout\">\n <strong><a href=\"https://coschedule.com/?p=82586#toc\">Back to the Top</a></strong>\n</div> \n<a name=\"dig\"></a> \n<h2><span style=\"font-weight: bold;\">How </span><span style=\"font-weight: bold;\">T</span><span style=\"font-weight: bold;\">o Dig Deeper Into </span><span style=\"font-weight: bold;\">Digital Asset Management Vendors</span></h2> At this point, you might be thinking that using a DAM tool sounds like a pretty great option. After all, it’s basically a software-based shortcut to finding, organizing, and storing all of your assets. [Tweet \"DAM is basically a software-based shortcut to finding, organizing, and storing all of your assets.\"] \n<span style=\"font-weight: bold;\">But h</span>\n<span style=\"font-weight: bold;\">ow do you know which DAM solutions are out there?</span> And where do you find out how each of them can help you better manage your digital assets? \n<span style=\"font-weight: bold;\">We already did all the hard work for you.</span> You might already know that \n<span style=\"text-decoration: underline;\"><a href=\"https://coschedule.com/marketing-suite/asset-organizer\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener noreferrer\">CoSchedule’s Asset Organizer</a></span>&nbsp;is one solution that can help get your entire collection of marketing assets organized in no time. But if you’d like to compare more DAM solutions, check out the in-depth roundup of DAM platforms below. It’ll help you decide which options might work best for your team. \n<strong>Recommended Reading:</strong> \n<a href=\"https://coschedule.com/blog/digital-asset-management-software-comparison/\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener noreferrer\">The Ultimate List of Top Digital Asset Management (DAM) Software Platforms</a> \n<h2>Questions to Ask DAM Vendors</h2> Choosing a DAM software is a big deal. There are a ton of things to think about and it can get a little overwhelming. Understanding your requirements and what features each DAM service provides can help the process run smoothly. Here are some items to make sure you check off in the early, exploratory stages. \n<h3>DAM UX Questions</h3> \n<ul> \n <li>How does the tool enable teams to accomplish their work?</li> \n <li>Regarding user adoption, is it intuitive to find what you’re looking for?</li> \n <li>Does the software offer a familiar and useful search experience?</li> \n</ul> \n<h3>DAM File Type Questions</h3> \n<ul> \n <li>What file types does the system support?</li> \n <li>Do all file types have previews?</li> \n</ul> \n<h3>DAM User Questions</h3> \n<ul> \n <li>How many users are included?</li> \n <li>Does the system limit the number of each type of user you can have?</li> \n <li>Does the provider charge for additional users? If so, how much?</li> \n</ul> \n<h3>DAM Storage Questions</h3> \n<ul> \n <li>How much storage in included standard?</li> \n <li>Can we add more as needed?</li> \n <li>What is the cost of adding additional storage capabilities?</li> \n <li>How does the system handle version history?</li> \n</ul> \n<h3>DAM Metadata Questions</h3> \n<ul> \n <li>Can we add customized metadata?</li> \n <li>What type of metadata is standard?</li> \n <li>Does metadata reside in the asset file?</li> \n <li>How do search methods and capabilities work?</li> \n</ul> \n<h3>DAM Onboarding Questions</h3> \n<ul> \n <li>Do you provide training and support?</li> \n <li>What channels do you provide support?</li> \n <li>Will we have a specific support contact?</li> \n</ul> \n<a name=\"wins\"></a> \n<div class=\"link-callout\">\n <strong><a href=\"https://coschedule.com/?p=82586#toc\">Back to the Top</a></strong>\n</div> \n<a name=\"conclusion\"></a> \n<h2><span style=\"font-weight: bold;\">How CoSchedule Can Help You Do DAM</span><span style=\"font-weight: bold;\"> (and Do It</span><span style=\"font-weight: bold;\">&nbsp;Well</span><span style=\"font-weight: bold;\">)</span></h2> Just one more thing before we send you off on your DAM journey. If you’re still looking for just the right digital asset management tool for your marketing team, we’ve got one right here. CoSchedule’s built-in \n<span style=\"text-decoration: underline;\"><a href=\"https://coschedule.com/marketing-suite/asset-organizer\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener noreferrer\">Asset Organizer</a></span>&nbsp;lets you: \n<ul> \n <li>Manage all of your assets in a single library</li> \n <li>Quickly find and securely share files</li> \n <li>Ensure you’re always using the latest versions</li> \n <li>Create custom tags to organize your files</li> \n</ul> Check it out and see how it can make managing your digital assets 10x LESS frustrating and 10x MORE rewarding. \n<a
