Marketing Strategy: How to Create a Remarkable Brand</a> – CoSchedule</li> \n </ol> \n</div> \n<h2>What Does a Marketing Plan Look Like?</h2> At their most basic, they're straight-forward planning docs that are usually formatted in Word. Here's an example for a quick look: [slideshare id=1126953&amp;doc=mktgplannoname-090310111111-phpapp02&amp;type=d] \n<h2>How to Write an Awesome Marketing Plan in 12 Steps</h2> The following 12 exercises will show you how to build each piece of your marketing plan. They are based on just some of the examples linked above. \n<div class=\"callout\"> \n <a name=\"toc\"></a>\n <strong>Table of Contents</strong> \n <ul> \n  <li><a href=\"https://coschedule.com/blog/?p=55628#toc\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener noreferrer\">Map Out a Table of Contents</a></li> \n  <li><a href=\"https://coschedule.com/blog/?p=55628#executive-summary-template\">Write an Executive Summary (Includes Template)</a></li> \n  <li><a href=\"https://coschedule.com/blog/?p=55628#mission-statement\">Write a Mission Statement</a></li> \n  <li><a href=\"https://coschedule.com/blog/?p=55628#goals\">Figure Out Your Goals</a></li> \n  <li><a href=\"https://coschedule.com/blog/?p=55628#standards\">Establish Content Standards of Performance</a></li> \n  <li><a href=\"https://coschedule.com/blog/?p=55628#competencies\">Determine Core Competencies</a></li> \n  <li><a href=\"https://coschedule.com/blog/?p=55628#swot\">Do a SWOT Analysis</a></li> \n  <li><a href=\"https://coschedule.com/blog/?p=55628#target-market\">Connect Your Message to Your Target Market</a></li> \n  <li><a href=\"https://coschedule.com/blog/?p=55628#audience-persona\">Create an Audience Persona</a></li> \n  <li><a href=\"https://coschedule.com/blog/?p=55628#go-to-market\">The 4 Ps and Your Go-to-Market Strategy</a></li> \n  <li><a href=\"https://coschedule.com/blog/?p=55628#budget\">Understand Your Budget</a></li> \n </ul> \n</div> \n<h2>Table of Contents With Numbered Pages to Easily Navigate Through the Plan</h2> Documented marketing plans can end up being lengthy, so having a \n<a href=\"https://support.office.com/en-us/article/Create-a-table-of-contents-or-update-a-table-of-contents-eb275189-b93e-4559-8dd9-c279457bfd72\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener noreferrer\">table of contents</a> will help you and others find their way around your plan. [Tweet \"Add a table of contents to your #marketing plan to help others find their way around it.\"] \n<h3>Write a Basic Marketing Plan Outline</h3> At a glance, these are the things that are typically included: \n<ul> \n <li>Map Out a Table of Contents</li> \n <li>Write an Executive Summary (Includes Template)</li> \n <li>Write a Mission Statement</li> \n <li>Figure Out Your Goals</li> \n <li>Establish Content Standards of Performance</li> \n <li>Determine Core Competencies</li> \n <li>Conduct a Situation Analysis</li> \n <li>Do a SWOT Analysis</li> \n <li>Connect Your Message to Your Target Market</li> \n <li>Create an Audience Persona</li> \n <li>The 4 Ps and Your Go-to-Market Strategy</li> \n <li>Pricing Strategy</li> \n <li>Marketing Tactics</li> \n <li>Create a Values Matrix</li> \n <li>Create a Budget</li> \n</ul> A few cool things that you might want to include in your marketing plan to spruce it up: \n<ul> \n <li><a href=\"http://coschedule.com/blog/visual-content-marketing/\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener noreferrer\">Include graphics</a> and graphs (tables, diagrams, and even pictures).</li> \n <li>A one-page marketing plan.</li> \n <li>An appendix of complementary research that proves&nbsp;your points.</li> \n</ul> You can go into as much detail as you'd like with your table of contents. Here is a great example, of a detailed table of contents by the&nbsp;\n<a href=\"http://www.paloalto.com/business_plan_software/sample_business_plans/\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener noreferrer\">Palo Alto Software</a>: \n<img class=\"aligncenter wp-image-56485 size-full\" src=\"https://coschedule.com/blog/wp-content/uploads/table-of-contents.png\" alt=\"Marketing plan table of contents example.\" width=\"770\" height=\"490\" /> \n<a href=\"https://coschedule.com/blog/?p=55628#top\">Back to the Top</a> \n<a name=\"executive-summary\"></a> \n<h2>Executive Summary to Sell Upper Management On Your Plan</h2> The executive summary provides a high-level \n<a href=\"http://coschedule.com/blog/marketing-objectives/\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener noreferrer\">overview of your&nbsp;marketing objectives</a>. \n<em>Write the executive summary last</em>. Leave a spot at the beginning of your marketing plan for your executive summary. Make things easier by downloading the complementary marketing plan template in this post. Ask yourself these questions as you work on your executive summary: \n<ul> \n <li>What types of customers are you targeting?</li> \n <li>What patents or products will you market specifically?</li> \n <li>What unique partnerships will you leverage to succeed?</li> \n <li>How is your&nbsp;marketing plan special?</li> \n <li>How will your&nbsp;company stand out?</li> \n <li>What problem are you solving?</li> \n <li>What is the solution?</li> \n <li>Why now?</li> \n</ul> Here's an executive summary template to get you started: \n<blockquote>\n [OUR COMPANY] offers [PRODUCT] to [TARGET CUSTOMER BASE] to help them [ACHIEVE GOAL]. Some of our leading product lines include [PRODUCT],&nbsp;[PRODUCT], and&nbsp;[PRODUCT]. Thanks to our unique position in the marketplace, we're able to easily leverage relationships with [PARTNER] and&nbsp;[PARTNER] to reach our customers. This marketing plan differentiates our strategy in the marketplace by focusing on [ACTIONABLE TACTICS]. By following this plan, [OUR COMPANY] will stand out amongst our competition by better addressing our customer's core concerns with more creativity and more targeted messaging. By clearly communicating how [PRODUCT] solves [PROBLEM] for [CUSTOMER], [OUR COMPANY] aims to achieve greater success for our organization and [CORE AUDIENCE] alike. With the release of [NEW PRODUCT/FEATURE] and [DISRUPTIVE TREND FOR YOUR AUDIENCE], now is the time to pivot our strategy toward our best customers' most pressing problems.\n</blockquote> [Tweet \"Make your project timely by asking yourself \"Why now?\" #marketing\"] \n<img class=\"alignnone wp-image-83839 size-full\" src=\"https://media.coschedule.com/uploads/2020/06/make-it-urgent.png\" alt=\"Make your project more timely by ensuring you make it urgent.\" width=\"1360\" height=\"577\" />\n<a href=\"https://coschedule.com/blog/?p=55628#top\">Back to the Top</a> \n<a name=\"mission-statement\"></a> \n<h2>Write a Mission Statement to Show What Is Most Important to Your Business</h2> Having a mission statement will remind you and your team of what is important. In order to do any of these marketing plan exercises, you'll have to ask yourself a ton of questions. You might have already noticed that. \n<ul> \n <li>What do we do?</li> \n <li>How do we do it?</li> \n <li>Who are we doing it for?</li> \n <li>What value does your blog or company bring to the table?</li> \n</ul> \n<div class=\"link-callout\">\n <strong>Recommended Reading:</strong>&nbsp;\n <a href=\"http://coschedule.com/blog/social-media-workflow/\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener noreferrer\">The Simple 6-Step Social Media Workflow That Will Get You More Organized</a>\n</div> \n<a href=\"https://coschedule.com/blog/?p=55628#top\">Back to the Top</a> \n<a name=\"goals\"></a> \n<h2>Figure Out What Your Goals Are</h2> It's also super important that you state your company's goals (financial and non-financial), so you know where you are headed and how much you can afford for certain things. \n<a href=\"https://blue-sky.co.uk/management-development/goal-setting\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener noreferrer\">Blue Sky</a> also provided a great example of their goals. \n<h3>Figure Out Your Financial Goals</h3> \n<ul> \n <li>What are your <a href=\"http://www.dummies.com/how-to/content/set-business-marketing-plan-goals-and-objectives.html\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener noreferrer\">business goals</a>?</li> \n <li>How much do you have to generate from your marketing efforts?</li> \n <li>What is your budget?</li> \n <li>What are some of the things you'd like to do?</li> \n <li>How many sales do you need to reach those goals?</li> \n</ul> [Tweet \"State your company's goals (financial and non-financial), so you know where you are headed.\"] \n<h3>Figure Out Your Non-Financial Goals</h3> Writing your goals is one of the first steps to reaching them. First off, you've probably seen blog posts on S.M.A.R.T. goals many times before, but they are really good to mention again. How to make your S.M.A.R.T. goals: \n<ul> \n <li><strong>S</strong>pecific: Is&nbsp;your goal clearly defined?</li> \n <li><strong>M</strong>easurable: Can you track your goal?</li> \n <li><strong>A</strong>spirational: Reach for the stars. Push yourself.</li> \n <li><strong>R</strong>ealistic: Are your goals realistic?</li> \n <li><strong>T</strong>imely: When do you want to reach your goals? What do you have to do to reach your goals and deadlines?</li> \n</ul> \n<img class=\"alignnone wp-image-83840 size-full\" src=\"https://media.coschedule.com/uploads/2020/06/smart-goals-1.png\" alt=\"Visual of what SMART goals are.\" width=\"1360\" height=\"578\" /> Now, write your goals and add them to your marketing plan. \n<a href=\"https://coschedule.com/blog/?p=55628#top\">Back to the Top</a> \n<a name=\"standards\"></a> \n<h2>Standards of Performance to Direct Content Development</h2> When writing your marketing plan, it's important to know what your standards of performance are, so you can continue bringing in bigger results or change up your current process to improve your content. To figure out your standards of performance,&nbsp;\n<strong>make a list of your latest content.</strong> \n<img class=\"aligncenter wp-image-56488 size-full\" src=\"https://coschedule.com/blog/wp-content/uploads/standards-of-performance-sheet.png\" alt=\"Standards of Performance\" width=\"770\" height=\"490\" /> Once you've entered&nbsp;your data into each field, ask yourself: \n<blockquote>\n What&nbsp;are the characteristics of my top-performing content according to my company's goals?\n</blockquote> For example, there are four pillars that&nbsp;we make sure to implement in all CoSchedule content: \n<ul> \n <li>Is the<strong> <em>keyword</em> </strong>well-chosen (for search volume and difficulty) and optimized throughout the post to help me get long-term traffic?</li> \n <li>Was this<strong> <em>topic</em>&nbsp;</strong>something my readers would want to learn more about?</li> \n <li>Was this post deeply<strong> <em>researched</em> </strong>to share unique and better information than any other source on the internet?</li> \n <li>Did the post turn the research into<strong> <em>comprehensive, how-to advice?</em></strong></li> \n</ul> Grade each piece of content against your standards of performance with a scale from one to three. A score of three means it’s awesome, and one is not so good. For more information on figuring out your standards of performance, check out our post on \n<a href=\"https://coschedule.com/blog/annual-content-calendar-template/\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener noreferrer\">rocking your data-driven content calendar template</a>. \n<a href=\"https://coschedule.com/blog/?p=55628#top\">Back to the Top</a> \n<a name=\"competencies\"></a> \n<h2>Core Competencies to Help You Choose the Right Projects</h2> Remind your company about what they do well and show them how you plan to stand up against rivals. If you don't know what your company does well, find out by meeting with your team and discussing it. Ask yourself unique questions to get yourself thinking about your core competencies in a different light, rather than just wondering what you and your company do well.&nbsp;\n<a href=\"http://www.davidmeermanscott.com/hubfs/documents/Marketing_Strategy_Template.pdf\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener noreferrer\">David Meerman Scott has a great example</a>&nbsp;of this. Get out an Excel spreadsheet and type out the answers to these questions: \n<ul> \n <li>What makes you and your company remarkable?</li> \n <li>What value do you bring?</li> \n <li>What proof do we have that you are the best?</li> \n</ul> \n<h3>Instead of Planning Another Meeting, You Could Also Send Your Team a Google Form</h3> \n<strong>First off, go to <a href=\"https://www.google.com/forms/about/\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener noreferrer\">Google Forms</a>.</strong> Pick out the kind of Google Form you'd like to send. \n<img class=\"aligncenter wp-image-56489 size-full\" src=\"https://coschedule.com/blog/wp-content/uploads/create-google-form.png\" alt=\"Choose a type of Google form.\" width=\"770\" height=\"176\" /> Once you click there, it will open to something like this — depending on which one you chose: \n<img class=\"aligncenter wp-image-56490 size-full\" src=\"https://coschedule.com/blog/wp-content/uploads/core-competency.png\" alt=\"Add fields to your form.\" width=\"770\" height=\"467\" /> \n<strong>You will be asked to give the Google Form a title and a description.</strong> Add your first question and press on the gray bar — right of the question — to change up the questions you want to ask. \n<img class=\"aligncenter wp-image-56491 size-full\" src=\"https://coschedule.com/blog/wp-content/uploads/title-and-description.png\" alt=\"Add a title and description.\" width=\"770\" height=\"545\" /> Pick \n<strong>Paragraph</strong> to let your team write as much as they'd like. Ask these questions: \n<ul> \n <li>What are our strengths as a team?</li> \n <li>What are our strengths as a company?</li> \n <li>What are the strengths of our product?</li> \n <li>How can we (are we) be the best in our industry/niche?</li> \n</ul> \n<img class=\"aligncenter wp-image-56492 size-full\" src=\"https://coschedule.com/blog/wp-content/uploads/add-questions.png\" alt=\"Add questions.\" width=\"770\" height=\"356\" /> Click on the plus sign to add another question. You can also add pictures or videos here. Once you are done, you can send an email to your team members with the Google Form link. Before sending the email, make sure you read and include the questions from Exercise #7. [Tweet \"Find out what your company's strengths are, so you can stand against your rivals.\"] \n<a href=\"https://coschedule.com/blog/?p=55628#top\">Back to the Top</a>\n<a name=\"swot\"></a> \n<h2>Create a Situational Analysis to Understand the Business Environment</h2> In order to thrive in your environment, you first need to understand it. This is what your situational analysis will accomplish. \n<strong>Company Outline:</strong> \n<ol> \n <li>Statistics about company size, locations, employees, etc.</li> \n <li>Tagline</li> \n <li>Unique Selling Proposition</li> \n <li>Sector</li> \n <li>Brand awareness</li> \n</ol> \n<strong>Customer Outline:</strong> \n<ol> \n <li>Age</li> \n <li>Income level</li> \n <li>Geographic location</li> \n <li>Socio-economic status</li> \n <li>Purchase tendencies</li> \n <li>Education level</li> \n</ol> \n<strong>Competitor Outline:&nbsp;</strong> Provide a list of each competitor, their products, and how they directly compete with your company (i.e. where they are strong and weak in comparison to your company). \n<strong>Environmental Factors:</strong> Determine the environmental factors (both internal and external), which can include economic or sociological factors that impact your business's performance. \n<h2>SWOT Analysis to Understand How You'll Differentiate Yourself</h2> It's important to have your strengths, weaknesses, opportunities, and threats at a glance. Then you can see what you need to improve. \n<img class=\"alignnone wp-image-83841 size-full\" src=\"https://media.coschedule.com/uploads/2020/06/swot-analysis.png\" alt=\"How to run a SWOT analysis.\" width=\"1360\" height=\"690\" /> When you meet, discuss these questions as a team: \n<strong>Strength (internal):&nbsp;</strong>What are your company and/or product's strengths? \n<strong>Weaknesses&nbsp;<strong>(internal):&nbsp;</strong></strong>How about your&nbsp;company and/or product's&nbsp;weaknesses? \n<strong>Opportunities&nbsp;<strong>(external):&nbsp;</strong></strong>What opportunities do you/we have? \n<strong>Threats&nbsp;<strong><strong>(external):&nbsp;</strong></strong></strong>What are your/our threats? Who are you/we competing against? [Tweet \"These are the things you should include in your S.W.O.T. analysis:\"] On a few of the different marketing plans I've seen, they put their S.W.O.T. quadrant into their appendix section. To see an example, scroll to extra tip #1. \n<div class=\"callout\">\n <strong>Pro Tip:</strong> When you write your S.W.O.T. analysis in your marketing plan, go in-depth in each of the categories.\n</div> \n<div></div> \n<div class=\"callout\">\n <a href=\"https://coschedule.com/blog/?p=55628#top\">Back to the Top</a> \n <a name=\"target-market\"></a>\n</div> \n<h2>Connect Your Message With Your Target Market</h2> You'll need to take a look at your Google Analytics to \n<a href=\"https://coschedule.com/blog/how-to-find-your-target-audience/\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener noreferrer\">figure out your&nbsp;target market</a>. You'll want to find the answers to these questions: \n<ul> \n <li>What is the majority of your audience's gender?</li> \n <li>How about their age range?</li> \n <li>Where are most of them located?</li> \n</ul> First off, it's super important to know who is currently following you. Read on to find out who your current audience is. \n<h3>Want to Find Out Who Your Current Audience Is?</h3> Click into&nbsp;\n<a href=\"https://analytics.google.com/analytics/\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener noreferrer\">Google Analytics</a>. On the left side, you'll see \n<strong>Audience</strong>. Click on it and scroll down to click \n<strong>Demographics</strong>&nbsp;and \n<strong>Overview</strong>. \n<img class=\"drop-shadow alignnone wp-image-83486 size-full\" src=\"https://media.coschedule.com/uploads/2020/06/Blog_Marketing-Plan-Samples_Header-copy-4.png\" alt=\"Analytics demographics overview.\" width=\"1222\" height=\"801\" /> For more in-depth information on each of the demographics, you can click \n<strong>Age</strong> and \n<strong>Gender</strong>. \n<img class=\"aligncenter wp-image-56495 size-full\" src=\"https://media.coschedule.com/uploads/age-gender-1.png\" alt=\"Find age and gender in Google Analytics.\" width=\"770\" height=\"424\" /> If you click on the \n<strong>Age</strong> tab underneath demographics, you'll see a more in-depth graph. \n<img class=\"aligncenter wp-image-56496 size-full\" src=\"https://coschedule.com/blog/wp-content/uploads/age-demographics.png\" alt=\"Find Age under Demographics in Google Analytics.\" width=\"770\" height=\"424\" /> Hover over one of the blue dots to see how many sessions you had and how old each of those people were. If you click on the \n<strong>Interests</strong> tab on the left side, you'll be brought to this page, which will show you their interests. \n<img class=\"aligncenter wp-image-56497 size-full\" src=\"https://media.coschedule.com/uploads/find-interests.png\" alt=\"Find interests in Google Analytics.\" width=\"770\" height=\"321\" /> In that same audience section of Google Analytics, you can click on \n<strong>Overview</strong>, and then you'll see a button underneath demographics that gives you a choice to look at which countries people are tuning in from. Then you'll know their location. After you know your current audience, it's important to take a look at who you'd like your target audience to be. \n<h3>How to Find Your Target Audience</h3> Ask yourself these questions to figure out who your target audience is: \n<ul> \n <li>What are their pain points? Keep in mind the audience that you want to attract.</li> \n <li>What problem does your company/blog/product solve for them?</li> \n <li>Who is your competition?</li> \n <li>What will your customers gain from your company/blog/product?</li> \n</ul> There's so much more on finding your target audience that we haven't covered yet. It would take a whole post to discuss that. Fortunately, you're in luck. We have a post on that \n<a href=\"http://coschedule.com/blog/how-to-find-your-target-audience/\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener noreferrer\">here</a>. \n<a href=\"https://coschedule.com/blog/?p=55628#top\">Back to the Top</a> \n<a name=\"audience-persona\"></a> \n<h2>Create an Audience Persona to Help You Know Who You're Writing Content For</h2> Take the information you found in the target audience exercise and ask yourself these questions to figure out your audience persona. [Tweet \"Create an audience persona, so you can target your content and products more.\"] \n<strong>An awesome persona answers these questions:</strong> \n<ul> \n <li>Who are they?</li> \n <li>What is their personality?</li> \n <li>How about their family life?</li> \n <li>What are their values?</li> \n <li>What do they do?</li> \n <li>What is their job title?</li> \n <li>Where do they work?</li> \n <li>Where do they live?</li> \n <li>What's their income level?</li> \n <li>What are their challenges?</li> \n <li>How about their pain points?</li> \n <li>What are their needs?</li> \n</ul> \n<div class=\"link-callout\">\n <strong>Recommended Reading:</strong>&nbsp;\n <a href=\"http://coschedule.com/blog/smarter-content/\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener noreferrer\">Using Google Analytics to Write Smarter Content</a>\n</div> It's easy to forget to ask questions that will really open up the psyche of your persona, so you can really pull the emotion into your content and business. Emotion sells. \n<ul> \n <li>What scares them?</li> \n <li>What are their life beliefs?</li> \n <li>What stresses them out?</li> \n <li>Favorite books, movies, and music?</li> \n <li>What keeps them up at night?</li> \n</ul> Go in deep when you are figuring out who your user persona is. Then go online to find a picture of them. \n<img class=\"aligncenter wp-image-55837 size-full\" src=\"https://coschedule.com/blog/wp-content/uploads/30-marketing-plan-samples-21.png\" alt=\"Photo of Blogger Brian.\" width=\"770\" height=\"698\" /> \n<div class=\"link-callout\">\n <strong>&nbsp;</strong>\n</div> \n<a href=\"https://coschedule.com/blog/?p=55628#top\">Back to the Top</a> \n<a name=\"go-to-market\"></a> \n<h2>Find the Four Marketing Ps to Help You Understand Your Go-to-Market Strategy</h2> In order to do marketing efficiently, you need to keep the four P's of marketing in mind: product, place, price, and promotion. \n<strong>Recommended Reading:</strong> \n<a href=\"http://coschedule.com/blog/google-analytics-reports/\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener noreferrer\">3 Hidden Google Analytics Reports to Help You Understand Your Audience</a> \n<h3>What Product Are You Marketing? (Product)</h3> Set your user persona and target audience next to you when you fill out these questions: \n<ul> \n <li>What is it that our audience wants?</li> \n <li>Why do they need it?</li> \n <li>What makes it special and different? Why should your audience care?</li> \n</ul> \n<h3>Where Should You Sell Your Product? (Place)</h3> \n<ul> \n <li>How will you sell your product?</li> \n <li>Are you selling it in a physical store or on E-commerce?</li> \n</ul> \n<h3>How Much Should You Sell It For? (Price)</h3> \n<ul> \n <li>Is it a good value for what your audience would be getting?</li> \n <li>How does the price compare with your competitors and others in the market?</li> \n</ul> \n<h3>How Are You Going to Promote It? (Promotion)</h3> \n<ul> \n <li>Where are you going to promote your content/product?</li> \n <li>How are you getting it in front of people?</li> \n <li>Will you do ads? If so, where will you do them?</li> \n</ul> Here's a helpful video that is thorough and simple. https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=ft8QvCJQgik \n<p class=\"p1\">To illustrate the whole idea a little better for you let's imagine you're selling some rad shoes with wings that you've created.</p> \n<p class=\"p1\"><strong>Product:</strong></p> \n<ul> \n <li><strong>What is it that your audience wants?</strong> Awesome shoes that will fly you all over. You know, like the shoes that had wings on them in Greek Mythology? Yes, just like Hermes and his flying shoes.</li> \n <li><strong>Why do they need it?</strong>&nbsp;It'll cut down&nbsp;on gas prices and also encourage people to get out more.</li> \n <li><strong>What makes it special and different?</strong>&nbsp;Well, they sorta have wings. I'd say that definitely makes them different.</li> \n</ul> \n<strong>Place:</strong> \n<ul> \n <li><strong>How would you sell your product?</strong> I'd sell them online (on my website) and in stores.</li> \n</ul> \n<strong>Price:</strong> \n<ul> \n <li><strong>Is it a good value for what your audience would be getting?</strong> I'd probably charge a lot of money for these shoes because they are definitely a great value for flying shoes. I mean, where else can you find such awesome shoes with wings?</li> \n <li><strong>How does the price compare with your competitors and others in the market?</strong> Well, I don't have any competitors, so I'd say the price sets the mark for this product.</li> \n</ul> \n<strong>Promotion:</strong> \n<ul> \n <li><strong>Where are you going to promote your content/product?</strong> On my website, in shoe stores, and introduce them to the athletes who perform in the Olympics. Who knows, maybe a new sport will be created because of these shoes.</li> \n <li><strong>How are you getting it in front of people? </strong>I'd send a pair to influencers, artists, and sport stars. I'd also do an awesome job with my branding. The shoe box would be super cool. Shoelaces would be different colors and even some sparkly tissue paper instead of the newspaper colored tissue paper you usually see stuck in the shoes at department stores. My aim would be to make everyone feel like flying superstars.</li> \n <li><strong>Will you do ads? If so, where will you do them? </strong>I don't think I'd need to do much advertising once it got out there&nbsp;because I think shoes that allowed you to fly would pretty much sell themselves.</li> \n</ul> Even though I used a mythological product idea in this example, you get the point. But, man, I'd love to have a pair of those shoes. Create your 4 Ps for your product and make it jump off the page at your audience. \n<a href=\"https://coschedule.com/blog/?p=55628#top\">Back to the Top</a> \n<a name=\"ongoing-plan\"></a> \n<h2>Create a Pricing Strategy</h2> Before you define your price, it's best to nail down your positioning, branding, and distribution channels. This ensures that your pricing doesn't negatively affect brand strategy or the company's values. The pricing strategy you choose will greatly influence how the market perceives your brand, so it's important to get it right. \n<h3>Match Your Pricing Strategy to Your Value Proposition</h3> Your price needs to be consistent with the perceived value of your product. If your product is too expensive to it's perceived value, it won't sell. Whereas, if your product is too affordable in relation to it's perceived value you risk losing out on revenue and potentially damaging your brand. After all, a luxury usually comes with a price. \n<h3>Analyze Competitor Prices</h3> Look at a wide variety of competitors to see how you are priced in comparison. This ensures that you are still pricing your products according to your brand strategy. \n<h3>Determine Price Sensitivity</h3> Higher price tags usually mean that your company with sell at a lower volume. Volume isn't the only to consider, though. You may generate more total revenue and/or profit with fewer units at a higher price. This depends largely on if your customers are extremely price-sensitive. \n<img class=\"alignnone wp-image-83842 size-full\" src=\"https://media.coschedule.com/uploads/2020/06/manufacture-costs.png\" alt=\"Manufacturing costs of a Burberry coat.\" width=\"1360\" height=\"846\" /> Burberry's customers are less price-sensitive, so the company can move less volume at a higher price tag, yet generate more total profit. The Gap version, on the other hand, moves greater volume at a much lower price due to tighter margins. \n<h2>Marketing Tactics + Checklist</h2> What will be your ongoing marketing plan? What do you want to do? Where do you want to do it? In order to plan your future marketing, you have to know these things. Set up an ongoing marketing plan for the year. What things will need to be done. I found this great sample example from the \n<a href=\"https://www.scribd.com/document/133378695/Tips-for-Developing-a-Marketing-Plan-Heavenly-Pies-Example\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener noreferrer\">Agricultural Development Center at the University of Tennessee</a>. It's so easy to see it all at a glance. You'll know exactly what goals you'll need to hit monthly. \n<img class=\"alignnone wp-image-83843 size-full\" src=\"https://media.coschedule.com/uploads/2020/06/marketing-plan-checklist.png\" alt=\"An example of a marketing plan checklist.\" width=\"1361\" height=\"1521\" /> \n<a href=\"https://coschedule.com/blog/?p=55628#top\">Back to the Top</a> \n<a name=\"budget\"></a> \n<h2>Create a Values Matrix</h2> A values matrix helps you prioritize all the tactics that you have come up with. Essentially, it helps you choose the tactics that have the highest business value and take the least amount of resources to implement. \n<img class=\"alignnone wp-image-83844 size-full\" src=\"https://media.coschedule.com/uploads/2020/06/value-complexity-matrix.png\" alt=\"Quadrants of the value-complexity matrix.\" width=\"1361\" height=\"1233\" /> Business “value” depends on strategic objectives. This could include a campaign's usefulness in increasing sales, increasing website visitors, generating leads, or increasing brand awareness. The most valuable marketing campaigns, initiatives, or activities are the ones that are tied closest to the business's overall objective. Implementation “complexity” encompasses the time it takes to implement, internal resources needed, and design costs. \n<strong>High-value, low-complexity:</strong> “Easy wins” that should be considered for your plan. \n<strong>High-value, high-complexity:</strong> Larger strategic initiatives that require effort and time but pay enormous dividends. \n<strong>Low-value, low-complexity:</strong> Might or might not be worth your time. Revisit these features later or brainstorm ways to make them of higher value. \n<strong>Low-value, high-complexity:</strong> Items that should be deprioritized. \n<h2>Budget to Understand Where You'll Spend Cash and Find Gaps</h2> You need to estimate how much&nbsp;your&nbsp;marketing projects are going to be.&nbsp;You'll be able to put&nbsp;together&nbsp;a budget to keep everyone on track over the course of the year. Marketing costs and needs vary quite a bit. There is no easy way to figure out what your marketing budget should be, but starting with your needs and wants is a great place to start. \n<img class=\"alignnone wp-image-83845 size-full\" src=\"https://media.coschedule.com/uploads/2020/06/dave-ramsey.png\" alt=\"Quote from Dave Ramsey about budget.\" width=\"1360\" height=\"537\" /> What's important is that you know what your needs and wants are. Answer these questions: \n<ul> \n <li>What does your content or business <strong>need</strong> when it comes to spending on marketing? This will help you narrow down the most important things that you currently need.</li> \n <li>What does your content or business <strong>want</strong> when it comes to spending?</li> \n <li>How much <strong>can</strong> you spend monthly?</li> \n</ul> Next for the needs and wants, write down how much it's going to cost. After doing that for all of your needs, you can start to see how much you can budget for your wants. Scroll down for a great example of what you could include in your appendix that has to do with budgeting and your financial goals. \n<div class=\"link-callout\">\n <strong>Recommended Reading:</strong>&nbsp;\n <a href=\"http://coschedule.com/blog/marketing-on-a-budget/\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener noreferrer\">How To Do Outstanding Marketing On A Limited Budget</a>\n</div> \n<a href=\"https://coschedule.com/blog/?p=55628#top\">Back to the Top</a> \n<h2 class=\"p1\">Bonus&nbsp;Challenge: Can You Fit Your Plan on One Page?</h2> What if a full documented marketing plan feels excessive for your needs? If that's the case for you, try paring it down to the bare essentials. You might even be able to squeeze it down to just one page with the most important information you need to guide your strategy. \n<p class=\"p1\">In this example, we have a one-page sheet you can glance at to see the most important information from your marketing plan. You might consider following a similar template:</p> \n<img class=\"alignnone wp-image-83846 size-full\" src=\"https://media.coschedule.com/uploads/2020/06/content-marketing-plan.png\" alt=\"One page content marketing plan.\" width=\"1360\" height=\"1683\" /> \n<h2>Now You Know What It Takes to Write an Awesome Marketing Plan</h2> \n<p class=\"p1\"><span class=\"s1\">Since you have a ton of marketing plan samples — and the awesome marketing plan download — you're set to be a rock star in the marketing realm. </span></p> \n<p class=\"p1\"><span class=\"s1\">Just make sure you wear your shoes with the wings.</span></p> [Tweet \"34 Marketing Plan Samples and Everything You Need to Include In Your Strategy\"] \n<em>This post was originally published on August 15, 2016. It was updated with new images and information on June 22, 2020.</em>\n<p>The post <a rel=\"nofollow\" href=\"https://coschedule.com/blog/marketing-plan-samples-and-templates/\">34 Marketing Plan Samples and 7 Templates to Build Your Strategy</a> appeared first on <a rel=\"nofollow\" href=\"https://coschedule.com\">CoSchedule Blog</a>.</p>","descriptionType":"html","publishedDate":"Mon, 22 Jun s://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx4/cdn92@2020_6/2020/08/24/21-56-37-080_43faaa42e4325dae.webp","https://coschedule.com/blog/wp-content/uploads/age-demographics.png":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx24/cdn24@2020_1/2020/08/24/21-56-37-549_9b504c923d6969dc.webp","https://media.coschedule.com/uploads/find-interests.png":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx27/cdn51@2020_3/2020/08/24/21-56-39-471_704fdf3f4f38852b.webp","https://coschedule.com/blog/wp-content/uploads/30-marketing-plan-samples-21.png":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx12/cdn31@2020_1/2020/08/24/21-56-36-421_a6ffd0ed0f155624.webp","https://media.coschedule.com/uploads/2020/06/manufacture-costs.png":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx31/cdn52@2020_5/2020/08/24/21-56-38-010_db3abc40d21e3e65.webp","https://media.coschedule.com/uploads/2020/06/marketing-plan-checklist.png":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx30/cdn99@2020_5/2020/08/24/21-56-35-310_dcc543b198d213d3.webp","https://media.coschedule.com/uploads/2020/06/value-complexity-matrix.png":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx/cdn84@2020_6/2020/08/24/21-56-35-134_b2c3c6b196608bf8.webp","https://media.coschedule.com/uploads/2020/06/dave-ramsey.png":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx19/cdn59@2020_6/2020/08/24/21-56-34-985_785915e71a782a73.webp","https://media.coschedule.com/uploads/2020/06/content-marketing-plan.png":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx18/cdn43@2020_3/2020/08/24/21-56-39-391_c053b59b200d572a.webp"},"publishedOrCreatedDate":1598306169704},{"createdTime":"2020-08-25 05:56:09","updatedTime":"2020-08-25 05:56:09","title":"The Best Email Marketing Calendar Template You Need to Organize Your Newsletters","link":"https://coschedule.com/blog/?p=53803","description":"<img class=\"alignnone wp-image-85426 size-full\" width=\"1361\" height=\"581\" /> Successful email marketing is all about consistency and delivering the right message, to the right audience, at the right time. How do you keep all your email content scheduled and organized effectively in order to meet these expectations? The answer? An email marketing calendar. They're an essential tool for planning, scheduling, and organizing your content and delivery dates to keep your strategy on track. Here are some things they can help you achieve: \n<ul> \n <li>Plan the content you'll share via email ahead of time.</li> \n <li>Provide team-wide visibility into <a href=\"https://coschedule.com/blog/email-marketing-strategy-template/\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener noreferrer\">your email strategy and execution</a>.</li> \n <li>Help you track your sends and hit deadlines.</li> \n</ul> Plus, getting organized is highly correlated with marketing success. In fact, according to CoSchedule research, \n<strong><a href=\"https://coschedule.com/marketing-statistics/\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener noreferrer\">it can help marketers be 397% more successful</a></strong>. That's nothing to sneeze at. [Tweet \"The Best Email Calendar Template You Need to Manage Email Marketing via @CoSchedule\"] \n<h2>Download Your Email Marketing Calendar Template...</h2> Make it easy on yourself and download your \n<strong>email marketing calendar template</strong>. This easy-to-use Excel spreadsheet will give you and your email marketing team the bird’s eye view you need to keep every sent email campaign organized. Easily connect your preferred email platform to CoSchedule with just a couple clicks.</li> \n <li><strong>Write click-worthy email subject lines every time</strong>. With email marketing, it’s easy to see how your email campaigns relate to the rest of your marketing strategy, and quickly make adjustments, if necessary.</li> \n</ul> Join the \n<a class=\"link-callout\"> \n <a name=\"toc\"></a>\n <strong>Table of Contents</strong> \n <ul> \n  <li><a href=\"https://coschedule.com/blog/?p=53803#one\">Determine Who Owns Each Email Campaign</a></li> \n  <li><a href=\"https://coschedule.com/blog/?p=53803#two\">Determine Email Topics and Themes</a></li> \n  <li><a href=\"https://coschedule.com/blog/?p=53803#three\">Keep Up With the Status of Each Campaign</a></li> \n  <li><a href=\"https://coschedule.com/blog/?p=53803#four\">Identify the Email Types That You’ll Send to Your Subscribers</a></li> \n  <li><a href=\"https://coschedule.com/blog/?p=53803#five\">Define the Number of Emails That Will Be Sent for This Campaign</a></li> \n  <li><a href=\"https://coschedule.com/blog/?p=53803#six\">Account for Email Campaign Seasonality</a></li> \n  <li><a href=\"https://coschedule.com/blog/?p=53803#seven\">Define the Marketing Persona</a></li> \n  <li><a href=\"https://coschedule.com/blog/?p=53803#eight\">Identify the Email Segment</a></li> \n  <li><a href=\"https://coschedule.com/blog/?p=53803#nine\">Consider Your Email Suppression List</a></li> \n  <li><a href=\"https://coschedule.com/blog/?p=53803#ten\">Clarify the Goal of Your Email Campaign</a></li> \n  <li><a href=\"https://coschedule.com/blog/?p=53803#eleven\">Write Your Email&nbsp;Subject Lines</a></li> \n  <li><a href=\"https://coschedule.com/blog/?p=53803#twelve\">Determine the Dates and Times Each Email Will Be Sent</a></li> \n  <li><a href=\"https://coschedule.com/blog/?p=53803#thirteen\">Plan Your Email Content</a></li> \n  <li><a href=\"https://coschedule.com/blog/?p=53803#fourteen\">Include Links to Graphics and Videos</a></li> \n  <li><a href=\"https://coschedule.com/blog/?p=53803#fifteen\">Record the A/B Test Results of Your Subject Lines</a></li> \n  <li><a href=\"https://coschedule.com/blog/?p=53803#coschedule\">How to Plan, Organize, and Schedule Email Content With CoSchedule</a></li> \n  <li><a href=\"https://coschedule.com/blog/?p=53803#conclusion\">Start Using Your Email Marketing Calendar to Get Organized</a></li> \n </ul> &nbsp; \n</div> \n<a name=\"one\"></a> \n<h2>Step 1: Determine Who Owns Each Email Campaign</h2> The first thing you need to identify in your email marketing calendar is who owns each campaign. This person is the point-man for every aspect of a campaign and ensures it goes off without a hitch. The primary duties of this role will be: \n<ul> \n <li><strong>Writing email subject lines and body content.</strong></li> \n <li><strong>Collaborating with designers to create email graphics, if necessary.</strong></li> \n <li><strong>Determining which list segments will receive the email.</strong></li> \n</ul> The owners of each project should be recorded in your email marketing calendar. \n<img class=\"drop-shadow aligncenter wp-image-73952 size-full\" src=\"https://media.coschedule.com/uploads/email-campaign-owner.png\" alt=\"Where to list email campaign owner\" width=\"1360\" height=\"272\" /> \n<div class=\"link-callout\">\n <strong>Action Item:</strong> Select your email project owner&nbsp;for each campaign.\n <span style=\"font-weight: bold;\">&nbsp;</span>This person may change depending on the campaign that needs to be created by your email marketing team.\n</div> \n<div class=\"link-callout\">\n <strong><a href=\"https://coschedule.com/blog/?p=53803#toc\">Back to the Top</a></strong>\n</div> \n<a name=\"two\"></a> \n<h2>Step 2: Determine Email Topics and Themes</h2> Before you begin planning your campaign, you need to decide what topics your emails will cover. Are you launching a new product or promoting an upcoming webinar, or are you hoping to provide new subscribers with helpful introduction content? Work with your team to decide the topic each email of your campaign will cover. Some common themes are: \n<ul> \n <li><strong>New product launch</strong></li> \n <li><strong>Upcoming webinar</strong></li> \n <li><strong>Weekly newsletter (topics will change week to week)</strong></li> \n <li><strong>New content you’ve written</strong></li> \n <li><strong>New functionality for your existing product</strong></li> \n <li><strong>Upcoming sale or event</strong></li> \n</ul> \n<img class=\"drop-shadow aligncenter wp-image-73953 size-full\" src=\"https://media.coschedule.com/uploads/email-topic.png\" alt=\"Email topic or purpose\" width=\"1360\" height=\"256\" /> \n<div class=\"link-callout\"> \n <strong>Action Items:</strong> \n <ol> \n  <li>Work with your email marketing team to determine the topics for each of your campaigns.</li> \n  <li>Record each topic in your email marketing calendar template that complements this article.</li> \n </ol> \n</div> \n<div class=\"link-callout\">\n <strong><a href=\"https://coschedule.com/blog/?p=53803#toc\">Back to the Top</a></strong>\n</div> \n<a name=\"three\"></a> \n<h2>Step 3: Keep Up With the Status of Each Campaign</h2> Your email marketing calendar should show the status of each of your email marketing campaigns. That way you, as a manager, can see what’s coming up, what’s staged and ready to send, and what your team is working on next. Break down the status of your campaign into three sections: \n<ul> \n <li><span style=\"font-weight: bold;\">New: </span>This is a new campaign that has recently been added to your calendar. No one on your email marketing team has touched this campaign.</li> \n <li><span style=\"font-weight: bold;\">In-progress: </span>Your email team is working on content, graphics, and more for this email. Once they are complete, they will move on to the project owner for final review.</li> \n <li><span style=\"font-weight: bold;\">Complete:&nbsp;</span>At this point, the email has been designed, subject lines are written, and the project owner is confident that this email is ready to be sent to the identified list.</li> \n</ul> Update the status of each of your campaigns regularly (at least weekly) in your template. \n<img class=\"drop-shadow aligncenter wp-image-73954 size-full\" src=\"https://media.coschedule.com/uploads/campaign-status-1.png\" alt=\"Where to denote campaign status\" width=\"1360\" height=\"255\" /> \n<div class=\"link-callout\"> \n <strong>Action Items:</strong> \n <ol> \n  <li>Set up weekly syncs with your email marketing team.</li> \n  <li>Review any new campaigns that have been added to the calendar. Update their status.</li> \n  <li>Review the in-progress campaigns. Update their status as&nbsp;needed.</li> \n  <li>Review completed campaigns. Update their status in your email marketing calendar template when done.</li> \n </ol> \n</div> \n<div class=\"link-callout\">\n <strong><a href=\"https://coschedule.com/blog/?p=53803#toc\">Back to the Top</a></strong>\n</div> \n<a name=\"four\"></a> \n<h2>Step 4: Identify the Email Types That You’ll Send to Your Subscribers</h2> Next, you need to identify what types of emails you want to send to your list. There are many different types of email that a marketing team can send but the most common are: \n<span style=\"font-weight: bold;\">Informational Emails</span> \n<ul> \n <li>These are emails that provide subscribers with helpful information that shows them how to solve potential problems they are facing.</li> \n <li>These emails can be anything from newsletters to an email pitching a specific piece of content.</li> \n <li>Helpful emails are usually placed at the beginning of your campaigns.</li> \n</ul> \n<span style=\"font-weight: bold;\">Pitch Emails</span> \n<ul> \n <li>These emails position your product as the best solution for the problems your audience is facing.</li> \n <li>They mention your product directly and focus on the benefits of using your product over another.</li> \n <li>At this point in your campaign, you want to show your readers that you understand their pain and know how to help them.</li> \n</ul> \n<span style=\"font-weight: bold;\">Follow-Up Emails</span> \n<ul> \n <li>Follow up&nbsp;emails help remind your customers that you offer the best solution to their problem and that they should buy from you.</li> \n <li>These come to your audience a few days after your last pitch email.</li> \n <li>They act as gentle reminders that the solution to their problem is right at their fingertips.</li> \n</ul> Identify which emails you’re sending on your calendar. \n<img class=\"drop-shadow aligncenter wp-image-73955 size-full\" src=\"https://media.coschedule.com/uploads/email-type.png\" alt=\"List email type\" width=\"1360\" height=\"254\" /> \n<div class=\"link-callout\">\n <strong>Action Item:</strong> Decide the frequency of each email type you are going to send in one campaign. We’ll cover how many emails you need to send in each campaign in the next section.\n</div> \n<div class=\"link-callout\">\n <strong><a href=\"https://coschedule.com/blog/?p=53803#toc\">Back to the Top</a></strong>\n</div> \n<a name=\"five\"></a> \n<h2>Step 5: Define the Number of Emails That Will Be Sent for This Campaign</h2> You’ll also need to identify the number of emails that need to be created for each campaign. That number can be hard to figure out. How many emails are too many? What’s the borderline between spamming your audience and sending them just the right amount of content? Start with these basic email delivery schedules for different types of content you might need to promote. \n<img class=\"alignnone wp-image-85375 size-full\" src=\"https://media.coschedule.com/uploads/2020/08/email-publishing-schedule.png\" alt=\"The best email publishing schedule\" width=\"1361\" height=\"948\" /> What if you’re doing more than just a single piece of content? What if you’re promoting a product launch? Here’s your email publishing schedule for that, too. \n<img class=\"alignnone wp-image-85376 size-full\" src=\"https://media.coschedule.com/uploads/2020/08/product-launch.png\" alt=\"Best email publishing schedule for a product launch\" width=\"1361\" height=\"1305\" /> What about a webinar email promo template? \n<img class=\"alignnone wp-image-85377 size-full\" src=\"https://media.coschedule.com/uploads/2020/08/webinar.png\" alt=\"The best publishing schedule for a webinar\" width=\"1361\" height=\"2046\" /> If you decide to send out a newsletter, try sending one \n<span style=\"text-decoration: underline;\"><a href=\"https://marketingartfully.com/2012/02/16/email-marketing-how-often-should-you-send-your-newsletter/\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener noreferrer\">at least once a month or weekly</a>,</span>&nbsp;if you can manage to create enough content. If you’re going for one a week or one a month, \n<span style=\"text-decoration: underline;\"><a href=\"https://coschedule.com/blog/best-time-to-send-email/\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener noreferrer\">send your newsletters on Wednesdays</a>,</span>&nbsp;as that is considered the best day to send emails. \n<img class=\"alignnone wp-image-85378 size-full\" src=\"https://media.coschedule.com/uploads/2020/08/newsletter.png\" alt=\"Publishing schedule for a newsletter\" width=\"1361\" height=\"1426\" /> Record each email you want to send on your calendar. \n<img class=\"drop-shadow aligncenter wp-image-73957 size-full\" src=\"https://media.coschedule.com/uploads/send-date.png\" alt=\"Establish send date\" width=\"1360\" height=\"423\" /> \n<div class=\"link-callout\"> \n <strong>Action Items:</strong> \n <ol> \n  <li>Pull the number of projected emails for each&nbsp;campaign.</li> \n  <li>List each email for the campaign in your calendar.</li> \n </ol> \n</div> \n<div class=\"link-callout\">\n <strong><a href=\"https://coschedule.com/blog/?p=53803#toc\">Back to the Top</a></strong>\n</div> \n<a name=\"six\"></a> \n<h2>Step 6: Account for Email Campaign Seasonality (as Needed)</h2> Identify which season this campaign is associated with. You could stick to the standard four, or you can also include seasonal events, like holiday shopping season. Why would you want to determine your seasons so far in advance? That’s the beauty of using an email marketing calendar; you can plan everything. By planning ahead, you can show your team when they can expect to be working on a larger number of emails and adjust their workload to accommodate them. For example,&nbsp;for a business-to-consumer retail store,&nbsp;it may&nbsp;make sense for&nbsp;your organization to&nbsp;send a lot more email during the holiday season in November and December than in March. You could have your team working on those November emails earlier in the year — or during their downtime in March — to ensure they won’t be so stressed by the time your holiday campaigns roll out. \n<img class=\"drop-shadow aligncenter wp-image-74004 size-full\" src=\"https://media.coschedule.com/uploads/buying-season-email-calendar-1.png\" alt=\"Where to find Buying Season on the Email Marketing Calendar\" width=\"1360\" height=\"194\" /> \n<div class=\"link-callout\">\n <strong>Action Item:</strong> Decide what season each email campaign is going to be sent.\n</div> \n<div class=\"link-callout\">\n <strong><a href=\"https://coschedule.com/blog/?p=53803#toc\">Back to the Top</a></strong>\n</div> \n<a name=\"seven\"></a> \n<h2>Step 7: Define The Marketing Persona You’re Targeting&nbsp;With Each Campaign</h2> If your company works with multiple marketing personas who are you trying to speak to in this campaign. \n<span style=\"text-decoration: underline;\"><a href=\"https://coschedule.com/marketing-strategy/marketing-persona\">As a </a></span>\n<span style=\"text-decoration: underline;\"><a href=\"https://coschedule.com/marketing-strategy/marketing-persona\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener noreferrer\">refresher</a></span>: \n<blockquote>\n Your marketing persona is a document that details your target audience’s who, what, when, where, and why, in addition to understanding general demographics information such as gender, job title, job function, business size, team size, needs, pain points, and challenges.\n</blockquote> If your team doesn’t have a marketing persona to work with yet, you can create your own. Start by answering the following questions: \n<ul> \n <li><strong>Who are our current best customers?</strong></li> \n <li><strong>What do our best customers all have in common?</strong></li> \n <li><strong>What problem are they experiencing?</strong></li> \n <li><strong>How did they get to the point where they were ready to search for a solution to their problem instead of trying to fix it themselves?</strong></li> \n <li><strong>Why did they go with our product over another?</strong></li> \n</ul> Once you start to see certain qualities overlap, you can format them into your marketing persona statement. This statement can be created with the following template: \n<blockquote>\n The target audience of [your organization] is looking for a solution to [problem]. We have found that our audience is more likely to experience that problem if they are [demographic], [demographic], and [demographic].\n</blockquote> Identify your persona, and record it on your calendar. \n<img class=\"drop-shadow aligncenter wp-image-74005 size-full\" src=\"https://media.coschedule.com/uploads/find-target-persona.png\" alt=\"Where to find Target Persona on the email marketing calendar\" width=\"1360\" height=\"194\" /> \n<div class=\"link-callout\"> \n <strong>Action Items:</strong> \n <ol> \n  <li>Identify your audience personas.</li> \n  <li>Choose the persona that would be most likely to respond to this campaign.</li> \n </ol> \n</div> \n<div class=\"link-callout\">\n <strong><a href=\"https://coschedule.com/blog/?p=53803#toc\">Back to the Top</a></strong>\n</div> \n<a name=\"eight\"></a> \n<h2>Step 8: Identify the Email Segment&nbsp;in Which You Are Sending This Campaign</h2> Your email calendar should also contain information about which list you plan to send this campaign. For example, you could have a campaign that goes to everyone on your list, or you could say this campaign should only go to people who attended your last webinar. However, if you don’t have an email list to send your content to,&nbsp;you won’t get very far. Plus,&nbsp;you don’t want to blast your emails to every person on your list because not all of your subscribers are in the same phase of your \n<a href=\"https://coschedule.com/blog/marketing-funnel\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener noreferrer\"><span style=\"text-decoration: underline;\">marketing funnel</span></a>. For example, if you have a customer who is just learning about your product, they don’t need to see an email that encourages them to buy right this second. How can you do all of this? First, you need to build your list. Try a few of the following tactics and see which ones your audience responds to: \n<ol> \n <li><strong>Add CTA’s to your website.</strong></li> \n <li><strong>Provide them with something of value that they can download in exchange for their email address.</strong></li> \n <li><strong>Publish content on other sites and encourage readers to learn more by joining your email list.</strong></li> \n</ol> Growing your email list is all about getting creative. The more value you can provide to your subscribers, the better. \n<div class=\"link-callout\">\n <strong>Recommended Reading:</strong> \n <a href=\"https://coschedule.com/blog/how-to-build-an-email-list/\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener noreferrer\">21+ Easy Ways To Build An Email List That Will Skyrocket By 140% In 1 Year</a>\n</div> Once you’ve built your email list, you can segment it out based on actions subscribers have taken on your site. For example, when a subscriber visits a specific product page, add that person into a specific segment for subscribers who are interested in that product. This type of action is possible with many email automation providers like \n<span style=\"text-decoration: underline;\"><a href=\"https://autopilothq.com/\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener noreferrer\">Autopilot</a></span>, \n<span style=\"text-decoration: underline;\"><a href=\"https://www.marketo.com/\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener noreferrer\">Marketo</a></span>, and \n<span style=\"text-decoration: underline;\"><a href=\"https://www.hubspot.com/\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener noreferrer\">Hubspot</a></span>. This segmenting process allows you to get specific and send targeted messages at the right time to the right subscribers. The right message at the right time can help increase your conversions if it’s done correctly. There are many different ways you can segment your list.&nbsp;\n<span style=\"text-decoration: underline;\"><a href=\"https://blog.hubspot.com/marketing/email-list-segmentation\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener noreferrer\">In fact, Hubspot has 30 of them</a></span>&nbsp;listed to help you get started. \n<img class=\"drop-shadow aligncenter wp-image-74006 size-full\" src=\"https://media.coschedule.com/uploads/email-list-calendar.png\" alt=\"Where to find Email List on the Email Marketing Calendar\" width=\"1360\" height=\"193\" /> \n<div class=\"link-callout\"> \n <strong>Action Items:</strong> \n <ol> \n  <li><a href=\"https://coschedule.com/blog/how-to-build-an-email-list/\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener noreferrer\">Build your email list</a>.</li> \n  <li>Decide how you want to segment your email list.</li> \n  <li>Choose your segments&nbsp;based on where your subscribers are at in their buying process.</li> \n </ol> \n</div> \n<div class=\"link-callout\">\n <strong><a href=\"https://coschedule.com/blog/?p=53803#toc\">Back to the Top</a></strong>\n</div> \n<a name=\"nine\"></a> \n<h2>Step 9: Consider Your Email Suppression List</h2> Once you identify who you are sending your emails to, you&nbsp;may&nbsp;need to determine who you are not sending your emails to. Maybe there is a group in your email list that needs to see a different message than the one you’ve planned for this campaign. Remember when you took all that time to segment your email marketing list? Now you can decide who doesn’t need to see specific emails you want to send. Add excluded segments to your calendar template. \n<img class=\"drop-shadow aligncenter wp-image-74007 size-full\" src=\"https://media.coschedule.com/uploads/excluded-list.png\" alt=\"Where to find suppressed email lists on the email marketing calendar\" width=\"1360\" height=\"195\" /> \n<div class=\"link-callout\">\n <strong>Action Items:</strong> Identify which of your email lists should be excluded from each&nbsp;campaign.\n</div> \n<div class=\"link-callout\">\n <strong><a href=\"https://coschedule.com/blog/?p=53803#toc\">Back to the Top</a></strong>\n</div> \n<a name=\"ten\"></a> \n<h2>Step 10: Clarify the Goal of Your Email Campaign</h2> What goal do you want your email campaign to accomplish? Are you trying to sell more of a particular product or are you trying to build awareness for your brand? Setting goals touches every single part of your marketing including your emails. These goals help define the purpose of you sending your email in the first place. Each goal you create for your email campaigns should be S.M.A.R.T or: \n<img class=\"alignnone wp-image-85379 size-full\" src=\"https://media.coschedule.com/uploads/2020/08/calendar-smart-goals.png\" alt=\"Email calendar SMART goals\" width=\"1361\" height=\"540\" /> Creating goals doesn’t have to be complicated. Since you know the topics of each of your campaigns, your goals should come naturally. For example, if you’re launching a new product, your goal could be to reach X amount of sales within one week. If you’re promoting a webinar, your goal will revolve around increasing your signups. \n<img class=\"drop-shadow aligncenter wp-image-74008 size-full\" src=\"https://media.coschedule.com/uploads/campaign-goal.png\" alt=\"Where to find Campaign Goals on the email marketing calendar\" width=\"1360\" height=\"192\" /> &nbsp; \n<div class=\"link-callout\">\n <strong>Recommended Reading:</strong> \n <a href=\"https://coschedule.com/marketing-strategy/marketing-goals\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener noreferrer\">How To Set SMART Marketing Goals</a>\n</div> \n<div class=\"link-callout\">\n <strong><a href=\"https://coschedule.com/blog/?p=53803#toc\">Back to the Top</a></strong>\n</div> \n<a name=\"eleven\"></a> \n<h2>Step 11: Write Your Email&nbsp;Subject Lines</h2> Subject lines can be a bit of a pain to write. What makes a good subject line? Should&nbsp;you include emojis in your subject lines? What language should you add in your subject lines to help increase open rates? CoSchedule just made it easy to write great subject lines with the introduction of the&nbsp;\n<span style=\"text-decoration: underline;\"><a href=\"https://coschedule.com/email-subject-line-tester\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener noreferrer\">Email Subject Line Tester</a></span>. \n<img class=\"drop-shadow aligncenter wp-image-74455 size-full\" src=\"https://media.coschedule.com/uploads/email-subject-line-tester.png\" alt=\"Screenshot of the Email Subject Line Tester\" width=\"1360\" height=\"603\" /> Hit \n<span style=\"font-weight: bold;\">Score My Subject Line,</span>&nbsp;and the tester will show you ways to improve your subject line: \n<img class=\"drop-shadow aligncenter wp-image-74011 size-full\" src=\"https://media.coschedule.com/uploads/eslt-example-1.png\" alt=\"Example from the Email Subject Line Tester\" width=\"1360\" height=\"528\" /> Include at least two subject lines for your A/B test and record them on your calendar. \n<img class=\"drop-shadow aligncenter wp-image-74017 size-full\" src=\"https://media.coschedule.com/uploads/subject-lines.png\" alt=\"Where to add subject lines to the email marketing calendar\" width=\"1360\" height=\"193\" /> \n<div class=\"link-callout\"> \n <strong>Action Items:</strong> \n <ol> \n  <li>Write potential subject lines.</li> \n  <li>Run them through the Email Subject Line Tester.</li> \n  <li>Choose your top two subject lines for your A/B test.</li> \n </ol> \n</div> \n<div class=\"link-callout\">\n <strong><a href=\"https://coschedule.com/blog/?p=53803#toc\">Back to the Top</a></strong>\n</div> \n<a name=\"twelve\"></a> \n<h2>Step 12: Determine the Dates and Times Each Email Will Be Sent</h2> What date and time is each email being sent out on? This is an essential element to establish in your email marketing calendar because it allows your marketing team to determine when they need to start working on an email to make sure that it gets done on time. First, let’s cover the best time to send your emails. \n<span style=\"text-decoration: underline;\"><a href=\"https://coschedule.com/blog/best-time-to-send-email/\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener noreferrer\">According to ten studies</a></span>&nbsp;the best times to send your emails are: \n<img class=\"alignnone wp-image-85380 size-full\" src=\"https://media.coschedule.com/uploads/2020/08/best-time-for-email.png\" alt=\"Best time to send an email\" width=\"1361\" height=\"1190\" /> While the best days to send email are: \n<img class=\"alignnone wp-image-85381 size-full\" src=\"https://media.coschedule.com/uploads/2020/08/email-calendar-day.png\" alt=\"The beset day to send an email\" width=\"1361\" height=\"1137\" /> Now that’s not to say that these are the times and days to send your emails on. You’ll need to experiment and see which days and times your audience prefers or is the most active. Try the following times and dates to start. \n<img class=\"alignnone wp-image-85382 size-full\" src=\"https://media.coschedule.com/uploads/2020/08/test-email-time.png\" alt=\"Test for the best email times and days\" width=\"1361\" height=\"868\" /> Once you have the days and times determined for each of your emails sends you can work backward to determine when your team needs to start working on the campaign to get it done on time. For example, let’s say your email publishing workflow looks something like this: \n<ul> \n <li><em>Email campaign owner chooses campaign topics and number of sends: One Day</em></li> \n <li><em>Copywriters write emails: Two Days</em></li> \n <li><em>Copywriters edit emails: One Day</em></li> \n <li><em>Campaign owner approves emails: One Day</em></li> \n <li><em>Designers create images and videos: Three Days</em></li> \n <li><em>Designers edit images and videos: One Day</em></li> \n <li><em>Images and videos are approved by campaign owner: One Day</em></li> \n <li><em>Copy and graphics are added to email platform: One Day</em></li> \n <li><em>Email lists are chosen: One Day</em></li> \n <li><em>Email is ready for publish: One Day</em></li> \n</ul> In this case, your email marketing team would need to work on a campaign at least 13 days before it begins. You may even add extra buffer days in case the work gets off course. \n<img class=\"alignnone wp-image-85383 size-full\" src=\"https://media.coschedule.com/uploads/2020/08/working-email-calendar.png\" alt=\"Your working email calendar\" width=\"1361\" height=\"1114\" /> Equipped with that information,&nbsp;you can select publish dates and times that maximize each email you send. Record your publish date times on your calendar. \n<img class=\"drop-shadow aligncenter wp-image-74019 size-full\" src=\"https://media.coschedule.com/uploads/email-send-date.png\" alt=\"Where to find Email Send Date in the Email Marketing Calendar\" width=\"1360\" height=\"422\" /> \n<div class=\"link-callout\"> \n <strong>Action Items:</strong> \n <ol> \n  <li>Using the best times to send an email and your audience’s preferences, determine what time you’re going to send your emails.</li> \n  <li>Repeat the process to decide which days you’re going to send your emails on.</li> \n  <li>Use those dates to determine when your team needs to start working on each of your campaigns.</li> \n </ol> \n</div> \n<div class=\"link-callout\">\n <strong><a href=\"https://coschedule.com/blog/?p=53803#toc\">Back to the Top</a></strong>\n</div> \n<a name=\"thirteen\"></a> \n<h2>Step 13: Plan Your Email Content</h2> Next, determine which content you'll share in each email. For the sake of this template, we will call each content block in your newsletter a \"lead story\". Each lead story should be a link, article, product, or other piece of content you'll place in the email. \n<strong>This doesn't need to be the exact email copy you'll write, just the items the email will promote</strong>. \n<img class=\"drop-shadow aligncenter wp-image-74020 size-full\" src=\"https://media.coschedule.com/uploads/plan-email-content.png\" alt=\"Plan Your Email Content on the Email Marketing Calendar\" width=\"1360\" height=\"128\" /> \n<div class=\"link-callout\">\n <strong><a href=\"https://coschedule.com/blog/?p=53803#toc\">Back to the Top</a></strong>\n</div> \n<a name=\"fourteen\"></a> \n<h2>Step 14: Include Links to Graphics and Videos That Need to Be in Each Email</h2> One of the last elements to record in your calendar are links to graphics and videos that have been created for each email in your campaign. This is important for your entire email marketing team because they need to be able to access which images and videos are associated with which email. If everything is in one folder, you run the risk of the wrong image being sent to the wrong email. \n<div class=\"link-callout\"> \n <strong>Recommended Reading:</strong> \n <ul> \n  <li><span style=\"text-decoration: underline;\"><a href=\"https://coschedule.com/blog/how-to-work-with-designers/\">How To Work With Designers With Authentic Advice From CoSchedule’s Designer</a></span></li> \n  <li><span style=\"text-decoration: underline;\"><a href=\"https://coschedule.com/blog/color-psychology-marketing/\">The Know It All Guide To Color Psychology In Marketing + The Best Hex Chart</a></span></li> \n  <li><span style=\"text-decoration: underline;\"><a href=\"https://coschedule.com/blog/how-to-make-an-infographic/\">How To Make An Infographic In 7 Easy Steps</a></span></li> \n </ul> \n</div> Each image and video should be linked to in your calendar, so it is easily accessible by the campaign owner. \n<img class=\"drop-shadow aligncenter wp-image-74021 size-full\" src=\"https://media.coschedule.com/uploads/add-images-email-content.png\" alt=\"Where to add image links to the email marketing calendar\" width=\"1360\" height=\"256\" /> \n<div class=\"link-callout\"> \n <strong>Action Items:</strong> \n <ol> \n  <li>Work with designer to create graphics or videos for your emails.</li> \n  <li>Upload them to a file storing system like Dropbox or Google Drive.</li> \n  <li>Link back to the folder in your calendar.</li> \n </ol> \n</div> \n<div class=\"link-callout\">\n <strong><a href=\"https://coschedule.com/blog/?p=53803#toc\">Back to the Top</a></strong>\n</div> \n<a name=\"fifteen\"></a> \n<h2>Step 15: Record the A/B Test Results of Your Subject Lines</h2> After you have sent your campaign, identify which of the two subject lines you created, won the A/B test. Most email service providers allow you to A/B test your subject lines within the platform. Based on how each subject line performs, your email platform will take the winning subject line and send it out to the rest of your list. \n<img class=\"drop-shadow aligncenter wp-image-74018 size-full\" src=\"https://media.coschedule.com/uploads/test-results.png\" alt=\"Email A/B Test Results in the Email Marketing Calendar\" width=\"1360\" height=\"192\" /> \n<div class=\"link-callout\"> \n <strong>Action Items:</strong> \n <ol> \n  <li>Pull the results of your A/B test.</li> \n  <li>Record the winning subject line.</li> \n </ol> \n</div> \n<div class=\"link-callout\">\n <strong><a href=\"https://coschedule.com/blog/?p=53803#toc\">Back to the Top</a></strong>\n</div> \n<a name=\"coschedule\"></a> \n<h2>How to Plan, Organize, and Schedule Email Content With CoSchedule</h2> The spreadsheet-based template included in this post is a great low-cost option to get started, but you might soon find it's somewhat limited. In that case, it may be time to consider using CoSchedule's marketing calendar and Content Organizer with email service provider integrations (MailChimp, Campaign Monitor, Active Campaign, and Constant Contact). Here's how to get set up and apply this process using CoSchedule. \n<h3>Setting Up Your Account</h3> Follow a few simple steps to get started: \n<ol> \n <li><strong>Connect your selected ESP</strong>. You can choose your provider under Settings.</li> \n <li><strong>Add team members to your account, if you haven't already</strong>. Give your team visibility into your email marketing strategy.</li> \n <li><strong>Head over to the Marketing Calendar</strong>. This is where you'll get started creating your email.</li> \n</ol> \n<img class=\"drop-shadow aligncenter wp-image-74025 size-full\" src=\"https://media.coschedule.com/uploads/cos-calendar.png\" alt=\"Example of the CoSchedule Calendar\" width=\"1360\" height=\"671\" /> Alternately, if you prefer to manage projects using a Kanban board, you can also use the Kanban Project Dashboard. \n<img class=\"drop-shadow aligncenter wp-image-74026 size-full\" src=\"https://media.coschedule.com/uploads/kanban-project-dashboard-example-1.png\" alt=\"Example of the Kanban Project Dashboard\" width=\"1360\" height=\"620\" /> \n<h3>Add an Email Newsletter to Your Marketing Calendar</h3> Now, if you have your email service provider connected to CoSchedule, you can start planning and scheduling email content. To begin, either click a day on the calendar, or click on the \n<strong>+Create</strong> button on the calendar. \n<img class=\"drop-shadow alignnone wp-image-74334 size-full\" src=\"https://media.coschedule.com/uploads/cos-calendar-copy-12.png\" alt=\"Example of the CoSchedule Calendar\" width=\"1360\" height=\"671\" /> If you're using the Kanban Project Dashboard, you can start by clicking the \n<strong>+</strong> at the top of a column, or by clicking \n<strong>+Create</strong>. \n<img class=\"drop-shadow aligncenter wp-image-74027 size-full\" src=\"https://media.coschedule.com/uploads/create-email.png\" alt=\"Progress dropdown menu for projects\" width=\"1360\" height=\"621\" /> \n<h3>Add a Description</h3> Here's a quick look at what the interface looks like within a project in CoSchedule. While we'll go through each area you see below shortly, for now, enter a text description of your email in the Description field. \n<img class=\"drop-shadow alignnone wp-image-74335 size-full\" src=\"https://media.coschedule.com/uploads/enter-text-description-13.png\" alt=\"Enter a text description in CoSchedule\" width=\"1360\" height=\"396\" /> \n<h3>Add Tags for Email Type, Buying Season, and Email List</h3> Next, you can use tags to organize email content by some of the other elements mentioned earlier in this post, like the type of email, buying season it's aimed at, email list segments that should receive it, or anything else that makes sense for your needs. Start by clicking \n<strong>+Tag</strong> underneath the Description field, and you'll see a list of tags you've created. \n<img class=\"drop-shadow aligncenter wp-image-74029 size-full\" src=\"https://media.coschedule.com/uploads/add-tag.png\" alt=\"Add a tag in CoSchedule\" width=\"1360\" height=\"578\" /> Now, how do you actually create and set which tags are available in your account? Head over to \n<strong>Settings</strong> in the left-hand navigation. \n<img class=\"drop-shadow alignnone wp-image-74339 size-full\" src=\"https://media.coschedule.com/uploads/find-settings-copy-14.png\" alt=\"Find calendar settings\" width=\"1360\" height=\"929\" /> Then, scroll down a bit to and add custom tags. \n<img class=\"drop-shadow alignnone wp-image-74346 size-full\" src=\"https://media.coschedule.com/uploads/add-custom-tags-copy-15.png\" alt=\"Add custom tags in Coschedule\" width=\"1360\" height=\"241\" /> \n<h3>Set Up a Workflow Using Task Templates + Custom Statuses</h3> When your team works on creating your email content, they'll need a clear workflow to follow. Planning those workflows into checklists will help keep production on track, ensure that deadlines are met, and remove ambiguity around who is doing what and when they'll get it done. You can do this in CoSchedule using \n<strong>Task Templates</strong>. In the screenshot below, you'll see a few things: \n<ul> \n <li><strong>Where to find your Task Templates</strong>. They're labelled in the upper right of your screen.</li> \n <li><strong>A list of templates</strong>. You can create multiple checklists for all different types of projects — not just email.</li> \n <li><strong>Controls to create, save, and duplicate task templates</strong>. This is easy to do.</li> \n</ul> \n<img class=\"drop-shadow aligncenter wp-image-74033 size-full\" src=\"https://media.coschedule.com/uploads/add-task-template-1.png\" alt=\"Add a task template\" width=\"1360\" height=\"1084\" /> Let's click on the Email Newsletter task template we have created. This will apply a checklist — note that you can customize your own task templates any way you'd like — that looks like this: \n<img class=\"drop-shadow aligncenter wp-image-74034 size-full\" src=\"https://media.coschedule.com/uploads/task-template-example-3.png\" alt=\"Add new tasks to your task template in CoSchedule\" width=\"1360\" height=\"348\" /> On the right, you'll see a few things on the checklist: \n<ul> \n <li><strong>The name of each task</strong>. What needs to get done?</li> \n <li><strong>When each task is due</strong>. You can easily adjust these deadlines.</li> \n <li><strong>Who is responsible for each task</strong>. They can check off each task when it's complete.</li> \n</ul> Now, it's likely someone on your team will need to review work before it can be considered complete. CoSchedule supports this with Task Approvals, and they're easy to set up as well. Start by clicking into a task, and then adding a team member who will need to approve that task before it can be checked off. \n<img class=\"drop-shadow aligncenter wp-image-74035 size-full\" src=\"https://media.coschedule.com/uploads/add-task-approval.png\" alt=\"Assign tasks to team members and who the tasks need approval from\" width=\"1360\" height=\"1052\" /> As work progresses on your email, you can also use Custom Statuses to indicate its level of progress. You can see the status in the bottom right. \n<img class=\"drop-shadow aligncenter wp-image-74037 size-full\" src=\"https://media.coschedule.com/uploads/custom-statuses.png\" alt=\"Customize your task progress\" width=\"1360\" height=\"1230\" /> \n<h3>Write an Email Subject Line Using the Built-In Email Subject Line Tester</h3> Once it's time to start writing your email, begin with the subject line. You can use either the standalone web version of CoSchedule's Email Subject Line Tester to start, or you can use it, built-in, with CoSchedule. \n<img class=\"drop-shadow alignnone wp-image-74347 size-full\" src=\"https://media.coschedule.com/uploads/built-in-eslt-16.png\" alt=\"Coschedule email subject line tester\" width=\"1360\" height=\"607\" /> \n<h3>Manage Workflow in CoSchedule + Set Up the Email Newsletter in Your Email Service Provider</h3> Next, you'll need to create your email content in your email service provider, but you can plan the content and organize your copy — provided you're writing copy using Google Docs or Word — in CoSchedule. Here's one way to consider approaching this. If you're creating content in Google Docs, then attach your Google Doc as an attachment to your project. You can also attach a Word Doc as a file, link content from Google Drive or Dropbox, or write copy directly in CoSchedule with the built-in text editor — use the option that best suits your workflow. \n<img class=\"drop-shadow aligncenter wp-image-74041 size-full\" src=\"https://media.coschedule.com/uploads/add-attachment.png\" alt=\"Add project attachment\" width=\"1360\" height=\"794\" /> This makes your email copy easily accessible. You can then use Discussion Threads to discuss the email as your team collaborates throughout the process. If you have images that will be designed for the email, you can use Discussion Threads to pass the files along and share feedback for review purposes as well. \n<img class=\"drop-shadow aligncenter wp-image-74042 size-full\" src=\"https://media.coschedule.com/uploads/use-discussion-threads.png\" alt=\"Using Discussion Threads\" width=\"1360\" height=\"396\" /> Then, once all your assets are created, you can set up the email in your ESP, and be ready for the final step. \n<h3>Schedule Send Date and Time</h3> Finally, it's time to actually schedule your email's delivery time and date. If you're using MailChimp, you can adjust the day and time within CoSchedule or in your ESP. Other ESPs are one-way sync only, meaning that you'll need to schedule the day and time within the ESP, but your send day and time will then be reflected on your CoSchedule calendar, too. \n<div class=\"link-callout\">\n <strong><a href=\"https://coschedule.com/blog/?p=53803#toc\">Back to the Top</a></strong>\n</div> \n<a name=\"conclusion\"></a> \n<h2><span style=\"font-family: -apple-system, BlinkMacSystemFont, 'Segoe UI', Roboto, Oxygen-Sans, Ubuntu, Cantarell, 'Helvetica Neue', sans-serif;\">Start Using Your Email Marketing Calendar to Get Organized</span></h2> Now that you have the tools and knowledge to improve your email calendar for everyday marketing, try out your newfound skills on your marketing newsletter. Master newsletter organization with the tips you've learned today, and continue learning how to get the rest of your marketing bearings in order. Ready. Set. Organize! \n<img class=\"alignnone wp-image-85384 size-full\" src=\"https://media.coschedule.com/uploads/2020/08/schedule-demo-cta.png\" alt=\"Schedule a demo with CoSchedule CTA\" width=\"1361\" height=\"581\" /> \n<em>This post was originally published on April 18, 2018. It was most recently updated and republished on Aug. 17, 2020.
